story: Guy Verhofstadt says five-week suspension unlikely to deliver stable future relationshipEuropean sources have warned that Boris Johnson‚Äôs move to suspend parliament for five weeks has increased the chances of a no-deal Brexit, while a leading MEP said: ‚ÄúTaking back control has never looked so sinister.‚ÄùThe plan to suspend parliament for five weeks, which would drastically reduce MPs‚Äô ability to influence changes to the withdrawal agreement or seek a delay, is seen in Brussels as a move to overpower rebels and force through Johnson‚Äôs Brexit agenda.The European parliament‚Äôs coordinator on Brexit, Guy Verhofstadt, said the move was unlikely to deliver a stable future relationship. ‚Äú‚ÄòTaking back control‚Äô has never looked so sinister,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúAs a fellow parliamentarian, my solidarity with those fighting for their voices to be heard. Suppressing debate on profound choices is unlikely to help deliver a stable future EU-UK relationship.‚ÄùEU officials said it heightened the chances of a no-deal outcome, as parliament could refuse to back a compromise presented to MPs, just days before the 31 October deadline.Nathalie Loiseau, a former Europe minister, who is a close ally of the French president, Emmanuel Macron, said the move showed there was a ‚Äúdisease‚Äù in British democracy.‚ÄúWe could see a Brexit without an agreement,‚Äù the MEP wrote on Twitter. ‚ÄúIt is, moreover, a Brexit without debate that is looming. From what disease is British democracy suffering from that there is a fear of debate before taking one of the most important decisions in its history?‚ÄùNorbert R”ßttgen, the chairman of the foreign affairs committee in the German Bundestag, sounded incredulous about the move. He tweeted: The request to the Queen was made as Johnson‚Äôs Brexit envoy met senior EU officials in Brussels.David Frost, the prime minister‚Äôs EU adviser, met officials working for Michel Barnier, the EU‚Äôs chief Brexit negotiator, as well Jean-Claude Juncker‚Äôs chief of staff, Clara Mart√≠nez Alberola.Frost, a former Foreign Office diplomat who went on to lead the London Chamber of Commerce and Industry, replaced Olly Robbins when Johnson took office in July.Before the meeting, Johnson saw EU leaders in Berlin, Paris and the G7 summit in Biarritz ‚Äì a series of meetings that have injected a new dynamic into talks, according to EU officials.But the move to suspend parliament is now seen as heightening the risk of no deal. It has also been pointed out that it does buy Johnson more time to strike a deal, if there are fewer parliamentary sessions.EU diplomats remain sceptical about whether the prime minister can find alternatives to the Irish backstop ‚Äì the main stumbling block ‚Äì that can win over his party.Frost was not expected to put fresh ideas on the table, while the EU is stressing that proposals need to be offered sooner rather than later. ‚ÄúI am not aware of any 30 days deadline,‚Äù an European commission spokesperson said, when asked about Johnson‚Äôs declaration that such a ‚Äúblistering timetable‚Äù existed. ‚ÄúOf course, for us, the earlier the better, because our working assumption is that Brexit should occur on 31 October and that should happen with a deal and that is our preferred scenario and the scenario we are working to. So for that to happen, the earlier we see workable proposals, the better.‚ÄùThe spokesperson said Juncker and Johnson had agreed to ‚Äúcontinue the dialogue‚Äù during a phone call between the two leaders on Tuesday evening.The EU has maintained its readiness to replace the backstop, an insurance plan to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland. Under the backstop, agreed between the EU and Theresa May, Northern Ireland would continue to follow many EU single market rules, while the UK would remain part of an EU single customs territory.The backstop would kick in automatically if the two sides failed to find an alternative and would apply until new arrangements could be agreed.Dublin remains sceptical about alternatives that have been circulating.‚ÄúI think we need to be honest here that the alternative arrangements that have been discussed to date do not do the same job as the backstop, not even close,‚Äù said Ireland‚Äôs deputy prime minister, Simon Coveney, speaking after a meeting with his Czech counterpart on Tuesday evening. ‚ÄúSo let‚Äôs not pretend that solutions exist when they might not.‚ÄùIn his call with Johnson, Juncker said the EU‚Äôs support for Ireland was ‚Äústeadfast‚Äù and that the bloc would ‚Äúcontinue to be very attentive to Ireland‚Äôs interests‚Äù.The UK government has said it is ‚Äúworking at pace to find a wide range of flexible and creative solutions to the unique circumstances on the island of Ireland‚Äù.

title: parliament only has itself to blame readers on plans to suspend parliament
story: You have been reacting in the comments to government plans to suspend parliament in the second week of SeptemberI‚Äôm sorry but parliament only has itself to blame for where we find ourselves. Parliament legislated for a two year period to negotiate a deal with no deal being the default option. They literally made this law. Parliament then proceeded to vote down multiple times the deal that was put to it despite the EU insisting that it was the only and best deal available and despite the WA being required for whatever type of Brexit transpired, even if ultimately staying in the single market. And they voted it down for their own contrived reasons, and ulterior motives. So once again, it is the members of parliament collectively responsible for where we are today. OhnoessNow‚Äôs the time to stop all tribal warfare ‚Äì serious times takes a strong coalition to fight this outrage. All parties came together during the second world war, to fight a foreign enemy, we have an internal enemy who has similar thoughts, to destroy the population and its way of life. So everybody should begin by contacting their MP and tell himher that if you support this situation, you have lost my vote. notgotaclueI cannot believe that this is the state of play in a country that was known around the world as a great proponent of democracy. If this goes ahead, by hook or by crook, it gives further credence to (re)forming the constitution and getting rid of the monarchy. Absolute shambles from a cockwomble extraordinaire. Well done, UK. Well done. awaw1283Brexiters, with their alleged love of tradition, might want to reflect on the awful position this is putting the Queen in. I‚Äôm personally agnostic on the royals, I don‚Äôt think they have any significant role in our governance, and they probably attract tourists, so fine I don‚Äôt have problem with them. However, if the Queen was drafted in to support this coup, that would be a different story. OldSynnerWhat an absolute travesty. If a government can‚Äôt get parliament to support it the correct route is a general election. The precedent this would set is abominable. GavinlBellIf Elizabeth Windsor has any sense, she‚Äôll realise that the game is up. Sitting on her hands is no longer a viable option. It‚Äôs quite obvious that during the latter part of her reign, Britain has gone from being an out-of-date democracy, to a completely broken one. Clearly it doesn‚Äôt help that it also has a broken government, and a broken opposition, but contagion spreads. That might not be entirely her fault ‚Äì the media and our politicians have clearly played a significant part ‚Äì but unless she steps in and prevents Johnson‚Äôs destruction of British democracy, she‚Äôs going to go down in the history books as the monarch who failed the country. Time for a written constitution, and for the entire political system to be overhauled. BlueThirdWhat this government is doing is an anti-democratic coup, pure and simple. If the scarcely believable reports this morning are accurate, it will show (i) the weaknesses wrought by lack of a written constitution, and (ii) further evidence (if any were needed) of the utter uselessness of the monarch as any kind of democratic safeguard. Anyone who wondered what defences this country had against an authoritarian executive has their answer. There needs to be legislation andor a vote of no confidence in the week beginning 3 September. And MPs like Rory Stewart, Gubb, Lee, Letwin and Grieve need to put their money where their mouths are. This is democracy at stake. hendchard11Unbelievable is all I can say. The UK is going down the same road as America where one half of the country hates the other half. If this goes ahead and parliament is shut down, it will surely rank amongst one of the worst abuses of power in any modern democracy. You can absolutely kiss the union goodbye with this and the further result of this will be a humbled England that is a vassal state of America. Shocking events at one level and disgusting at another. andrew_arrow

title: spending review set for next week fuels election speculation live
story: Government will prorogue parliament in September, with Queen‚Äôs speech on 14 OctoberThe Lib Dem leader, Jo Swinson, has written to the Queen to ask for a meeting in light of the prime minister ‚Äústifling the voices of both the people and their representatives‚Äù.Further to this post about the geographical spread of the signatories on the petition against the proroguing of parliament, this nifty tool allows you to check how many people in your constituency have signed it. 1,627 people in Jeremy Corbyn‚Äôs constituency have signed it so far, compared with 199 in Boris Johnson‚Äôs seat of Uxbridge and South Ruislip.(The petition has nearly 287,000 signatures now, by the way.)The Brexit secretary, Stephen Barclay, has accused the French government of leaving British people resident in the country behind after Brexit, writes Lisa O‚Äôcarroll.Speaking at a conference in Paris organised by the French business group Medef, Barclay said Brits in France would be left with fewer rights than those of the 300,000 French nationals in the UK in the event of no deal.‚ÄúWe have guaranteed the rights of the approximately 300,000 French nationals and indeed all EU nationals living in the UK,‚Äù said Barclay. ‚ÄúI call on the French government and others in the EU to match our offer and provide certainty for UK nationals in France.‚ÄùThe value of the pound fell sharply against the euro and the dollar this morning after Boris Johnson announced plans to suspend parliament, raising the chances of a no-deal exit from the EU. Sterling fell by more than a cent against the US dollar to a six-day low of below $1.22, and by almost as much against the euro, to ‚Ç¨1.096.Here‚Äôs our story:The Sun‚Äôs political editor is reporting some ‚Äúserious disquiet‚Äù in government about Boris Johnson‚Äôs new strategy.This is a great explainer by Jessica Elgot on what exactly prorogation is and why the prime minister is using it.The Press Association is reporting that a group of Church of England bishops has issued an open letter outlining their particular concerns over the prospect of a no-deal Brexit.Twenty-five bishops signed the letter warning of the potential cost of a no-deal Brexit to ‚Äúthose least resilient to economic shocks‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe sovereignty of parliament is not just an empty term, it is based on institutions to be honoured and respected: our democracy is endangered by cavalier disregard for these,‚Äù they said.The archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, said on Tuesday he would be willing to chair a citizens‚Äô forum on Brexit ‚Äúin principle‚Äù after being approached by senior MPs. ‚ÄúThe archbishop of Canterbury has conditionally agreed to chair a citizens forum in Coventry and, without prejudice for any particular outcome, we support this move to have all voices in the current Brexit debate heard,‚Äù said the bishops.‚ÄúHowever, we also have particular concerns about the potential cost of a no-deal Brexit to those least resilient to economic shocks.‚ÄùBoris Johnson has placed the Queen ‚Äúin the firing line‚Äù over Brexit, according to the anti-monarchy campaign group Republic. It floated the possibility that a parliamentary crisis could become a royal crisis.Republic‚Äôs spokesman, Graham Smith, said Johnson had thrown British politics into a deep crisis ‚Äúand has shone a spotlight on the impotence of the Queen and the role of the monarch‚Äôs powers‚Äù.‚ÄúAlready people are petitioning the Queen to intervene, but she won‚Äôt. Not because she can‚Äôt, but because the Queen‚Äôs first priority is always the preservation of the monarchy.‚ÄúBut Johnson‚Äôs decision to prorogue parliament has created a unique crisis for the Queen. The convention is that the Queen does as she‚Äôs told by the PM. But in normal times the PM has the full support of a majority in the Commons.‚Äù‚ÄúConstitutionally the Queen is free to decide whether or not to go along with the government‚Äôs plans or support the sovereign parliament. So the Queen has a choice to make, and she‚Äôs damned if she does and damned if she doesn‚Äôt.‚ÄùSmith added: ‚ÄúWill the public care about the constitutional niceties? How much the Queen fulfils the public‚Äôs expectations and hopes will determine how much the parliamentary crisis becomes a royal crisis.‚ÄùFor the record, a YouGov poll in the run-up to last year‚Äôs royal marriage of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle found that seven in 10 Britons support Britain continuing to have a monarchy.The shadow attorney general, Shami Chakrabarti, has told BBC Radio 5 Live that ‚Äúopposition parties will be more united‚Äù as a result of Boris Johnson‚Äôs prorogation of parliament. She described the move as ‚Äúunconstitutional and unlawful‚Äù and said she had ‚Äúlittle doubt that the courts will step up to protect our parliament and parliamentary democracy‚Äù.They think they can get away with shutting down parliament because it‚Äôs inconvenient, and that is unconstitutional and unlawful in our country ‚Ä¶ None of us voted for a prime minister to shut down parliament because it‚Äôs annoying.Chakrabarti said the first step would be to mount a parliamentary challenge, before considering legal action.We will work across parties to defeat this strategy in parliament. And I hope it doesn‚Äôt come to it, but if down the road it ends up in the courts, I have little doubt that the courts will step up to protect our parliament and parliamentary democracy.She also said of Boris Johnson:He‚Äôs been getting away with blue murder, but this time he‚Äôs gone too far.That petition is now at 175,000 signatures. It had 14,000 just over two hours ago. Once a petition gets more than 100,000 signatures it must be considered for a debate in parliament.You can see where in the country the signatories come from by looking at this heatmap. It‚Äôs interesting to see the dark red patches in places such as London, Brighton, Oxford and Cambridge, as well as the more affluent parts of big northern cities such as Manchester and Sheffield.Jeremy Corbyn has said Labour will do everything it can to prevent what he described as a ‚Äúsmash and grab‚Äù operation on the part of the government.‚ÄúI have protested in the strongest possible terms on behalf of my party and all the other opposition parties that are going to join in with this in saying that suspending parliament is not acceptable, It‚Äôs not on,‚Äù the Labour leader said in a clip pooled to broadcasters.‚ÄúWhat the prime minister is doing is a sort of smash and grab on our democracy in order to force through a no-deal exit from the European Union. What is he so afraid of that he has to suspend parliament in order to prevent parliament discussing these matters?Corbyn said the first thing Labour would do was to put forward legislation to prevent the suspension, and than there would be a challenge in the form of a vote of no confidence.Asked about plans by a cross-party group of MPs to hold an alternative parliament, and calls by some Labour MPs for people to take to the streets, he replied: ‚ÄúWe will do everything that we can. We will join everybody else in doing that.‚ÄùMick Whelan, the general secretary of the train drivers‚Äô trade union, Aslef, has said Boris Johnson‚Äôs decision to ‚Äútry to sideline parliament in the run-up to Brexit‚Äù could cause civil unrest.Whatever your views on Brexit, the democratic process must underpin what is done in all our names ‚Äì or civil unrest will be the result.It is disturbing that a prime minister who only has a mandate from the Conservative party and not from the electorate is trying to undermine the foundations of our democracy.And while people did vote, three years ago, to leave the European Union, no one voted to leave without a deal. The best way forward is to call a general election and let the people decide.The political commentator Paul Mason has called on people to gather in central London tonight to protest against the government‚Äôs planned suspension of parliament.‚Äôs chief political correspondent, Jessica Elgot, has a useful caveat here on how much parliamentary time will be lost through the prorogation.In practice, MPs are only likely to lose between four and six sitting days in parliament, depending on which day parliament is prorogued in the second week of September. MPs would have been due to hold conference recess from 12 September until 7 October. Given that MPs do not generally sit on Fridays, it means MPs will not be able to sit for four days until the following Monday, 14 October. They could also lose days in the second week of September, depending on what day parliament is prorogued in the week beginning 9 September. However, one key new obstacle is that any legislation that is incomplete ahead of prorogation will fall, meaning MPs would have to pass any anti-no-deal legislation in its entirety either before prorogation or in the three weeks leading up to 31 October.Jeremy Corbyn has written to the Queen expressing concern about the move by Boris Johnson, reports our colleague Heather Stewart.The Labour MP Clive Lewis has said the police will have to remove him and other MPs from the chamber of the House of Commons if parliament is shut down.Charlie Falconer, the Labour peer and former lord chancellor, has also been tweeting:

title: childhood happiness lowest level in decade says report
story: Charity describes finding that 200,000 are not content with their lives as ‚Äònational scandal‚ÄôChildhood happiness has fallen to its lowest level in a decade, with more than 200,000 children unhappy with their lives, according to a report.For the first time since it was launched in 2009-10, the annual Good Childhood report found overall contentment among 10- to 15-year-olds has dipped below eight on a scale of one to 10. It now stands at 7.89 on average, down from a high of 8.21 in 2011, at a time when adult wellbeing is improving.The Children‚Äôs Society, which conducted the research, said the decline in childhood happiness was a national scandal. The charity called on Boris Johnson to move the issue to the top of his agenda and introduce a national measurement of children‚Äôs wellbeing.The report is based on an annual survey of about 2,400 households and a longitudinal study involving 40,000 households.It found a significant dip in contentment about friends and school among both boys and girls and an increase in unhappiness among boys about their appearance.Asked why he is unhappy with his appearance, one boy surveyed said: ‚ÄúLike Instagram and stuff, right? You see all these models, you see all these weightlifters, bodybuilders, and you look at yourself and you‚Äôre like: ‚ÄòI look like a stick.‚Äô I feel like we‚Äôre exposed to a lot more, so we are less secure about our appearance.‚ÄùRichard Crellin, the policy and research manager at the Children‚Äôs Society, said the research provided observational data, so it was difficult to pinpoint reasons for the decline in childhood happiness.‚ÄúThe latest ONS data for adults suggests wellbeing is increasing and improving. Adults tend to be slightly less happy than children, but the proportion with high wellbeing is improving, whereas it is declining for children.‚ÄùMark Russell, the chief executive of the Children‚Äôs Society, said: ‚ÄúModern childhood is a happy and carefree time for most, yet for too many it is not. It is a national scandal that children‚Äôs unhappiness is increasing so quickly.‚ÄúWe are urging the government to introduce a national measurement of children‚Äôs wellbeing so we can really listen, respond and show young people they matter.‚ÄùJonathan Ashworth, the shadow health secretary, said the report should act as ‚Äúwake-up call to ministers‚Äù.He added: ‚ÄúOur children‚Äôs health should be a national priority, yet after nine years of austerity, the government‚Äôs response to the issue of child health has been piecemeal as it continues to squeeze the NHS and take money from our public health system and schools.‚ÄùA government spokeswoman said: ‚ÄúWe want young people growing up in a modern Britain to feel confident tackling the challenges life throws at them. That is why we‚Äôre giving teachers the power to deal with bad behaviour and bullying in the classroom, investing billions every year in mental health support for young people, and providing quicker access to specialist treatment where needed.‚Äù

title: we need to talk about the menopause as loudly as we can says campaigner
story: Campaigner, who was once a fixture on the Britpop scene, had no idea what was going on when she became perimenopausal‚ÄúI consider myself a woman of the world and I didn‚Äôt know what being perimenopausal was,‚Äù says Meg Mathews, the former music PR. But since launching a blog about the menopause in 2017, she has become a prominent campaigner on the subject.Mathews believes the subject is not discussed as much as it should be. ‚ÄúWe need to talk about the menopause as loudly and as much as we can because we have to get past the stigma and shame our society places on the menopause,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe have to break the taboo.‚ÄùNow 53 and on hormone replacement therapy, Mathews started going through her menopause at 49, although she now thinks she was perimenopausal in her early 40s. It hit her hard, but she had no idea what was going on.‚ÄúThe only thing I knew about the menopause was hot flushes and no more periods ‚Äì but I wasn‚Äôt getting those two symptoms,‚Äù she says. Mathews later found out through her own research that she had been suffering 32 of the 34 lesser-known symptoms of menopause, including burning mouth, mood swings, problems sleeping, hair loss and low libido. Her GP prescribed her antidepressants to no effect.The menopause is a natural part of ageing and usually occurs between 45 and 55 years of age after levels of the hormone oestrogen have declined to the point where ovulation and menstruation stop. It is defined as a woman going 12 months without a period. In the UK, the average age for a woman to reach the menopause is 52. However, about one in 100 women have their menopause before the age of 40.Common symptoms can include hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal dryness and discomfort during sex, a reduced sex drive, low moods or anxiety and difficulty sleeping. Memory and concentration can also be affected.&nbsp‚ÄúBut I couldn‚Äôt tell anyone: my mum had recently died, so I couldn‚Äôt talk to her, and we all know about ‚ÄòMeg Mathews‚Äô rock and roll lifestyle‚Äô,‚Äù she says, referring to her reputation as a fixture on the 1990s Britpop party scene ‚Äì she was married to Oasis‚Äôs Noel Gallagher for four years. ‚ÄúI thought it had all caught up with me,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI told everyone I had glandular fever and didn‚Äôt go out of the house for three months.‚ÄùThen, at an AA meeting, she stood up to tell the room that she thought she was going mad. ‚ÄúA woman approached me afterwards, saying that I wasn‚Äôt going mad I was having my menopause. I went to an NHS menopause clinic, which I didn‚Äôt even know existed, and the light switched on. I was like, ‚ÄòOh God, I have had all those years feeling like this ‚Äì why isn‚Äôt it talked about?‚Äô‚ÄùMaking sure the menopause is talked about has become one of Matthew‚Äôs driving forces. In 2017, she started a blog about the menopause. It features articles and Q&ampAs from menopause specialists, real-life experiences ‚Äì including her own ‚Äì and lists of products Mathews says have helped her.The blog has been a runaway success, with a million visitors in its first six months. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve held two conferences in London with a range of the country‚Äôs best specialists talking on a wide range of topics. For the second one, in May this year, the tickets sold out,‚Äù she says.Mathews has given talks in unlikely places, including at the Foreign Office‚Äôs services ision: ‚ÄúThey opened the phone lines to every embassy and Commonwealth office around the world so that they could listen in, too,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt went so well that they invited me back to their main office in Milton Keynes to talk to their employees there.‚ÄùShe has spoken at the British Library and the BBC, and is in discussions to speak at another government department.This, says Mathews, is just the start. ‚ÄúI want to take my conferences nationwide,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI want to help women create a sisterhood network, like Weight Watchers, where they meet weekly in a village hall-type setting to discuss their symptoms and swap advice because many women don‚Äôt have anyone to talk to ‚Äì we‚Äôre in a bubble in London. I have learned everything just through my network of women.‚ÄùMathews plans to lobby the government for trained nurse practitioners to act as the first port of call for women experiencing menopausal symptoms ‚Äì and to persuade writers of soaps to include a menopause storyline.‚ÄúThere have been storylines about paedophiles, rape, murders and drug addiction, LGBT issues ‚Äì but they have never had Bet Lynch behind the bar having a hot sweat,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúSoaps play a pivotal role in helping to start conversations within families on a national scale. So many women probably don‚Äôt know how to explain to their husbands what‚Äôs going on. But if it was on a TV show as a storyline, it‚Äôd be ‚Äòlook at what‚Äôs going on in EastEnders, she‚Äôs got the menopause!‚Äô‚Äù

title: helping nine year old eating disorder recovery podcast
story: We hear about the importance of early intervention in rare cases of pre-teen eating disorders. Plus, calls to ban hands-free phone use while drivingMaggie and her husband James have four daughters. While their oldest, Hattie, was still at primary school, she began severely restricting the amount she ate and exercising obsessively.  Eating disorders in young people can be life-threatening, although this wasn‚Äôt the case for Hattie. Her case was unusual because of the age at which her problems began ‚Äì she was nine.  Maggie and James tell Anushka Asthana they want to share their experience because it reveals something about the pressures on girls, the impact on families and the services that can help.  Also today: Gwyn Topham on the MPs calling for a ban on using hands-free phone kits while driving after seeing evidence of how distracting they can be.   Names and voices in this episode have been altered

title: mako vunipola injury world cup japan tongo italy jack nowell
story: ‚Ä¢ Prop Vunipola to miss Italy trip but likely to be ready for Tonga‚Ä¢ Exeter wing Nowell‚Äôs Japan chances in the balance, says coachEngland prop Mako Vunipola, whose injury was the sole blight on their record 57-15 demolition of Ireland at Twickenham, has a small tear of scar tissue in his hamstring which will need some 10 days of rehabilitation to heal.That will be a huge relief for Eddie Jones as his England squad fly out to Treviso to continue their preparations for next month‚Äôs World Cup in Japan with a final warmup match, against Italy on 6 September at St James‚Äô Park.Ben Moon has been called up to Jones‚Äôs squad as a temporary replacement for Vunipola, who needed surgery to reattach tendons after tearing his hamstring for Saracens in May.But the prospects of wing Jack Nowell‚Äôs chances of playing in Japan are ‚Äòtouch and go‚Äô, according to his club coach Rob Baxter. The 26 year old injured his ankle in Exeter‚Äôs Premiership final defeat by Saracens in June, but was included in England‚Äôs 31-man squad.‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs going to be touch and go for involvement in the World Cup,‚Äù Baxter told BBC Radio Devon. ‚ÄúBut let‚Äôs cross our fingers and hope that he can come through.‚ÄùAfter facing Italy, England fly to Japan on 8 September ahead of the Rugby World Cup. They begin their World Cup campiagn against Tonga on Sunday 22 September.

title: nick kyrgios accuses atp of being corrupt after us open win
story: Nick Kyrgios has accused the ATP of being corrupt in the aftermath of his US Open first-round win over American Steve Johnson at Flushing Meadows.The tennis firebrand was asked what he thought about being fined a record $US113,000 ($A167,000) for his spectacular meltdown in Cincinnati this month.‚ÄúThe ATP is pretty corrupt anyway. I‚Äôm not fussed about it at all,‚Äù he said in a development that will almost certainly force the governing body of men‚Äôs tennis to suspend the Australian, having already said it was considering such a move.‚ÄúI was fined $113K for what? Why are we talking about something that happened three weeks ago when I just chopped up someone first round of a US Open?‚ÄùUS Open officials had given Kyrgios the green light to play the final grand slam of the year despite tennis chiefs continuing to weigh up whether or not the temperamental talent should be suspended for his latest outburst in Cincinnati.The ATP offered no time line around when it would make any decision on Kyrgios‚Äôs fate when quizzed on the eve of the Open, which started on Monday.Believed to be the biggest fine in the sport‚Äôs history, Kyrgios was slapped with separate penalties for an audible obscenity, ball abuse, verbal abuse towards the umpire, leaving the court and four counts of unsportsmanlike conduct during his explosive second-round loss to Karen Khachanov.In addition to the fines, the ATP said it was ‚Äúlooking further into what happened during and immediately after the match to see if additional action is warranted under the Player Major Offence section of the code and that could result in an additional fine andor suspension‚Äù.But the 24-year-old was unrepentant after progressing to the second round at Flushing Meadows.‚ÄúHave you ever sworn at someone before?‚Äù he countered at a journalist. ‚Äú... You‚Äôre not an elite athlete.‚Äù Asked if he was saying it was acceptable for elite athletes to swear, he said: ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm just saying people get frustrated. It happens.‚ÄùEarlier, Kyrgios delivered heaps of brilliant shotmaking and a sprinkle of controversy in his 6-3, 7-6 (7-1), 6-4 win that put him into a second-round meeting with Frenchman Antoine Hoang, who beat Argentine Leonardo Mayer.Kyrgios was laser-focused for the first half of the match as he deployed a lethal mix of monster serves, stinging forehands and smart net play but nearly unravelled when he got agitated over a fan who interrupted his ball toss. The 28th seed was serving at 4-4 in the second set when a woman trying to get to her seat entered his line of sight during his serve, at which point an annoyed Kyrgios asked aloud if she was alright. Kyrgios then looked to the chair umpire who said he could not have prevented the interruption because he did not see it since he was focused on the players. But a clearly perturbed Kyrgios was not happy with that explanation and following a verbal exchange was given a code violation warning for an audible obscenity. After Kyrgios held serve to go 5-4 up he resumed his back-and-forth with the umpire on the changeover at which point a clearly annoyed Johnson asked his opponent when he was going to ‚Äúplay fucking tennis‚Äù. Kyrgios, who has repeatedly got in trouble for on-court actions and is known for his short temper, did not let the incident affect his sublime play as he settled right back down to business. The Australian blitzed Johnson in the second set tiebreak where he showed his lighter side when he broke into a little dance after chasing down a dropshot he sent back for a brilliant crosscourt winner and a commanding 6-0 cushion. ‚ÄúIt was pretty clean,‚Äù Kyrgios said of the tiebreak. ‚ÄúI knew it was an important set. If he got that set the match could have been different and we‚Äôd still be playing right now.‚Äù Johnson, who was being thoroughly outplayed, did manage to finally earn his first break to get to within 3-1 in the third set but Kyrgios relied on his massive serve to carry him over the finish line.

title: greatest cricket test of all headingley 2019 ashes
story: Being broad-minded, we had an unbeliever to stay the weekend. At some point on Sunday afternoon I yelled out of the window: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got to come and see this! It‚Äôs the most astonishing game!‚Äù A languorous, world-weary voice replied from the garden: ‚ÄúCricket! Always astonishing. Always historic. Always unprecedented.‚Äù She never budged.It is true that this was cricket‚Äôs second astonishing-historic-unprecedented Sunday in six weeks. It is also true it was being shown on Sky, whose policy is that everything must be treated as a-h-u even if it‚Äôs a goalless draw between Barrow and Boreham Wood. Which makes it hard to recognise an a-h-u when you see it. And on Sunday we really did (except our visitor).On such occasions, it is easy to get confused between a great game and a great finish. The World Cup final was a fairly typical 50-over contest, spiced up by the gravity of the occasion and the StokesButtler‚Äëled revival of the England innings. Planet Earth spectacularly lurched off its axis in the final moments but Headingley ‚Äô19 had more.There have been 2,358 Test matches played since 1877. In terms of closeness Headingley 2019 has a lot of competition. Two Tests have been tied, both involving Australia, against West Indies and India. Two have been drawn with the scores level and the fourth innings still in progress, the first being the ‚Äúwe flippin‚Äô murdered ‚Äôem‚Äù Test in Bulawayo in 1996, named after the scorecard-defying response of England‚Äôs coach, David Lloyd, perhaps the most quoted of all his many quotable comments.There has been a one-run win (West Indies over Australia in 1993), a two- runner (Edgbaston 2005 of beloved memory) and two three‚Äërunners, also both Ashes Tests, at Old Trafford in 1902 and Melbourne 80 years later. This time England‚Äôs win was by one wicket, which is in itself no big deal. It was the 14th in all and not even the first this year (Sri Lanka did the same to South Africa in February).Indeed, 18 Ashes Tests have been decided by one or two wickets or fewer than 20 runs. The score in these matches is 13-5 to England, and Australia‚Äôs last win was in 1925. This stat must mean something but I‚Äôm not sure what. The British ability to defy seemingly impossible odds (Betfair made them a 35-1 chance at one stage on Sunday)?England were of course 500-1 at Headingley in 1981 but that was more PR stunt than serious assessment. There is a school of thought that this long-ago win wrecked English cricket for years, making the team dependent on blind optimism rather than logic, practice and application. For God‚Äôs sake don‚Äôt pass the 13-5 figure to Downing Street. It‚Äôll make things 10 times worse.Many superlatives have been offered these past couple of days. For Ben Stokes and his magnificent sidekick Jack Leach: Sancho Panza to his Quixote Tonto to his Lone Ranger Passepartout to his Phileas Fogg. Their stand passes the a-h-u exam with flying colours. Stokes took dozens of risks and got away with them brilliantly. It was indeed the stuff of fiction. But the greatest innings of all time, as some suggest? It might not be quite the same (an old fogey writes) as a few of Don Bradman‚Äôs.Assessing whether this was the greatest cricket match ever played is also tricky. Quality would be one criterion and, as we all know, England‚Äôs first-innings batting was atrocious. And Australia were without their best player. You do remember Steve Smith? But you can only play the opposition who turn up and quality is also hard to quantify. All sport is about making fewer mistakes than the opposition.Was Headingley compelling from start to finish? Almost. Australia‚Äôs second innings was a dire time but perhaps not to an Australian. And in hindsight that slow buildup of English pain was crucial to the plot ‚Äì the way great detective novels accrete evidence, all pointing to the wrong suspect.Above all, because the Ashes were on the line, presumed already won and lost, the match had context. Headingley in 1981 and Edgbaston in 2005 were important battles that turned the tide at the time but both came early in the series and neither could have settled the war on their own, whoever won.The most enjoyable Test I watched involved Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart defying the West Indies quicks and conjuring a three-wicket victory in Trinidad in 1998. But that was a very personal memory and meant little in the great scheme of things. Athers was gone as captain five weeks later, something that may yet happen to Joe Root in three.The most compelling I remember was the Centenary Test at Melbourne in March 1977. The Ashes were not at stake ‚Äì it was a one-off ‚Äì and it was invisible from Britain but the memory of listening from my dingy flat to Derek Randall‚Äôs epic 174 is with me for ever. Hardly anyone knew the camaraderie of that occasion was greased by the fact most of the players were plotting to desert Test cricket and join the breakaway led by the tycoon Kerry Packer.The original tied Test, in Brisbane in 1960, had an impact that surged across the cricketing world. Hardly anyone saw it at the time ‚Äì even Australia‚Äôs No 1 commentator, Alan McGilvray, was so certain of defeat he took an early plane home. But it set up a terrific series: the excitement, after much dourness in the 1950s, the class of the players and the amity between the teams helped rekindle enthusiasm for the game.With that match a close second, I think ‚Äì for its twists, turns and thrills and its collective and inidual sense of redemption ‚Äì Headingley ‚Äô19 may be the best of them all.Note to readers: The above column contains no criticism of the ECB, ICC, MCC or any other component of the alphabet soup that runs cricket. Normal service will be resumed shortly.

title: lewis hamilton alexander albon f1
story: Having enjoyed his best opening 12 races, Lewis Hamilton is in position to seal his sixth world championship with his most successful season. That the title, which will move him above Juan Manuel Fangio and behind only Michael Schumacher, is in his grasp is beyond doubt. He has already won eight races, to lead his Mercedes teammate Valtteri Bottas by 62 points, and Hamilton usually only improves on the run-in. Last year he won four of the first five races after the summer break nine races remain, starting with this weekend‚Äôs Belgian grand prix, and with four more victories he will have surpassed his previous best of 11 in a season. Hamilton has been explicit in insisting he is taking nothing for granted yet he is in the form of his life and motivated as never before. Closing out the championship by leaving the opposition scattered and reeling will be his target as Schumacher‚Äôs record seven titles looks eminently reachable next season.This time last year Formula One looked a world away for the London-born Thai driver Alexander Albon. Yet when racing resumes he will make his debut for Red Bull in his rookie season after only 12 F1 races. He was set to compete in Formula E‚Äôs 2018-19 season until a late call-up to Toro Rosso. He has impressed there and as Pierre Gasly fell apart at Red Bull they unexpectedly promoted the 23-year-old Albon into a race-winning car, alongside the intimidating No 1 driver, Max Verstappen. With few alternatives on offer and Red Bull desperate to have a driver to back up Verstappen at the front, a strong performance could secure Albon‚Äôs place for next season and beyond. He was impressive in coming up to speed at Toro Rosso with little preparation and the Red Bull should suit his smooth driving style. Albon has an opportunity most drivers can only dream of how he faces the challenge will be fascinating.After a process that began soon after Liberty took over the sport in 2017, the end-of-October deadline for signing-off new regulations for 2021 looms large. Delayed once this year already, the plan devised by the director of motor sports, Ross Brawn, intended to improve the racing could not be of greater import. What is agreed will shape the sport and what has already been a tortuous process is likely to become increasingly tense as the days count down. Several midfield teams have warned the proposals are in danger of being watered down by the leading marques, who want to maintain their advantage. Equally, a new concorde agreement between competitors and Liberty has yet to be signed for 2021. Confidence in how competitive they can be under the new regulations will play a part for the smaller teams in those negotiations, with Gene Haas already warning F1 has to make sporting and financial sense if teams such as his are to remain. This is the first vital test for F1 in the Liberty era.Mercedes have swept into the distance in the constructors‚Äô championship, 150 points clear of Ferrari, but behind them every race is vital. Ferrari are still struggling with their car and winless, while Red Bull are snapping at their heels thanks to Verstappen‚Äôs two victories. They trail the Scuderia by 44 points and the Dutchman is third, ahead of Sebastian Vettel, in the drivers‚Äô championship. Verstappen and Red Bull clearly sense Ferrari blood in the water. The team have gone from strength to strength and if Albon can perform where Gasly failed, they could take the fight for second to the wire. Behind them McLaren are a team reborn with Lando Norris and Carlos Sainz revelling in their competitive car. They are fourth in the championship, 39 points in front of Toro Rosso and 43 in front of Renault. After the turmoil of recent years they look to be firing collectively, reminiscent of the team that once towered over the sport. Holding fourth would be their best finish since 2012 but it is far from a given a tooth-and-nail scrap may well define the midfield run-in.Jockeying in the drivers‚Äô market will begin in earnest when racing resumes at Spa. The decision that will likely set the dominoes in motion is whether Mercedes will drop Bottas for their protege Esteban Ocon as Hamilton‚Äôs partner. Toto Wolff, the team principal, said they would consider it over the summer and it seems likely they will announce their choice, now expected to be to stick with Bottas, at Spa. There is considerable trading still to be done, however. The Red Bull drive might yet be open should Albon not make the grade and, although highly unlikely, a return to his former team has been rumoured for Vettel, despite the German being contracted with Ferrari until the end of the 2020 season. Romain Grosjean at Haas, Antonio Giovinazzi at Alfa Romeo and Renault‚Äôs Nico H√ºlkenberg are all out of contract and the last of these is expected to be replaced by Ocon should Mercedes retain Bottas. Racing Point are likely to stick with Lance Stroll and Sergio P√©rez, as will Williams with George Russell, but the latter will likely replace Robert Kubica with their reserve driver Nicholas Latifi. McLaren have already confirmed Norris and Sainz for next season.

title: shock and bore how dave chappelle lost his comic touch
story: In his controversial Michael Jackson-defending, trans-attacking Netflix special, the once-groundbreaking comedian shows his power has been diminishedIt all goes back to Lenny Bruce and Richard Pryor, or at least the reputation they left behind as a legacy. The two continue to inspire up-and-coming comedians due to their lionized status as embattled truth-tellers, men whose jokes were so searingly incisive about human hypocrisy that the culture‚Äôs tongue-cluckers couldn‚Äôt handle the truth. Bruce in particular stands today as something between a rock star and martyr, the angry young subversive with a tight fifteen so powerful that the squares had to put him in handcuffs and drag him off the stage. At the time, rabble-rousers like Bruce and Pryor knew they were doing something right when people got angry at them. They prided themselves on it, in the knowledge that shaking the foundations of the old guard ‚Äì their religion, their etiquette, their sexual hangups ‚Äì made their voices vital and exciting.This is almost certainly how Dave Chappelle sees himself, judging from the material and delivery in Sticks and Stones, his fifth stand-up special recorded as part of his twenty-million-a-pop deal with Netflix. He opens with an epigram from Kendrick Lamar, triumphantly declaring, ‚ÄúTell me somethin‚Äô  you mothafuckas can‚Äôt tell me nothin‚Äô  I‚Äôd rather die than to listen to you.‚Äù It‚Äôs a defiant middle finger extended in the direction of the critics, notifying whatever haters may have tuned in out of perverse curiosity that he will not be deterred by their words. Indeed, Chappelle has come under fire as of late for saying things he should not say, the very same charge that Bruce and Pryor were slapped with decades earlier. But only if a person thinks about the ire directed at these provocateurs that broadly, with no mind to the specifics of their respective situations, does the comparison hold up.A single moment‚Äôs consideration would reveal that there‚Äôs a big difference between Lamar telling the hosts of Fox News that he won‚Äôt be their talking point in bad-faith conversations about the societal effects of hip-hop, and Dave Chappelle taking potshots at the transgender community. Trans people ‚Äì referred to as ‚Äúthe Ts‚Äù in an extended run about ‚Äúthe alphabet people‚Äù that make up the LGBTQ community, as if Chappelle will melt like the Wicked Witch of the West if he even says the word ‚Äì really take it on the shins, but they‚Äôve got plenty of company. Chappelle speaks out against Michael Jackson‚Äôs accusers, stating in no uncertain terms that ‚ÄúI do not believe these motherfuckers‚Äù to whistles and cheers of approval from the audience. An assortment of his hotter takes plays like an exoneration wishlist: Kevin Hart‚Äôs a good guy, Louis CK never did anything wrong, and even if the King of Pop did prey on innocent children, ‚ÄúI mean, it‚Äôs Michael Jackson.‚ÄùChappelle likes to play sheepish when airing what he knows will be his more polarizing opinions, repeatedly doing the classic ‚Äúdrop the punch line, throw your hands up, and walk upstage‚Äù bit to playact stepping away from the fallout of his jokes. He puts on the Bugs Bunny gee-ain‚Äôt-I-a-stinker face as he qualifies with transparent sarcasm, ‚ÄúFar be it from me to offend anybody!‚Äù He even gives the timeless defense of the indefensible and mentions more than once that he has gay friends, perhaps in the hopes that they will form a protective phalanx around his ideas.The public hailed Chappelle as a shit-stirring seer for so long, and for the most part rightly, that he cannot part with that image of himself even as it rapidly sours. In the worst-case scenario, this trajectory ultimately sends him the way of Ricky Gervais, currently locked in an increasingly sweaty campaign to get a rise out of his audience with the same tired jabs. That‚Äôs the most meaningful front on which Sticks and Stones fails for all his power to offend, Chappelle has utterly lost the power to shock.The predictability has been the most dispiriting part about watching the master lose his touch over the past couple of specials. Excepting one little tease facetiously implying that he may have had sex with a fourteen-year-old, none of the lines raise an eyebrow. We‚Äôre locked into a routine, both the performer and the critical corps professionally obligated to take his bait, his transgressions every bit as preordained as our objections to them. Even for someone uninterested in pondering the particulars of who he‚Äôs making angry and why, Chappelle‚Äôs got to recognize another major difference between his predecessors and himself in their reception. Those familiar with his recent output click into the newest knowing full well what they‚Äôre in for, leading to the same restricting self-selection of opinion that one might otherwise find on Fox News, Chappelle‚Äôs secondhand enemy left unnamed in Lamar‚Äôs quotation. Forefathers like Bruce and Pryor reveled in infiltrating the mainstream with beliefs so progressive about sex, race, and culture as to be dangerous. Chappelle would rather retreat into his niche as an old crank, where all is expected and safe.

title: apple ends contracts hundreds workers hired to listen siri
story: At least 300 contractors in Europe sent home after ‚Äògrading‚Äô project suspendedHundreds of Apple workers across Europe who were employed to check Siri recordings for errors have lost their jobs after the company announced it was suspending the programme earlier this month.More than 300 employees have had their contracts ended in the company‚Äôs Cork facility alone, according to former employees, with more sent home from other sites across Europe.The staff had been on paid leave since 2 August, the day Apple announced its decision to suspend the programme, referred to as ‚Äúgrading‚Äù, as it conducted ‚Äúa thorough review‚Äù.The decision followed a story in the  that revealed the workers frequently heard confidential medical information and couples having sex while checking the Siri recordings.The graders, employed through contracting firms, were sent home that Friday, with many told there was no work for them due to ‚Äútechnical errors‚Äù.However, last week the contracting firms were told by Apple that the grading work would be terminated, leading to the mass job losses with little notice.Even among those employees who were concerned by the ethics of the programme, there has been anger about how the job losses have proceeded. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm relieved this information came out,‚Äù said one former contractor who asked to remain anonymous due to a still-active non-disclosure agreement, ‚Äúalthough I was involved in the work and I just lost my job. Discussions around ethics in this job was a constant between workers, but we don‚Äôt know how to bring it up.‚ÄùBut, they added, ‚ÄúApple, recruiting through vendor companies in Ireland, take absolutely no responsibility in the employment of contractors and their treatment in work. They do what they want, and when they‚Äôre done with your project or they screw up (like what just happened), they tell your vendor company to let you go, which they do ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs been coming at them for over a year. How could they not see this coming? Did they think about protecting their employees at all? Or just their reputation?‚Äù‚ÄúWe‚Äôve all been laid off after the scandal, with no protection against this. More than 300 at once just in Cork, with no redundancy, just one week‚Äôs notice.‚ÄùThe next software update to iOS, the operating system that runs iPhones, is expected in early October and was likely to be the first occasion where the company would have been able to implement a promised opt-out to the Siri grading system. The job losses suggest, instead, that Apple is not planning to resume the grading project in the immediate future.Apple did not respond to a request for comment.

title: australian who says he invented bitcoin ordered to hand over up to 5bn
story: US court orders Craig Wright to share cryptocurrency haul with the estate of American programmer David KleimanThe Australian man who claimed to have invented cryptocurrency bitcoin has been ordered to hand over half of his alleged bitcoin holdings, reported to be worth up to $5bn.The IT security consultant Craig Wright, 49, was sued by the estate of David Kleiman, a programmer who died in 2013, for a share of Wright‚Äôs bitcoin haul over the pair‚Äôs involvement in the inception of the cryptocurrency from 2009 to 2013.Kleiman‚Äôs estate alleges Wright and Kleiman were partners, and therefore his family is entitled to a share of the bitcoin that was mined by the pair in that time. Wright denies there was a partnership.A US district court in Florida on Tuesday ruled that half of the bitcoin mined and half of the intellectual property held by Wright from that time belongs to Kleiman.One issue is it is not known exactly how much bitcoin Wright holds. It has been claimed that the Kleiman estate could get anywhere between 410,000 and 500,000 bitcoin, putting the value at between A$6.1bn and A$7.4bn as of Wednesday.Wright claimed to the court that he couldn‚Äôt access the bitcoin because he doesn‚Äôt have a list of the public addresses of that bitcoin. He claimed in 2011, after seeing the cryptocurrency had begun to be associated with drug dealers and human traffickers, he put the bitcoin he mined in 2009 and 2010 into an encrypted file and into a blind trust. The encrypted key was ided into multiple key slices, and the key slices were given to Kleiman who distributed them to people through the trust.Wright said this meant he could not decrypt the file until he gets access to the key from a bonded courier who will arrive in January 2020 ‚Äì a claim Wright has made before in claiming to be Satoshi Nakamoto, the pseudonymous creator of bitcoin.In the judgment, Judge Bruce Reinhart said Wright had not proved he could not comply and obtain the bitcoin. He said Wright made inconsistent statements and the whole story was ‚Äúinconceivable‚Äù that he‚Äôd had a Dr Frankenstein-like revelation when his creation ‚Äúturned to evil‚Äù.‚ÄúDuring his testimony, Dr. Wright‚Äôs demeanor did not impress me as someone who was telling the truth. When it was favorable to him, Dr. Wright appeared to have an excellent memory and a scrupulous attention to detail. Otherwise, Dr. Wright was belligerent and evasive,‚Äù Reinhart said.In 2015, Wright was investigated by the Australian Taxation Office over his involvement with bitcoin with his Sydney home raided by the Australian federal police, leading to speculation he might be Nakamoto.In 2016, Wright claimed he was Nakamoto, but experts questioned the evidence he provided. He promised to provide further proof, but backed down days later, saying he was ‚Äúsorry‚Äù and did ‚Äúnot have the courage‚Äù.Reinhart said at the start of his ruling the court ‚Äúis not required to decide, and does not decide‚Äù whether Wright is Nakamoto, and the court was not required to decide and did not decide how much bitcoin Wright controls today.

title: mix it up the mixologists guide to drinking rum
story: Still drinking gin? Update your drinking habits with tips from the experts on enjoying rum‚Äôs craft revivalWhile gin has had a dramatic rise in popularity over the past five years, bartenders have been quietly getting excited about rum. It offers huge cocktail variety, depending on the style from the unaged white variety to those aged in the tropics, it‚Äôs as complex and nuanced as any other spirit. I spoke to some top mixologists about their favourite cocktails.Jack Wallis and Chris Tanner at the VaultRum cocktails range from the super-simple to concoctions worthy of Michelin stars. Jack Wallis, operations manager at the Vault in Soho, is proud of the simplicity of their Captain‚Äôs Blood ‚Äì a twist on a daiquiri, made with rum, fresh lime, sugar syrup and bitters that‚Äôs perfect to serve at home. For something a little more complex, Chris Tanner, also of the Vault, makes a version of Planter‚Äôs Punch with orange, pineapple, lime juice, grenadine, sugar syrup and Lugger Rum. Unlike some varieties, Lugger Rum is not dominated by vanilla, aiming instead to deliver a full profile of spices, including nutmeg, orange peel and cloves.Liam Cotter of Heads, Hearts and TailsBarman Liam Cotter, of events and consultancy firm Heads, Hearts and Tails, warns not to take shortcuts in rum-based cocktails: ‚ÄúInexperienced bartenders may swap out a quality rum with an inferior one and wonder why their grog isn‚Äôt quite the same.‚Äù Cotter‚Äôs all-time favourite cocktail is a Jungle Bird not the original 1970s version, created in the Kuala Lumpur Hilton, but the reimagined New York classic, created by way of Giuseppe Gonzales (formerly of New York‚Äôs Suffolk Arms and long-standing patron of Milk &amp Honey). He reworked it to become infinitely more balanced and appealing to a refined contemporary palate. It‚Äôs part all-night-fun negroni, part complex bitter daiquiri. He thinks this would be great with Lugger Rum.He also has a soft spot for something more straightforward: ‚ÄúThere is something lovely about a simple rum and coke.‚ÄùMia Johansson at SwiftLondon bar Swift is known for its elegant and inventive cocktails, and one of managing partner Mia Johansson‚Äôs favourites is a Praline Flip. First, they make their own hazelnut orgeat ‚Äì by heating the nuts in water, cooling and re-blending them ‚Äì then combine with Angostura bitters, egg, Guinness and spiced rum. Their second cocktail is a little less complicated, but still one I wouldn‚Äôt try at home. It‚Äôs an espresso martini using Mr Black cold-brew coffee liqueur, coffee, vodka, rich demerara sugar and spiced rum.Thom Solberg at Black RockBlack Rock‚Äôs bar manager Thom Solberg loves a Mai Tai. Although this award-winning Shoreditch bar primarily focuses on whisky, it also works with rum. Solberg‚Äôs take on his retro favourite uses three rums ‚Äì Jamaican, Lugger spiced and over-proof ‚Äì along with triple sec and lime juice. All it needs is shaking up, pouring over ice and a garnish of orange and mint. He says spiced rum goes well with anything apple-y, and that a particular favourite rum modifier is pomegranate molasses. He incorporates this mix into a rum punch alongside dry cider, lime, allspice dram and a little vanilla syrup, garnished with cinnamon, nutmeg and apple slices.Kurt Maitland, cocktail authorKurt Maitland, author of Drink, can recommend something simple and something more showy. A Devil‚Äôs Kiss won‚Äôt tax you: shake up equal parts coffee liqueur, Grand Marnier and Lugger Rum with ice and strain into small glasses.The Kama‚Äôaina is a completely different kettle of fish, however. It starts with ginger syrup, almond paste and pimento liqueur, stirred to create a #9. Next add Rhum agricole, Lugger Rum, guava nectar, real cream of coconut, and fresh lime then shake with crushed ice and strain into a tiki glass, adding Angostura bitters and an orange blossom garnish at the end. Maitland describes a Devil‚Äôs Kiss as like an aperitif at home before the main drama of a complicated Kama‚Äôaina in a specialist bar. The former can easily be made in quantity for parties and the spiced rum balances beautifully with the bitter coffee and sweet Grand Marnier.Featuring fruit, spice and a genuinely fiery twist ‚Äì careful with those matchesLugger rum 50mlStrawberry and lime syrup 20ml*Angostura bitters, 2 dashesWest country cider 30mlSprig of rosemarySpiced powder**MatchesStrawSugar 50gStrawberries x10Peeled lime skins (x2 whole limes)Juice of 1 whole limeIn a bowl, muddle all ingredients and leave for 10-30 minutes in fridge, then strain through a sieve.Mix equal parts of icing sugar, cinnamon powder and nutmeg powder.Lugger Rum is a Caribbean rum aged in Devon, featuring sophisticated notes of orange peel, nutmeg, cloves and vanilla. Pick up a bottle at Waitrose today

title: spirit of the high seas the craft rum from devon making waves
story: When is a winery not a winery? When it makes spiced rum too. Find out what inspired Lyme Bay Winery to take the plunge with this dark and stormy spiritThere can be little doubt about it: Britain likes a drink. Considered by some as the core of the ‚Äúdrinksphere‚Äù, it‚Äôs home to pioneers in everything from cider to gin, but rum has barely registered on the radar. Unless you‚Äôre James Lambert, managing director of Lyme Bay Winery, that is.‚ÄúWe wanted to make a spiced rum, but not as we know it,‚Äù says Lambert, whose winery is set just a few miles from the sandy Devon coastline. The location is intricately entwined with the creation of their signature dark spirit, whose full name ‚Äì Jack Ratt‚Äôs Lugger Spiced Rum ‚Äì comes from infamous smuggler Jack Rattenbury.‚ÄúReading Jack‚Äôs book, Memoirs of a Smuggler, it just spoke to us, as it‚Äôs what we‚Äôre all about. There‚Äôs cheekiness, innovation and that sense of trying to be a little bit roguish ‚Äì we just felt his character suited so well what we were trying to do with the rum,‚Äù says Lambert. In true Rattenbury form, the winery is not afraid to venture into the unknown. ‚ÄúWe have a bit of an obsession with all things ‚Äòoff the beaten path‚Äô, says sales manager Sara Walters, who has worked at Lyme Bay for 10 years. ‚ÄúThe fact that there was no one in Devon making a spiced rum made for an irresistible challenge, particularly given our rich smuggling history.‚ÄùTaking inspiration from these tales, Lyme Bay embarked on its own voyage of discovery. It created a bottle design to convey the spirit of Jack Rattenbury ‚Äì a black label to match his black-painted boat, and rakish typography ‚Äì all the while showcasing the winery‚Äôs trademark elegance.Upon arriving in Devon, this exotic import is aged in a solera system, where it matures alongside older versions, aged up to six years. After years spent in charred-oak bourbon barrels from Tennessee, the rum is ready to provide the base character for Lugger Rum, bringing with it hints of caramel and molasses to give a complex and superior taste.The second spirit added to the blend is a premium Guyanan rum, ‚Äúfrom the homeland of demerara sugar,‚Äù says Lambert. But if the mention of sugar sets your teeth on edge, don‚Äôt worry: this rum offers a soothing kiss of natural sweetness without having to add excessive amounts of sugar.Spices complete the symphony. Nutmeg, stem and ground stem ginger, cinnamon, orange peel, clove and vanilla are introduced to create an inviting yet complex flavour combination. ‚ÄúThe intention was always to make a high-quality spirit,‚Äù says Lambert. ‚ÄúMany commercial spiced rums have an overpowering vanilla essence, but it was important to us to follow a more craft approach.‚Äù For Lugger Rum, they mellowed out the vanilla tones to bring forward the natural flavours of both rums, re-enforcing them with a distinct array of spices.That‚Äôs all well and good, but one imagines that the rum‚Äôs namesake would ask only one question: ‚ÄúHow do I drink it?‚Äù Although the combination of rums with the charred-oak barrels has created a dark spirit that‚Äôs flawless in cocktails or with simple mixers, I like nothing more than three large ice cubes and a nice splash on the rocks. Sourced from afar, yet aged on our doorstep ‚Äì and sitting at a refreshingly mid-tier price point ‚Äì Lugger Rum is ideal for those who want something a little special in their glass.Lugger Rum is a Caribbean rum aged in Devon, featuring sophisticated notes of orange peel, nutmeg, cloves and vanilla. Pick up a bottle at Waitrose today

title: the secret to a truly british rum a multicultural palate
story: The rich history of smugglers, exotic spices and spirits comes together in Lyme Bay Winery‚Äôs Lugger Rum, a smooth blend that‚Äôs aged on these shoresRecent television has been peppered with irresistible references to stormy nights on England‚Äôs shores, in which roguish smugglers in loose white shirts and faded leather boots pull small boats up the beach under cover of darkness. These tales of infamous men ‚Äì whose names have endured for centuries ‚Äì bring to mind the smell of woodsmoke and sea salt, and warming brown spirits sipped from battered tin mugs.And so to Lyme Bay on the unspoilt Jurassic Coast of England‚Äôs south-west, where the fossilised remains of ichthyosaurs and plesiosaurs lay waiting to be discovered under the sand and shingle. For more than 100 years smugglers in this area, such as the notorious Jack Rattenbury, would paint their rickety little ‚Äúlugger‚Äù boats black and pack them full of contraband to sell to the highest bidder.Fast forward to today, and these romantic scenes have given way to a vibrant, brilliant mix of influences. Nowhere is this blend of cultures more evident than in the food and drink we have on offer across the UK. Whether it‚Äôs Turkish meze or Korean fried chicken, chances are you‚Äôll be able to find it here. In terms of food and flavours, Britain‚Äôs multiculturalism has always been a string in our bow, and for Lugger Rum ‚Äì which is made in Devon‚Äôs Lyme Bay Winery ‚Äì this international twist is essential to a modern-day rum.Lugger Rum seamlessly blends complex flavours and spices to create a rounded, subtly complex, yet richly flavoured sipping spirit. Here‚Äôs how:The Caribbean connectionTake your windswept Devon coastline and add Trinidadian and Guyanese rum, aged in charred Tennessee barrels to add smoky, vanilla notes. The resulting spirit pulls back on the sweetness thanks to the unique style of these aged rums, unlike many of the commercial, more confected varieties.Spice it upCloves were lauded by Chaucer and Shakespeare for the unique flavour they imparted to ales and pies, and Elizabethan royalty would use them in pomanders to mask unsavoury bodily aromas. During the spice wars of the 17th century ships went to great lengths to bring these spices to our shores.Nutmeg, highly sought after for its curative and mildly hallucinogenic properties, as well as its culinary ones, used to be worth more than livestock per kilogram. Britain couldn‚Äôt get enough of this exotic flavour, and using it became a sign of wealth. Now they‚Äôre two of the spices found in Lugger Rum.The Mediterranean twistLugger‚Äôs flamboyant, citrus peel kick on the finish harks back to Plantagenet times, when expensive deliveries of oranges from the Mediterranean would be requested by Edward I‚Äôs Spanish wife, Eleanor of Castile, to remind her of home. Their beguiling scent permeated London‚Äôs theatre scene during Restoration England, when oranges were sold to theatregoers by wenches such as the infamous Nell Gwyn, who became Charles II‚Äôs mistress.Lugger Rum is the result of centuries of British history and the inquisitive, innovative minds at Lyme Bay Winery. Here is a team who have been helping lead the surge in quality and discovery of English wines, and are now turning their hand to fine spirits. Their rum is a nod to all the delicious things that made the British food and drink scene what it is today, as well as the notorious smugglers who managed to supply more illegal brandy and rum to the West Country than was ever legally imported into the capital. The finish on Lugger Rum is sure to be a little smoother, however, than the contraband hooch dragged up the beach from those little lugger boats.Lugger Rum is a Caribbean rum aged in Devon, featuring sophisticated notes of orange peel, nutmeg, cloves and vanilla. Pick up a bottle at Waitrose today

title: the great british bake off review sweet relief in these trying times
story: From a caramel schnauzer to a blood-spattered treasure chest, here‚Äôs another scrumptious series to save us from a sugar-free life. But have we been blessed with the new Nadiya? On your marks, get set ‚Ä¶ GET HAPPY! The Great British Bake Off ‚Äì the show that brought the nation together at the exact same time everything else fell in the bin like a sabotaged baked alaska ‚Äì is 10 years old. To celebrate, we get ‚Ä¶ another scrumptious series of The Great British Bake Off (Channel 4). No surprises hidden like currants in a fruit cake. No crimes or misdemeanours (not yet anyway). No boat-rocking channel switches. Just some decent folk getting in a tizzy over the height of their genoise in a Berkshire tent.Let‚Äôs face it, reviewing Bake Off is now about as necessary as scoring your nan‚Äôs scones. Of course they‚Äôre going to be just right, you ungrateful wretch. Nevertheless, like those scones, Bake Off commands attention, praise, respect. And we show this recognition not by making ‚Äòmmmm‚Äô noises and saying ‚Äòyour best yet, nan‚Äô but via the cooking up of vast amounts of column inches, manufactured scandals, and thinkpieces on what it really means when Paul Hollywood describes Michelle‚Äôs Fairy House showstopper as ‚Äúfaultless‚Äù yet doesn‚Äôt give her the handshake. Is it unconscious bias? Because it‚Äôs the first episode and he doesn‚Äôt want to peak too soon? Or has the handshake been overused to the point of redundancy and will now only be rolled out in the event of another bread lion?We will never know, but I‚Äôm racing ahead when what we‚Äôre after is a low-and-slow bake. So to the opening tableau a riff on The Wizard of Oz. Noel Fielding, droll, kind, cheeky-faced, is Dorothy. Sandy Toksvig is the scarecrow with no brain (Noel: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the QI gig gone!‚Äù). Prue Leith ‚Äì she of the showstopper necklaces and compassionate judging ‚Äì is the lion. And Hollywood is the tin man. No heart. ‚ÄúIs it weird that I fancy you now?‚Äù Toksvig asks Fielding as they wander across the lawn and we wait for the theme, the aural equivalent of stepping into a warm bath, to kick in. ‚ÄúSo do I,‚Äù mutters Hollywood. Hil. Ar. I. Ous.It‚Äôs cake week, and the signature challenge is a fruit cake, which is all about batter consistency. Too thin and the fruit drops to the bottom, too thick and ‚Ä¶ whatevs. What we‚Äôre really interested in is the texture of the contestants. Will we be blessed with a Nadiya or Rahul? Who‚Äôs going to be the anal Brendan-y one? (Henry, without a doubt: just look at his royal iced house). The posh one who induces automatic fond eye-rolls whenever they mention using pullet eggs from their own chickens? (A toss-up between vet Rosie and geography teacher Alice). The clumsy one? (Michael: he keeps cutting himself but still makes a treasure chest cake with about three fingers.) As all Bake Off fans know, the ideal contestant will be the perfect cake mix of wit, compassion, baking flair, self-deprecation, team spirit, and comedy stress responses. It‚Äôs too early to say, but I‚Äôm keeping an eye on Steph and Michelle.Much has been made of how young the group is this year, and it‚Äôs true that seven out of 13 are in their 20s. Jamie, 20, is easily the silliest. One of those inexplicable people who looks like he‚Äôs having the best time even while failing to add eggs to his caramel schnauzer. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like mixing concrete,‚Äù he grins. Special mention, also, to Helena, who ‚Äúlives like every day is Halloween‚Äù and makes the droopiest bat wings ever crafted out of sugar. ‚ÄúFrom one goth to another I know you‚Äôll be fine,‚Äù Fielding reassures her. God love him, and all goths who bake. Her genoise is so rubbery, she says, that if it fell on the floor it would bounce right back. Tragically, this doesn‚Äôt happen.But her showstopper leads to the episode‚Äôs best moment. Based on the fairy garden Helena imagined as a child, she explains that she now has an actual fairy garden at home. Hollywood looks a bit smirky. Turns out he thought she said furry garden. Oooooh, naughty! ‚ÄúOh Paul,‚Äù says Helena, slightly hysterical. ‚ÄúI know what you‚Äôre thinking.‚Äù Cue a query about how big her furry garden is, at which point I started to miss Mary Berry, because her confused-amused face would have been priceless.No matter. Bake Off remains a constant in this otherwise sugar-free life. A place where catastrophe is a dropped cake that can always be squashed back together. Welcome home, nan.

title: prince andrew virginia giuffre epstein accuser
story: Royal has previously denied Virginia Giuffre‚Äôs accusation that she was forced to have sex with himAn accuser of the financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein on Tuesday addressed her accusation that she was coerced into sex with Prince Andrew, saying the royal ‚Äúknows what he‚Äôs done‚Äù.Virginia Giuffre had already alleged in 2011 testimony that Andrew ‚Äúknows the truth‚Äù about Epstein‚Äôs abuse of underage girls and said he should be made to testify. In a December 2014 court filing she alleged that she was made to have sex with Andrew and other friends of Epstein.The prince has always vehemently denied the allegations. In 2015 a court decided that the allegations made by Giuffre about the prince were ‚Äúimmaterial and impertinent‚Äù and ordered them to be struck out of a claim against Epstein.On Tuesday, Giuffre, who now lives in Queensland with her Australian husband, spoke to reporters outside federal court in Manhattan. She was one of nearly two dozen women who spoke about alleged sexual abuse by Epstein during a unique court proceeding scheduled after the financier‚Äôs death in prison on 10 August, which was ruled a suicide.Epstein‚Äôs death at 66 brought an end to his criminal case but the judge gave accusers the opportunity to speak publicly.‚ÄúHe knows what he‚Äôs done and he can attest to that,‚Äù Giuffre said about Prince Andrew, a video of the press conference showed. ‚ÄúHe knows exactly what he‚Äôs done, and I hope he comes clean about it.‚ÄùBrad Edwards, a lawyer representing a number of Epstein accusers, said that ‚Äúwith respect to Prince Andrew or anyone else who made statements, gratuitous statements, if anyone wants to come over here and talk with us, and answer real questions that the victims have, and that we have on their behalf, we welcome that invitation.‚ÄúI personally extended that invitation to Prince Andrew multiple times. Any time, we are ready, and we have a lot of questions for him.‚ÄùAndrew said in a statement last Saturday that he made Epstein‚Äôs acquaintance in 1999 and saw him once or twice each year. The prince also said he stayed at several of Epstein‚Äôs homes.The prince also said: ‚ÄúHis suicide has left many unanswered questions and I acknowledge and sympathize with everyone who has been affected and wants some form of closure.‚ÄúThis is a difficult time for everyone involved and I am at a loss to be able to understand or explain Mr Epstein‚Äôs lifestyle. I deplore the exploitation of any human being and would not condone, participate in, or encourage any such behaviour.‚Äù

title: coalition talks resume in effort to avert snap elections in italy
story: M5S and Democratic party in last-ditch attempt to form new coalition governmentTalks between Italy‚Äôs anti-establishment Five Star Movement (M5S) and the centre-left Democratic party (PD) have resumed in a last-ditch attempt to form a new government.The longstanding rivals are under pressure to present a convincing pact to the president, Sergio Mattarella, on Wednesday.Discussions have been hampered because of clashes over who would lead the coalition and who would hold ministry positions. The PD succumbed to demands from M5S for Giuseppe Conte, who last week ended the fraught alliance between the party and the far-right League, to be reinstated as prime minister. The PD has insisted that the M5S leader, Luigi Di Maio, steps down as deputy prime minister in return.To complicate matters, M5S said it would ask members to vote on any deal agreed with the PD on Rousseau, the online network it often uses to make policy decisions. The vote would only takes place if Mattarella gives the parties a mandate to form a government.The chaos was prompted by the deputy PM and interior minister, Matteo Salvini, who dramatically withdrew the League from its coalition government with M5S this month as he sought to exploit his high popularity to force snap elections in an effort to become the next prime minister.Di Maio and Nicola Zingaretti, the PD leader, have been under pressure to strike a deal in an attempt to avert elections that could create western Europe‚Äôs first fully far-right government, despite their personal reservations and resistance from factions within their parties.Mattarella, who has the power to dissolve parliament and call new elections, will hold consultations with leaders from Italy‚Äôs main parties ‚Äì the PD, Forza Italia, the League and M5S ‚Äì from 4pm (CET). He said last week that unless a strong new parliamentary majority could be formed, he would call snap elections.Conte, a 55-year-old lawyer, has accumulated many fans since his blistering attack on Salvini in the Senate last week, not least Donald Trump, who gave his endorsement on Twitter.‚ÄúStarting to look good for the highly respected prime minister of the Italian Republic, Giuseppe Conte,‚Äù Trump tweeted. ‚ÄúRepresented Italy powerfully at the G7. Loves his country greatly and works well with the USA. A very talented man who will hopefully remain prime minister!‚ÄùConte met Trump in the US last year, and the pair were reunited at the G7 summit in Biarritz.

title: russia pushing unsuitable nuclear power in africa critics claim
story: Moscow aiming to win influence by wooing African states with nuclear energyRussia is attempting to gain influence in Africa and earn billions of pounds by selling developing nations nuclear technology that critics say is unsuitable and unlikely to benefit the continent‚Äôs poorest people.Representatives of Rosatom, the Russian state corporation responsible for both the military and civil use of nuclear energy, have approached the leaders of dozens of African countries in the past two years.The company, which is building a $29bn reactor for Egypt, has concluded agreements with Uganda, Rwanda, Ghana, South Africa and others. Winners of an Africa-wide competition were rewarded with an ‚Äúeducational‚Äù trip to Russia that included visits to a nuclear power plant and the ‚Äúscience city‚Äù of Obninsk. Rosatom is among international groups that are exporting light-water technology, which is generally considered among the safest, and is building a $13bn light-water reactor in Bangladesh. But such reactors typically generate more than 1,000 megawatts and very few countries in sub-Saharan Africa have the capacity to distribute that amount of power.Nuclear power‚Äôs supporters argue that the lengthy construction times of nuclear reactors allow poorer countries to build up their infrastructure. But N√©vine Schepers, a nuclear expert at the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London, said light-water technology was not suited to many African countries.‚ÄúIn terms of economic sense smaller countries that have a long way to go to develop their grids would be better off aiming for something like smaller modular reactors,‚Äù she said.Technology for cheaper reactors that would produce about 300MW is being developed in Russia, China and the US.Another concern is that the expensive projects favoured by Rosatom would not benefit Africa‚Äôs poorest people. In most countries energy is generated in large, centralised plants and distributed over a national grid ‚Äì a model that would be reinforced in Africa by nuclear power.‚ÄúAccess to energy is a basic human right and necessary for a dignified life. The majority of those denied this right live in Africa,‚Äù said Friends of the Earth. ‚ÄúHowever, the expansion of profit-driven nuclear energy in Africa would only exacerbate the problem.‚ÄùThe environmental NGO said the answer to Africa‚Äôs energy needs lay in ‚Äúefficient technology that meets the daily needs of people, in the hands of communities and municipalities, and controlled democratically‚Äù.
