title: one of the britains tiniest babies start school september somerset
story: Miya,  weeks premature, was given just a  per cent chance of survival and was kept in an incubator for the first  days of her le.Doctors were unsureshe would reach her first birthday but the tough little girl is now due to start her first day at primary school on September .Miya spent four months in hospital before she was allowed home with parents Shannon Baker,  and Luke Woodgate, .Mum Shannon, who gave birth at  weeks, told The Sun: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a little bit nervous because she is still so tiny. She went to pre-school for two years and that was alright but this is a bigger step.‚ÄúShe is so excited to get to school, because she is excited it makes me feel so much better. She‚Äôs always asking me to put her school unorm on and I‚Äôve had to hide her school shoes because she keeps putting them on and running into the garden.‚ÄúIn the early days we didn‚Äôt even think we would make it to her st birthday let alone her fth. It‚Äôs incredible.‚ÄúWe held her back for a year because of her medical needs and actually it‚Äôs done her a world of good.‚ÄúI went to her preschool graduation and it was amazing, I‚Äôm so proud of her and everything she has achieved. She is so strong, nothing bothers her she just takes everything her stride.‚ÄùMiya, now four, is thrilled for her first day at Rockwell Green Primary School on  September, where she will be joined by friends from the local preschool.Miya told The Sun: ‚ÄúI am so excited to start my new school and to see all my friends from pre-school. I‚Äôm a big girl now which means I get to to wear my unorm.‚ÄùShe is waiting to have a gastronomy implant and still struggles to gain weight.At .kg she weighs around kg ess than the average girl of her age, but mum Shannon said her little angel is perfect.Miya was born on August ,  weighing just under lb lb oz.Most babies born between  and  weeks weigh somewhere between  pounds,  ouncesand  pounds,  ounces .Shannon said: ‚ÄúFrom about  weeks into my pregnancy doctors noticed that she wasn‚Äôt growing properly and that my placenta was not working as it should be.‚ÄúI had a cesarean at  weeks and it was horrible, it was such a shock you don‚Äôt think anything that small could survive. She was in Bristol hospital for seven weeks, they gave me and my partner Luke a room next door to her incubator so we could go in and see her whenever we wanted.‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt come out of the incubator and was ventilated for the first  days of her le, the nurses told me she had a  per cent chance of survival. We didn‚Äôt knowshe was going to make it or not. We all just took it one day at a time.‚ÄúShe was wrapped up in a little plastic bag to keep her warm and there were wires and tubes attached to monitors everywhere. It was crazy.‚ÄúIt was so frightening, I remember saying to the doctors I don‚Äôt want to hold her. I was so scared of accidentally hurting her.‚ÄúWe were able to put our hands in the incubator the day after she was born. We were not allowed to stroke her but could put a finger on her hand or on her foot.‚ÄúI first held her when she was three weeks old and then at four weeks Luke held her for the first time.‚ÄúEvery day you could see how she was getting better and better and growing. I loved going in to see her every day to see how dferent she would look.‚ÄùAfter she was born on  August , Miya was finally allowed home to Wellington, Somerset, just in time for Christmas on  December.But on Boxing Day the baby girl stopped breathing and spent a further two weeks in Bristol children‚Äôs hospital.Slowly she began getting better but regularly used oxygen until she was two.Shannon added: ‚ÄúShe was then transferred to Taunton hospital where she was for nine weeks.‚ÄúHer due date was the rd December and she eventually came home for the first time on  December.‚ÄúShe was in hospital for  weeks in total. The doctors and nurses had her on oxygen the whole time as well as a feeding tube down her nose.‚ÄúJust eight days after she came home she stopped breathing and we had to rush her to Bristol children‚Äôs hospital. She was then back in hospital for another two weeks.‚ÄúMiya had to use oxygen at home in her day-to-day le until she was two. She was in and out of hospital all the time as they tried to wean her body off the oxygen.‚ÄúIt was so hard for all of us. We were really lucky that we had so much support from both our families, the whole time we were in hospital we had visitors every day.‚ÄúThe entire experience was just surreal, we just used to think ‚Äòhow is this happening ‚Äô. But we were always so glad to see her growing, she just did so well.‚ÄúShe does not think she is any dferent, Miya is determined that nothing will get the better of her.‚Äù

title: indonesia jakarta capital city borneo
story: The decision comes as the current capital, which is home to more than million people, is sinking into the ground as nearly half of the city already sits below sea level.President Joko Widodo said three years of intense study saw officials identy the future capital which sits on the eastern side of the island as the ideal location.The island is the third largest in the world and is at the centre of the archipelago nation, with the move expected to take up to  years and cost ¬£.billion.The site of the new capital, ,miles northeast of Jakarta, is one of the regions least prone to the natural disasters that regularly hit the archipelago of , islands.Most of the move will be funded by cooperation between the government and businesses and by direct investment by state-run firms.Around  per cent will come from the governments budget.The new city will sit in between two undeveloped regions of Kutai Kertanegara and Penajam Paser Utara.In a televised speech, the Indonesian president said: The location is very strategic - its in the centre of Indonesia and close to urban areas.The burden Jakarta is holding right now is too heavy as the centre of governance, business, finance, trade and services.He also added the city already has a relatively complete infrastructure with it being near the cities of Balikpapan and Samarinda.The new city is said to be atminimal risk of natural disasters.In a televised speech, Widodo said the burden on Jakarta had become too much, with it being home to the government, the countrys largest seaport and airport, and the centre for finance, trade and business.The decision to relocate the countrys capital city was because the government wants to spread the countrys wealth and population.Currently,  per cent of the countrys  million population live on Java, making it the most populated area in Indonesia.Widodo added: We couldnt continue to allow the burden on Jakarta and Java island to increase in terms of population density.Economic disparities between Java and where would also increase.Officials say they want the new capital to be ‚Äúa smart city in the forest‚Äù and have set aside , acres of government land.Jakarta is sinking due to rising sea levels and the over-extraction of groundwater.More than  per cent of Jakartas resident use groundwater.This consequently makes floods worse as floodwater is unable to flow into the ocean.The city is sinking by an average of in a year and almost half the city now sits below sea level.Greenpeace senior forest campaigner Jasmine Puteri said: ‚ÄúThe move will have an environmental impact.‚ÄúJakarta has suffered so many failures from pollution, water crisis, and flooding. We don‚Äôt want these problems in the new capital.‚Äù

title: low paid brits up property ladder
story: Communites Secretary Robert Jenrick plans to rip up existing rules around ‚Äòshared ownership‚Äô housing to make it far easier for people to own a greater chunk of their new home.Under existing rules, Brits have to a buy a minimum  per cent of a shared ownership property, rent the rest and then increase their equity in tranches of  per cent a time.Mr Jenrick wants to change this to allow Brits to move up at  per cent a time ‚Äì so it‚Äôs more affordable and encourages them to take the plunge in the first place.It means Brits could up their equity for as little as ¬£, depending on the value of the property.Mr Jenrick told The Sun: ‚ÄúMost people want to own their home. But for millions the dream seems out of reach.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my mission to change that and our new shared ownership scheme is the first big step.‚ÄúThis will help tens of people buy their home in small, affordable chunks.‚ÄùHe added the new ‚ÄòStaircase Rule‚Äô should come into force early next year.Currently some , people are in shared ownership accommodation ‚Äìeither with housing associations or private developments.It‚Äôs the latest move by the Tories to try and win back  to  year-old voters who they are convinced left them in  because of the chronic shortage of available homes.Entering Downing Street, Boris Johnson said Britain suffered from ‚Äúone of the worst housing crises in the democratic world‚Äù.And soaring house prices now average almost  times average earnings.¬†Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris has been a revelation since he took over brexit but signing away powers to get it over the line could cost him his job
story: Delivering on the referendum ought to make Nigel Farage‚Äôs Brexit Party redundant and ensure a Tory election win. But binning the toxic Irish backstop might not be enough eventhe EU agrees.There is plenty in Theresa May‚Äôs deal to bind our hands even after we have left.The Sun would still prefer a deal. But Farage will capitalise, understandably so,Boris signs away any sovereign powers in haste to get Brexit over the line. That could yet cost him power.This may all be moot. We do not see Brussels nor the Irish PM scrapping the backstop they have treated as holy writ.But when his own allies like Iain Duncan Smith warn him not to be satisfied solely with that, Boris must listen.WHO‚ÄôS up for more years of bitter Brexit ision and political paralysis Not Leavers, who were sick of it long ago and are furious their vote hasn‚Äôt been fulfilled. Not the EU, either. Its leaders, Boris says, just want it done now too.But others ARE bent on prolonging the agony indefinitely. What are Labour, the Lib-Dems, the SNP, the Greens and the Exact Change brigade all smoking After all that‚Äôs happened, how can they still believe our best bet is to nully the referendum and hold a second, skewed to ensure a Remain verdict  Nothing is more certain to wreck Britain.Yet befuddled Corbyn, led by his scheming sidekick Keir Starmer, has signed Labour up to this lunacy and abandoned his Leave voters entirely.Riding high two years ago, Corbyn is now reduced to feebly branding No Deal a ‚Äúbankers‚Äô Brexit‚Äù or a ‚ÄúTrump-deal Brexit‚Äù, apparently unaware bankers funded Remain and that no Trump deal would ever involve the NHS.It is dog-whistle drivel for deranged anti-American Trots and the #FBPE losers whining about Brexit on Twitter.These diehard Remainers, trapped in their bubble, are a truly pitul bunch.THE shake-up of shared ownership rules for hard-up home buyers is a smart idea as far as it goes.But they still have to find or borrow  per cent upfront. Why not slash that to ten, or even one  And it still smacks of tinkering when the solution to turning millennials into home owners is both more obvious and far more radical:A bonfire of archaic planning rules and a massive increase in the total of affordable homes built each year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remainers porkie pies trade deals
story: By drawing his excited opponents into making accusations about yet more of Boris‚Äôs ‚Äúporky pies‚Äù, he has skilfully drawn attention to the point he really wanted to make ‚Äî that there are huge global opportunities for British food exportersonly we are prepared to make concessions in opening up our own food markets to the world.In fact,we start exporting pork pies to the Far East we will only be ing to what we were doing more than  years ago.In , Melton Mowbray bakers Evans  Hill reported they had received a large order of pork pies from Borneo ‚Äî which is even further from Britain than Thailand.If we could do it then, without modern refrigeration, we can surely do it now. As Boris was arguing, the real barriers to trade are not practical ones ‚Äî they are taxes and regulations.Remainers continually lecture us on the benefits of free trade with the EU ‚Äî and they are right to do so. Hardly anyone really wants to leave without a deal. If we do have to take that route it will surely not be long before discussions on a free trade deal recommence.Yet those same Remainers bizarrely retreat in horror when anyone suggests we do a free trade deal with the US. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôll have to eat chlorinated chicken,‚Äù they complain, as well as GM ‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù food.As shown by their failure yesterday to agree on a common course of action to thwart Brexit, Remainers are bumbling along in a state of confusion.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   MB-COMP-JANEMOORE.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentJANE MOORE Coleen will forgive silly fool Wayne again after club girl lt photograph " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-e.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" THE SUN SAYS Signing away powers to get Brexit over the line could cost Boris his job " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Remainers have no right to complain now that the tables have turned " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   TM-comp-Tony-Parson-.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTONY PARSONS Be the Duchess of Woke or jet-setter, Meghan, but you cant be both " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   TM-comp-Epstein.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Andrew must front up about Epstein relationship ‚Äî The Firms rep is at stake But nothing demonstrates this better than their contradictory approach to free trade. They seem to think it a great benefit to the country when conducted with the EU, but a route to national disastercarried out with any other country.The charge that anyone will be forced to eat chlorinated chicken or GM foods is, needless to say, a far bigger porky pie than anything Boris has said on the subject.It is far from certain that a Johnson Government, when engaged in trade talks with the US, will make the concessions allowing these products into UK markets, butit does, then UK shoppers will continue to have a choice.They will still be able to buy chicken produced in Britain or the EU, or they will be able to choose to eat American chicken.I certainly have no fear of eating chicken which has been washed in chlorine. The idea that it is ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù has been thoroughly debunked. Each of us ingests far more chlorine through drinking water than we ever would do through eating US-produced chicken.As for GM foods, we already eat them, vegans especially. The EU allows imports of GM soyafor simple practical reasons. Most of it is grown in the Americas and too many growers there use GM seed for non-GM soya to be sold as a separate product.If we want free trade we are not going to achieve it just by persuading other countries to open their markets to us. No, we will have to make the concession of opening our markets to them too. But there is no reason to be frightened.True, there are some products which need to be banned from sale for genuine health and safety reasons. But most of the EU‚Äôs food product standards are really just a form of protectionism in disguise, dreamed up to block competition for European farmers.If we do post-Brexit trade deals with the US and other countries ‚Äî and in the process do away with the EU‚Äôs protectionist tarfs and product standards ‚Äî some UK producers would suffer.But others would prosper as they enjoyed access to new export markets. Overall, as is almost always the case when trade barriers are taken down, we would benefit. Strong industries would grow and consumers would enjoy greater choice and lower prices.Boris‚Äôs vision of a global British pork pie industry shows the dference between him and the political opponents who spent much of yesterday scheming over how to stop him taking Britain out of the EU.While his glass is half full, theirs is half empty.They are driven by a pathological fear of le outside the EU.It is not that they have any great enthusiasm for the EU. After all, I haven‚Äôt heard one of them make a convincing case why the EU is an institution to be admired. It is just that they have a lack of ambition for Britain and so cling to EU membership.After meeting for several hours yesterday, what did the likes of Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer and Jo Swinson come up with That they want to extend Article  yet further, to prolong yet again the endless drt which unsettled markets and put off investment.Fortunately, the public seems to have come to a very dferent conclusion. It just wants Brexit to be over and done with.Thanks to the Remain lobby‚Äôs endless infighting and self-indulgent argument over who it would like as a caretaker Prime Minister, that is exactly what is overwhelmingly likely to happen on October .¬†Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is the the queens privy council
story: Read on to find out everything we know about the Privy Council...Her Majestys Most Honourable Privy Council is a formal body of advisers who serve the sovereign of the UK, in the current case - the Queen.It is made up of a group of senior politicians who are were or are members ofthe House of Commons or the House of Lords.The role of the privy council is to advise the Queen on the exercises of Royal Prerogative, which is essentially the Queens overall authority afforded to her by her royal status.The council has the power to Enact acts of Parliament, this is done through Orders of Council.They can also advise the sovereign on the issuing of Royal Charters, which are used to grant special status to incorporated bodies, and city or borough status to local authorities.However, the majority of the Privy Councils have been taken over by the Cabinet.Only the Queen can prorogue parliament, as only a monarch can announce the proroguing of Parliament - so the government must ask the Queen permission to do so.It is looking likely that the Queen will accept the request however, as the monarchy is bound to be independent of politics.However, the Privy Council can advise the Queen to suspend Parliament.The privy council currently has a -strong membership, composed mostly of politicians and civil servants.Membership is for le, so evena politician retires, they are still a member of the Privy Council.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has declared war on Parliament by confirming he plans to suspend Parliament for a month - and hold a Queen‚Äôs Speech on October . That means MPs face a race against time to thwart the Prime Minister taking the UK out of the EU without a Brexit deal on October . Johnson says he wants an opportunity to set up new bills to ‚Äòlevel up‚Äô spending on his priorities, including the NHS, education and policing. But his plan will also dramatically cut down the amount of time MPs have to block Johnson pressing forward with a chaotic no-deal Brexit . Commons Speaker John Bercow has branded it a constitutional outrage. Activists have begun the process of legal action. And Jeremy Corbyn has written to the Queen asking for an urgent meeting, accusing the PM of a smash-and-grab on our democracy. Here‚Äôs everything you need to know about Boris Johnson ‚Äôs new plan - and what it means for Brexit.  He‚Äôs setting the date for a Queen‚Äôs Speech and State Opening of Parliament . This effectively reboots Parliament, setting off a new ‚Äòsession‚Äô and shutting down the old one. This process called proroguing usually happens every year - but it doesn‚Äôt have to, and Theresa May chose not to have a Queen‚Äôs Speech in -, so she‚Äôd have more time to push Brexit plans through. That means weaposve now had the longest gap between Queenaposs Speeches for more than  years. To trigger a Queenaposs Speech Parliament has to have a short break, which usually lasts a few days. And when MPs , the slate is clear. Any legislation that was in the process of passing through Parliament is cancelled and MPs start the new session effectively from scratch.  aposProrouguingapos means to suspend a session of Parliament without dissolving it . So ending one session and kicking off a new one with a Queenaposs Speech. Rebooting Parliament. Charles I famously prorogued Parliament and kept it from sitting for  years between  and . That‚Äôs why you may be seeing comparisons to a power-mad king. Thataposs because Parliament is expected to be prorogued on around September - - meaning it will be off for a full month. What is the Queen‚Äôs Speech   It‚Äôs theannual address given by the Monarch to MPs and peers, opening the new session of Parliament. It‚Äôs used by the Prime Minister to outline the Government‚Äôs legislative programme for the upcoming session.  That hasn‚Äôt been fully confirmed, but here‚Äôs the most likely scenario. Parliament is expected tofrom recess on Tuesday September . It‚Äôs then expected to sit until September  or , when it would break up for party conference season. Usually, Parliament wouldstraight away after the end of Conservative Party Conference, which finishes on October . What‚Äôs being suggested is that instead the Queen will end the current session of Parliament on September  or , leaving a longer gap all the way to October .  It massively slashes the amount of time MPs have to pass any kind of blocking measures through Parliament. Let‚Äôs assume the Commons sits Monday to Friday - which it doesn‚Äôt always, but let‚Äôs assume it would in a crunch. If the original timeline were to take place, there would be a maximum of eight sitting days before the conference recess. And assuming they ed the Monday after Tory conference, there would be scope for  sitting days between then and the October  deadline. That‚Äôs  days in which an anti-no-deal coalition could work on ways to block it.  ¬† Now,there‚Äôs a Queen‚Äôs Speech on October , in all likelihood Parliament would stay in recess for the week before. There are usually five full days of debate following a Queen‚Äôs Speech - and another two days of votes on the speech on October -. This would make it exceptionally dficult to schedule any further business in the Commons during that time. So that would leave just seven potential sitting days between conferences and the Brexit deadline - and just  in total. There‚Äôs also the small matter of the European Council meeting on October , which will be the PM‚Äôs last opportunity to seal a new deal with the EU. Boris Johnson this morning said there will be ‚Äúample time‚Äù to debate Brexit before and after the October  meeting.  ¬† Can it be challenged in the courts  Former Prime Minister John Major had already warned he would take High Court action to stop Boris Johnson suspending Parliament to ram through no-deal. Gina Miller, the anti-Brexit campaigner, made similar noises. Within hours of the announcement, Remainer QC Jo Maugham said he was initiating legal action to try to stop Boris Johnson.  ¬† Can MPs hold a Parliament anyway  Technically yes, but it wonapost have legal effect. It comes just a day after Jeremy Corbyn and opposition leaders agreed to table a law next week aimed at blocking a no-deal Brexit on October . More than  MPs also signed a declaration in Westminsteraposs Church House, vowing to carry on sitting in an alternative venueParliament is suspended. Moments before the Queenaposs Speech emerged, Tory Rory Stewart warned MPs would continue to run Parliament somewhere it was suspended. Labour MP Clive Lewis added: The police will have to remove us from the chamber. We will call on people to take to the streets. We will call an extraordinary session of Parliament. Can the Queen say no   She can, but she won‚Äôt. And she hasnapost. The Queen‚Äôs role in this is almost entirely ceremonial. Even her speech to Parliament is written by the Government. Constitutional experts have said The Queen would do everything possible to avoid becoming involved in any political battle the country finds itself in.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heatwave is gripping The Arctic, melting away Greenland‚Äôs ice sheet on an unprecedented scale and threatening a global rise in sea levels ‚Äì an urgent reminder of the climate crisis we are now all facing. Kids splashing each other in the sea and locals wearing t-shirts were unheard of here in August  years ago. But now, alongside teenage girls wearing skirts to school and increasing mosquitoes, it is a common occurrence for the residents of Qaanaaq, in north-west Greenland, one of the world‚Äôs most northerly cities situated  miles north of the Arctic Circle. Greenland, the world‚Äôs largest island at almost three times the size of France, is now living with extreme environmental changes which could see the Arctic Sea free of ice by no action is taken.  ¬† I travelled to Greenland, home to just , people, last week to see first hand the drastic changes to conditions and to understand why it matters to us all. Away from headlines about melting ice caps and pictures of underfed polar bears unable to stalk seals on flimsy ice forced to invade towns for food, I found a community battling to adjust. Living alongside a backdrop of eerily beautul icebergs and utterly terrying melting sea ice and retreating glaciers is having a devastating impact on species, habitats and human le. This is the frontline of climate change.  ¬† Three-quarters say they have personally experienced the impact of global warming in their daily lives, from coping with dangerous sea ice journeys to having hunting sled dogs put down for economic reasons due to shorter winters - with many unaware of the full impact. While we may shrug at the decline of traditional hunting, it is impossible to visit Greenland and not be profoundly affected by their tales of how climate change has upturned their world in just a single generation. Families have been torn apart, livelihoods threatened giving us all an insight into the scale of the battle now facing humanity. ‚ÄúIf all of Greenland‚Äôs ice were to melt, it would raise global sea levels by fett meaning cities like London, Sydney and New York underwater and the whole of Bangladesh would disappear,‚Äù says Mark Wright, director of science at WWF, who accompanied the Daily Mirror to the Arctic. ‚ÄúThis is not science fiction. This is the reality of climate change.  ¬† ‚ÄúIt is happening now ‚Äì and here in accelerated terms ‚Äì providing a crucial insight into what we will all face unless urgently tackle this now. Sea ice now forms here two months later and melts one month earlier - as temperatures rise twice as fast as the global average. This summer has seen more than  wildfires in the Arctic Circle devastating once pristine forests, turning them from precious carbon dioxide absorbing sponges into giant new emitters of greenhouse gases. The country is also experiencing record-breaking temperatures. In mid-June, along the eastern coast it was C warmer than the - average. Just as western Europe has baked in a heatwave with record temperatures at the end of July, the hot air moved as far north as Greenland with the gauge hitting C on August . The average high is around C.  Journeys around the coast which took three weeks in the s because of the sea ice now take a single day. Perched beneath the world‚Äôs second largest ice cap after Antarctica, nothing other than black moss and lichen grow here. Fourth fths of Greenland is buried under an ice sheet two miles thick, much of it three million years old. But in the blink of an eye in geological terms it has begun melting ‚Äì and much faster than climate change models predicted. Around % is affected, including higher elevations that only rarely see temperatures climb above freezing. In July alone  billion tonnes of meltwater poured into the Atlantic ‚Äì enough to raise sea levels by .mm. We take a small fishing boat out with Joseph Manumina, , who points to a glacier he used to cross in a five-metre sled pulled by  huskies in the winter.  ¬† But like thousands of others here, the fourth-generation hunter has been forced to abandon his family trade and is now a fisherman. Joseph stops his boat beside the Hiawatha glacier and points out when he was young it stretched hundreds of metres further into the fjord. ‚ÄúThe land you can now see was not visible at all a few years ago. But heavy rains came in  and changed the landscape for good,‚Äù he said. Last year, thanks to signicant melting, scientists discovered a -mile-long crater ‚Äì the first to be found under ice ‚Äì believed to be a direct result of a meteorite impact. While similar melting effects are being measured in the southern hemisphere, the Greenland sheet may be uniquely vulnerable, lying much further from the chill of the pole than Antarctica‚Äôs. Scattered across  small towns and approximately  villages, all situated on a narrow coastal strip, Greenland‚Äôs residents have often been overlooked by data science. But a first-ever national survey has examined the human impact of the climate emergency ‚Äì showing % of islanders interviewed fully accept that the climate crisis is happening. The Greenlandic Perspectives Survey was carried out by the University of Copenhagen‚Äôs Center for Social Data Science, the Kraks Fond Institute for Urban Economic Research and the University of Greenland.  ¬† Lead author Kelton Minor said: ‚ÄúThe Arctic is a bellwether for the unequal impact of global warming on social and economic systems. ‚ÄúAs countries struggle to limit future risks and overall warming to .C many Arctic and Greenlandic residents are already living in regional climates that have changed by more than this, in less than a letime. ‚ÄúTherein lies the paradox: while satellites and sensors monitor the surface of Greenland‚Äôs ice sheet, chase icebergs and scan sea ice daily, relatively little is known about what the residents of Greenland think about their changing surroundings.‚Äù July st was the biggest melt day since at least , when % of sheet experienced melt. Studies found ice melt periods like the one seen seven years ago typically occur about every  years. One occuring so quickly is an important sign how quickly the climate is changing, warn experts. ‚ÄúThis is a double edged sword, says Mark Wright, director of Science at WWF. ‚ÄúWhat we do here in the UK, they way we live our lives by burning fossil fuels, is speeding up the change. ‚ÄúAt the same time this is affecting Greenland and other Arctic countries. But what happens here will also affect what happens at home in terms of our weather patterns and security in coastal areas. ‚ÄúThis is why we have to take action and now. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have long left to cap this rapid change that we‚Äôve never seen before in human history.‚Äù The rapid melting is also opening up new shipping routes and mining opportunities for deposits of rare-earth elements used in technology previously buried under ice sheets hundreds of metres thick.  It has sparked the interest of American President Donald Trump with an attempt to buy it, while China already has a mine on the island. While it is impossible to put a price on the territory, estimates range from . trillion to .trillion depending on the mining potential - believed to be enough to meet % of the world‚Äôs demand in the next  years. Trump may have cancelled his trip to Denmark for now but his suggestion is a marker of the fact Greenland is also now at the heart of a new battle for supremacy in the Arctic, where superpower competition is heating up as fast as the ice is melting.

Make sure to have your supplies ready.The storm has already passed over Barbados, where the countryaposs Prime Minister Mia Amor Mottley said there had been no major incidents, damage or injuries, at a briefing at the National Emergency Operations Centre .Before the storm hits the US authorities have been looking to support Puerto Rico following heavy criticism over the response to the  storm.The White House said in a statement that President Donald Trump had approved an emergency declaration for Puerto Rico late on Tuesday, allowing for the Federal Emergency Management Agency to provide assistance in coordination with ongoing disaster preparedness efforts.And Puerto Rico Governor Wanda Vazquez said they are better prepared than when Hurricane Maria attacked our island.  Vazquez, who took office this month after political turmoil led to the resignation of his predecessor, said preparations for the storm were more than % complete, culminating with the opening of emergency shelters. Infrastructure ranging from electric power lines to telecommunications and banking networks were in better shape than they had been in , she added. In Puerto Rico, public schools will be closed on Wednesday and public workers have been instructed to stay home, Vazquez said. The Dominican Republic also ramped up storm preparations on Tuesday.  ¬†¬† Juan Manuel Mendez, director of the emergency operations center, said authorities have identied , buildings that can be converted into shelters, with capacity for up to , people. The UK Foreign Office has also issued a warning to holidaymakers heading to Barbados, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Dominica, Martinique and Grenada. A Foreign Office spokesperson said: Tropical Storm Dorian is forecast to affect the eastern Caribbean from Tuesday  August.You should exercise due caution and monitor local news and weather reports.

title: bard of salford john cooper clarke promises a right good night in dundee visit
story: John Cooper Clarke is ready to rock# and Dundee should be afraid, very afraid.He may be in his older years, but he is not holding back.And the man known as the punk poet has vowed to perform in his unmistakable style ‚Äì machine gun delivery studded with factory floor language.The rasping Salford accent is still there and the humour as cutting as a surgeon‚Äôs scalpel.And for the real devotees, John has teased them by telling the Tele exclusively that he has begun planning his memoirs.In typical fashion he says: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt kept a f****** diary, but I have got a good memory.‚ÄúIn fact, my memory is long and my vengeance is total.‚ÄùTo the musicians and celebs who have crossed JCC in the past, start praying now because the master could even recall the gig I saw him perform at Strathclyde University in the early s and who was playing on the same bill.For the record, it was Siouxsie and the Banshees ‚Äì and I couldn‚Äôt remember that, despite being a few years younger than the man.Back in the day, John easily recalls everyone being angry young men and women. The hate for Thatcher was pure and the depth of feeling surged through concerts and rallies.He says with a chuckle: ‚ÄúThem were the days.‚ÄúWe thought it was bad then, but everything can get worse, as we see now. It‚Äôs a case of careful what you wish for.‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get involved in politics now, like I say when didn‚Äôt anyone complain about politicians ‚ÄúCan you point me to a golden era where# everybody liked being ruled  F***ing never!‚ÄúBut there are some real creeps nowadays. But then again I expect the worst from any politician.‚ÄùSo what can fans in Dundee expect when John rolls into town for his show at the city‚Äôs Gardyne Theatre on Saturday October  Without missing a beat he fires back: ‚ÄúA right f****** good night!‚ÄúAnd they can expect more of the same#and then some. There will be a few classics and there will maybe be a few extra poems.‚ÄúThen I will add a bit of fun and I can guarantee ‚Äì solid, copper-plated guarantee ‚Äì that everybody is going to leave with a smile on their face.‚ÄùJohn has fond memories of Dundee and spoke of savouring the atmosphere of a waterfront hotel and added: ‚ÄúI love coming to Scotland and Dundee. I‚Äôve been many times and the reaction of the crowd is great.‚ÄúI was here last year and saw the VA which is fabulous. I know of DC Thomson and the Sunday Post, the Beano and the Dandy plus Oor Wullie.‚ÄúMaybe I will buy one of those sculptures.‚ÄùPosh hotels and venues seem a world away from the clubs and student venues of the s with smoke-filled rooms and plastic tumblers full of warm beer.He used to travel to the shows on public transport and chuckles at the memory.John said: ‚ÄúYeah, long time ago now, mate. Now I have a driver and I am too old for public transport.‚ÄúBut I still love doing live gigs. It‚Äôs smashing. Anywhere where there‚Äôs people is greatI‚Äôm doing my stuff.‚ÄúI am working on my book of poems right now. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄòThe Luckiest Man Alive‚Äô and I‚Äôm also working on the memoirs. vw, px"  ‚ÄúI am thinking of calling that ‚ÄòI Wanna Be Yours‚Äô after the Arctic Monkeys. I just hope to live long enough to finish it.‚ÄúBut I am not finishing up any time soon. I have never even thought about that. I am not retiring, not yet and not in the foreseeable future.‚ÄùJohn has the tour to contend with first and is also lining up some television work.And at the age of  there is definitely no holding him back. So look out for many more tours to come from the man who wants to be yours.

title: dark blues boss derbies massive but we must not forget big picture
story: James McPake would never talk down the importance of the Dundee derby ‚Äì he‚Äôs had too many extreme highs and lows in these games to do that.However, from his days wearing a dark blue shirt, the Dundee boss knows there can be even bigger achievements than beating Dundee United and that‚Äôs what he‚Äôll be telling his players this week.The obvious derby low for James came on January ,  when his career was ended as he suffered a horric knee injury as he slid in to tackle United‚Äôs John Rankin.The highs came via two goals, one in a long overdue Dee win at Dens, the other a dramatic and memorable last-gasp equaliser at Tannadice. vw, px"  For him, though, the best of his time at the heart of the defence came where.McPake said: ‚ÄúThe highlight of my time as a player here was the first season, finishing in the top six and the second year when a better team, in my opinion, finished seventh.‚ÄúIt played some real good football and Kaneand Gregthat season were unplayable. The highlight is over the period, meeting and playing with some fantastic players.‚ÄùAnd as he prepares to take them to Tannadice on Friday, that‚Äôs a message he‚Äôll be passing on to the squad he‚Äôs in charge of now.‚ÄúI think we‚Äôve said from the start nothing will be won or lost just now, regardless of what happens in the match for either team.‚ÄúThrow in Ayr United, Inverness and forgive meI‚Äôm missing others out but there will be a lot of teams challenging come March, April and into May. We want to be one of them.‚ÄùThat said, he does not hide how much he is looking forward to the biggest game of the season, so far, and, despite those mixed memories, it‚Äôs a fixture he relishes.‚ÄúI‚Äôd say the highlight in a derby was here when we beat them -, I think for the first time in  years.‚ÄúIt was a big night for our fans because we were - up, they got back into the game but we got back in front.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the goal that never gets spoken about, but it‚Äôs my favourite goal for Dundee, the header.‚ÄúI know why everyone loved the one down therebecause we were - down with  minutes to go. It‚Äôs the nature of football.‚ÄúDown there it was great because we were out the game so it felt like a win because we were - down with  minutes to go away from home.‚ÄúBut,it‚Äôs for a goal,I had to pick one of the two it was the one here.‚ÄùObviously, the injury three-and-half years ago was the low point, though, he is still able to look to the positive long-term outcome.‚ÄúI look on the positive side. If that injury hadn‚Äôt happened I wouldn‚Äôt be leading a team down there this week.‚ÄúI would have continued playing and I would have had some good times and some not so good times going through the later stages of my career.‚ÄúWas it a blessing in disguise  Well I wouldn‚Äôt like to go through that again because it was a horric time for myself and my family but it helped me get a head start in coaching.‚ÄùAs for the injury itself, he admits he knew almost immediately how severe it was.‚ÄúI‚Äôd had bad injuries before but nothing as shocking and as severe as that in terms of the reaction of people around it at the time.‚ÄúI have to say, United were fantastic. I remember Ryan McGowan and Sean Dillon in particular, they were great on the day.‚ÄúAt the time you are in shock, the pain was there and I probably knew within  minutes of being in the ambulance heading to hospital my career was over.‚Äù

title: james mcpake accepts share of blame for dundee draw with inverness caley thistle
story: Boss James McPake has accepted his share of the blame for Dundee‚Äôs below-par performance in Saturday‚Äôs goalless draw with Inverness Caley Thistle.After pushing Aberdeen all the way to extra time in the Betfred Cup six days earlier, the Dark Blues looked sluggish as they could not find a way past the Highlanders at Dens Park.While the gaffer was unhappy about that, for him, it was a case of collective responsibility that stretched beyond those on the park.‚ÄúWe‚Äôre inconsistent at the minute. title: a note of chamber music coming to crear
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe UK‚Äôs leading string orchestra, the Scottish Ensemble , has announced the first half of Scottish tour¬† # and Argyll is on the list of venues.The ensemble will perform Mendelssohn and Enescu‚Äôs stunning octets, and will be led by the outstanding Norwegian violinist Marianne Thorsen.Though written for just eight instruments, both of these sophisticated works have the drama, richness and depth of a full-blown symphony. They also make for an excellently contrasting pair.From Mendelssohn‚Äôs exuberant opening bars, we are swept through music that is complex yet captivatingly, joyously melodic throughout, while Enescu‚Äôs is moody, breathlessly dramatic and, in parts, simply volcanic.Guest directed by Marianne Thorsen, SE will explore the specic charm of seeing a small group of musicians performing live. With fewer instruments, the fabric of the music becomes more tangible, subtle shts in mood may have a new-found presence, and pieces you think you know well might offer surprising new colours when heard live. With fewer musicians on stage, it is easier to follow each inidual path and witness the beautul alchemy of eight artists creating something together.Thorsen is an acclaimed soloist and passionate chamber musician. Former leader of the Nash Ensemble, she regularly performs with Norway‚Äôs Trondheim Soloists, one of the founding ensembles of The Bridge network and festival.The first half of the tour, which is called Chamber Notes, will call at Crear Studio, Kilberry, on August , followed by a performance at Mull Theatre, Tobermory, on August  before moving on to Inverness and Dundee.Other Scottish dates, including Edinburgh and Glasgow, are programmed for February .PIC:Marianne Thorsen. no_aMarianne Thorsen

title: letters to the editor august 16 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to record my thanks to everyone who contributed to the running of the Mid Argyll Show this year.It is great for visitors to see these traditions and talent brought together and seeing young people participating in events assuring that these customs are in safe hands for the future.Thank you again to all involved in running the show.Councillor Anne HornSir,I read with some interest that a new dentist was coming to town in Lochgilphead to set up a practice, which I am sure we look forward to.The local NHS trust cannot seem to lure one to the area to work at the Mid Argyll Hospital practice, which I think is unfortunate for all concerned. We do at the moment have a dentist and fully qualied staff and are happy with their work.Rumour has it that the aforementioned dentist and staff will be taking on patients from Mid Argyll Hospital, which I presume they tend to already.But the practice is to lose its local NHS patients, so they will deal solely with patients who require dental treatment from the hospital. I think this situation leaves the NHS patients in limbo.I am sure we would rather that the current dentist and all of her staff be given a chance to voice their opinions on this matter as much and as well as the local populace.Yes, it will be brilliant to have both dentists in the town. There is the possibility that those on the local list who are currently treated well by the dental department at the hospital maybe still seen by the dentist and her staff, but I would like this to be confirmed by the local NHS trust.Brian MacDonald, CrinanSir,Hundreds of¬†people across Scotland have been helped through their exam results by a¬†local¬†group of Skills Development Scotlandcareers advisers.Based across the north of Scotland, the advisers were part of a team taking calls at the SDS Exam Results Helpline from am on results day.The helpline is a vital service, supporting young people and their families at what can be one of the most stressful times of their lives.Expert advice and guidance is available all year round, not just on results day.Our professionally qualied careers advisers are working in every state secondary school in Scotland and from our network of high street centres across the country.In schools, careers services are delivered one-to-one, in classrooms and at school events across all year groups, supporting young people to develop the skills to make informed career decisions throughout their lives. There is also support for parents and carers.At SDS centres customers can get information, advice and guidance about jobs, the local labour market, training courses and apprenticeships as well as how to prepare for interviews and help with CVs and applications.The work of SDS careers advisers in schools and centres is supported by Scotland‚Äôs careers website myworldofwork, where you can access advice  hours a day. It is packed with career information, advice and tools such as the CV builder. There is also a dedicated exam results section.Details of the local SDS centres are available at myworldofwork centres and information about events and opportunities is also available on Facebook.Pauline Graham, Project Manager for the SDS Exam Results HelplineSir,I had a great time at this year#s Islay Show. It was fantastic to speak to so many of my constituents.It was also wonderful to see many local business stalls promoting Islay#s dynamic and booming economy.The show was well attended with lots of families, both local and visitors, having a fun day out and luckily the sun was shining most of the day.A huge thanks to all the organisers and everyone  who contributed to the event.Councillor Alastair RedmanSir,I have real concerns about the deteriorating condition of some Argyll cemeteries.Constituents from Islay recently joined Councillor Alastair Redman in highlighting the poor upkeep of cemeteries in the area he represents.Councillor Redman reported that there were also problems at other cemeteries in his ward, including the cemetery at Carradale in East Kintyre.I understand that Argyll and Bute Council confirmed that they now, at last, have plans in place to address the problems at Kilnaughton.It remains disappointing, however, that things are allowed to deteriorate to the extent that the maintenance of cemeteries has become a matter of public concern.Frankly, it is very surprising that a cemetery where interments are actually still taking place has been undermined in this way and there must surely be an obligation to ensure this doesn‚Äôt happen.My experience is that communities in the Highlands and Islands pay special regard to the final resting places of fellow members of their communities and will be perplexed to discover that they appear to be uncared-for.Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands MSP

title: lets not negotiate away scotland the brand
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowIf there is an accusation that could not be thrown at Ruth Watson, founder of the Keep Scotland the Brand campaign, it is that she lacks enthusiasm.The Argyllshire Advertiser caught up with the founder of the Keep Scotland the Brand campaign at the recent Mid Argyll Show.She is a firm believer that Scotland#s iconic food and drink products should be protected from imitation where. The means for¬† protection is the European Union PGIdesignation, to promote and protect names of quality agricultural products and foodstuffs.Ruth, an experienced journalist, explained: #I became concerned about two years ago when, during Japan EU Canadatrade talks, the UK government did not submit one PGI for protection.#Across Europe, , food names were protected. It worries me greatly.#She continued: #I am also concerned about how hard it is becoming to source local food and drink. I live in rural Angus, and the carrots grown down the road from me started le just as Angus carrots, but they went away for packaging and came back as Great British carrots. Technically that is correct, butwe believe in supporting local farmers and making clear choices about food miles and quality, this is ridiculous.#She stressed: #This is not a protectionist campaign. I welcome trade with any part of the world as long as the farm assured quality is there.##Keep Scotland the Brand is about valuing the integrity of our food and drink and recognising that Scotland is the brand. Across the world, people recognise Scotland as a quality brand.#One in five Scots is employed in the food and drink sector, so it is vitally important to keep our brand quality.#We trust the food on our shelves at the moment. Butthe trade deals being proposed go through we#ll end up with a multi-tiered system of quality. If the Americans get the trade deal they want, the high food standards we have are really only going to be accessible to those who can afford to pay.#It#s bad enough people having to go to food banks to survive, without people not knowing why their kids are getting ill.Ruth Watson is keen to emphasise that Keep Scotland the Brand is not a political campaign and it#s not about Brexit.#It is a campaign looking at the realities of what is before us,# she says. #I think that we have to look with some alarm at the trade deals that have been done. The UK government just has not protected our food brands.##I do this campaign on a voluntary basis from my kitchen table,# she went on. #Many people do not know what is coming. Food is treated as a commodity rather than something we should be grateful for every day, that is how successful our farmers have been.#I just believe thatfarming fails, my community is going under.##I#ve been talking to elected representatives, I go round shows. I#ll talk to anyone about this.#But what can ordinary people do Ruth is quite clear. #Get out there and talk to each other, spread the word on social media, speak to politicians.#But most of all support our local farmers.#

title: 43-year-old-woman-admits-causing-ambulance-disturbance-a7
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered for a Hawick woman involved in a fracas while being transported to Borders General Hospital.Grace Smith, , of Fisher Avenue, pleaded guilty at Jedburgh Sherf Court to a charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in an ambulance on the A at Ashkirk on November .She admitted shouting and swearing, struggling with police officers and running from an ambulance on an unlit road during the hours of darkness.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said the accused reported that she had been assaulted by being struck in the face in a Hawick public house.She had complained of a sore face and was intoxicated but there was no evidence of an assault.The fiscal said that due to the circumstances an ambulance was summoned and it was considered appropriate to take Smith to Borders General Hospital.But at .pm when the ambulance was about five miles south of Hawick paramedics called the police because she was being unruly.Mr Fraser said the ambulance had to stop because of her conduct and Smith jumped out of the vehicle and was running along the road and ambulance personnel ran after her and escorted her back to the ambulance.Mr Fraser said: "Police officers arrived on the scene and her behaviour was described as emotional and volatile. She started struggling with police and had to be placed in handcuffs."He added that Smith stated thatshe was let out she would kill herself.A cigarette lighter was found in her underwear with which she intended to use to cut herself.Sentence was deferred until September .

title: council-backs-plans-return-jim-clark-rally
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is backing plans for theof the Jim Clark Rally later this year.Organisers of the popular event have earmarked the weekend of November  and  for the closed roads race.Following the deaths of three people in  a major investigation into closed road motor sport was launched by the Scottish Government.Earlier this year organisers were given the green light to start preparations once more for hosting the event after new legislation was passed - but they still requirepermission from Scottish Borders Council.Senior councillors havetoday confirmed that it is minded to approve plans.A recent local authority consultation on the organiserrsquos plan received more than  responses, with an overwhelming majority supporting the proposals for  rally stages, using four routes, over the two days.Councillor Euan Jardine said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank everyone who took part in the consultation."A number of specic points were raised and these have been passed to the event organiser and discussed through our Safety Advisory Group meetings.ldquoWe are all operating under new legislation in planning for this event and that has its own requirements and a signicant amount of work is still required before we could provide formal approval and a Motor Sport Order for the event.ldquoHowever, we are confident that the outstanding matters can be dealt with through the intense planning process that is ongoing and for the event to take place as currently proposed.The Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Group process enables the local authority and other concerned groups to discuss event plans, including safety arrangements.Councillor Mark Rowley said: ldquoWhilst a smaller event than in previous years, there is no doubt that a Jim Clark Rally in November would provide an economic boost to the Berwickshire area, and the Scottish Borders generally."This would be particularly welcome outwith the normal visitor season and would be a great finale to the year which has seen the successful opening of the Jim Clark Motorsport Museum in Duns.ldquoThe economic impact of the proposed event is, as written in the new legislation, a consideration for the Council in assessing whether it should go ahead, however our priority, first and foremost, is that it is as safe as possible for all involved.

title: beyond-borders-celebrating-10-years
story: TOP writers, broadcasters, politicians and artists are heading to Innerleithen this weekend for the Beyond Borders International Festival.The event which is celebrating its th anniversary, is being held at Traquair House.A number of activities will be on throughout the weekend in the main marquee in front of the house.And in the old walled garden where there will be music, exhibitions, film, food tastings, meditation sessions and yoga.The global impact of climate change will take centre stage throughout the festival including a  discussion addressing the vital role of women in climate action a youth climate change summit with school strikers taking part in discussions and events and Carbon Casualties, a photography exhibition from the New York Times which is on display in the garden.Other programme highlights include the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon former UN Special Envoy to Syria, Staffan de Mistura and journalists Lindsey Hilsum Razia Iqbal Allan Little Jim Naughtie and Sarah Smith.For a historical perspective, Professor Bettany Hughes Sir Tom Devine Sir Hew Strachan and Rosemary Goring will all be appearing.The event will also welcome remarkable female cultural leaders from Afghanistan, Kashmir, Pakistan, Syria and Yemen to take part in sessions on the art of peace building.This festival which also includes walks, storytelling and bike rides, began  years ago as the inspiration of Mark Muller Stuart QC who lives at Traquair with his we, Catherine.He told us: "The festival proves that the thirst for human debate and the desire to listen to the first-hand experiences and stories of others remains undiminished notwithstanding the rise of the digital age."What better place to do it than in the tranquil setting of Traquair in the Scottish Borders."

title: vandals-target-primary-schools-days-pupils-return
story: POLICE have launched an investigation after vandals ransacked a Peebles primary school - just days before pupils were due tofrom the summer holidays.Parents of Halyrude Primary School were horried after discovering the destruction caused by thugs at the weekend.Vandals undermined months of hard work by fundraisers and volunteers by destroying the polytunnel as well as the plants inside.Not content with ripping apart the tunnel, they also smashed a window in the school building and pushed over all the new picnic benches.The culprits also appear to have tried to force entry to a locked shed.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: "We are investigating following a report of vandalism to a primary School in Peebles."The incident happened sometime overnight between Saturday and Sunday, August  and , and resulted in a window being broken and a vegetable patch being disturbed."Inquiries to identy those responsible are ongoing."The school purchased the new greenhouse structure after landing a windfall from the Tesco Bags of Help earlier this year.The project was made possible with help from members of the Peebles CAN team and parent volunteers.And green-fingered pupils were hoping to harvest ingredients for lunches, but vandals have destroyed those plans.Locals took to the Peeblesshire Community Vandalism page to voice their disgust and dismay, with offers to help to clean up the destruction pouring in from residents.Parents said there was a large amount of broken glass within the grounds, and there are reports of trails of blood on the ground.One local said it was very ldquobrazen of the louts to carry out these attacks at the school considering it is situated next door to the local police station.One parent added: ldquoThis is sickening. How can anyone think it is okay to do this "Someone knows who is responsible for this. Do the right thing and call it in to the police.Anyone with information should contact Police Scotland on .

title: mobile-recycling-service-arrives-borders
story: MOBILE recycling is set for ato the Borders.From next month a pilot, which allows for wood, electrical items, batteries and cooking oil as well as garden waste to be deposited, will be launched in Jedburgh.Andthe scheme is successful it will be rolled out to West Linton, Lauder, Coldstream and Newcastleton.The mobile recycling service is the latest effort by Scottish Borders Council for the region to become a landfill-free area.Councillor Gordon Edgar said: ldquoThe Borders public has helped save poundmillion a year on landfill tax thanks to their efforts in recycling.ldquoHowever, we still have around  per cent of waste in our general bins which could have been recycled."Not only does this have an impact on the local environment, this costs taxpayers over poundm a year which could be spent where.ldquoWe are always looking at ways to increase recycling in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThis mobile recycling service pilot scheme is our latest effort."The four-month mobile pilot will run from Sunday, September  to the Sunday before Christmas.A survey will carried out during the same period to gauge use and views ahead of a decision being made about a roll-out.Councillor Edgar added: "It is important to emphasise this is a pilot scheme, with the results of the pilot and survey to be considered fully before a final decision is made."The mobile recycling service will operate every Sunday in Lothian Park Car Parkbetween am and pm.middot

title: additional-needs-summer-camp-goes-bang
story: A SUMMER camp for children with additional needs has been hailed a huge success.The Borders Additional Needs Groupteamed up with Live Borders to host five days of fun and adventure at the Leader Valley School in Earlston.An inaugural camp was held last year over three days.But thanks to funding from Cash for Kids and Tescos Bags for Le, the  camp was extended - with more than  children enjoying the activities.And hopes are high that next years will be even bigger.Pauline Charles from BANG told us: ldquoThroughout my years of experience, I never expected the camp to be as good as this."Wersquove had  people through our doors and over  children."We have young carers, parent carers, siblings, grandparents, foster carers ndash itrsquos been overwhelming.ldquoLive Borders staff and BANG will evaluate this project, look at worked well, and what we can improve and start to redesign rsquos respite camp."Cash for Kids donated pound, towards the camp with pound, coming from Tescos.Plans are already taking shape for more camps throughout .Pauline added: "Parents have been asking for Easter, Summer and October camps."Irsquom working now with another charity to develop a bigger project next year.ldquoWe were very privileged to be able to use Leader Valley School and thatrsquos down to the relationship with SBC."The environment and the school lsquomakersquo the project. It provides a safe environment.All of the children were given the opportunity to take part in sporting activities, music and art projects.And it was also a chance for parents and carers to relax.Sports Development Manager from Live Borders, John McBay said: "Itrsquos been action-packed for the children, but above all, itrsquos been about fun and the children feeling very safe.ldquoThe parents are the critical bit - they often get missed in families where additional needs are required."We have to make sure that mum and dad have the opportunity just to chill out and relax.ldquoThe parents have all got together and been chatting and thought this has been a great outlet for them."They have all learnt from each other about some of the challenges they face at home and dferent copping strategies.ldquoWe would love to do this on a more regular basis and not just the holidays.

title: ban-boozed-up-bgh-driver

title: erin-designs-women-39-s-tour-scotland
story: ONE Peebles cycling fan has made her mark on the very first Womens Tour of Scotland.Some of the biggest names in womens cycling took part in the three-day event earlier this month.And the winner of the Best Young Rider was presented with a jersey designed by schoolgirl Erin Acherman.The -year-olds design, inspired by the hills of the Tweed Valley, was the pick of the peloton for race organisers.Erins prize included one of her own jerseys signed by all the the inaugural tour winners.Mum Judith told us: "Erin was inspired by the hills in the Tweed Valley and part of her prize was to go in the convoy car and hear all the race excitement from a prime spot."Despite dficult conditions for much of the three stages, the Womens Tour of Scotland has been hailed as a huge success.Riders from some of the worlds top teams set off from Dundee for Dunfermline on stage one.Day two of the race took the riders from Perth to Glasgow.And the finale involved a loop through Peeblesshire from the start and finish in Edinburgh.An estimated , cycling fans lined the  kilometre route over the three days.Winner of the race was -year-old American Leah Thomas from Team Bigla.And it was another Bigla team member, Nikola Noskovao won Erins Best Young Rider jersey.

title: last-ditch-plea-save-local-drama-group
story: A STRUGGLING local am-dram group is hoping help is at hand so the show can go on.Denholm Drama Group has been putting on performances for  years.But times are tough, as the group may now be forced to close, due to a lack of support.In recent years, the local drama enthusiasts have had to cut short or completely cancel their tours, due to not having enough members to produce performances.At the recent AGM an ultimatum was agreed... to either fold or make only last ditch attempt to rally support.Alan Dowler Smith from Denholm Drama Group said: "Many of our regular members have left, for one reason or another, and the Group has been struggling for some years to find plays that suit a small number of actors, particularly men."Additionally, our backstage members are not getting any younger, and the logistics of transporting a portable theatre around the countryside are becoming unsustainable."In the past, the group was somewhat a village staple.Exactly when it was formed is unclear, but it was certainly around in the s, when it performed in the old village hall.The groups first recorded performances began in  when pantomimes took place every year at the village primary school, often involving the school children.But in , a catastrophic fire put the groups future at risk.The societys assets were totally lost, and with no insurance cover, the future looked bleak.With generous donations from local organisations and grant aid from Scottish Borders Council, new equipment was purchased and the Group found a new role, touring local village and town halls, mostly performing one-act plays.Now,  years on, the group are struggling once again, and are on the verge of disbandment.Alan said: "It has been decided that as a last-ditched effort, a more robust recruitment drive will be carried out before September comes."However,insufficient interest is expressed, with deep regret the group will close down for ever, bringing a sad end to more than six decades of service to the local community."Anyone who wishes to register their interest in joining Denholm Drama Group should call Alan Bowler-Smith on .

title: innerleithen-music-festival-goes-swing
story: THE range of entertainment at last weekendrsquos Innerleithen Music Festival lsquosurpassed our high expectationsrsquo, according to Robin Dempsey from the coordinating committee.The core venues of Live  Local at the Vale Club and the St Ronanrsquos Hotel brought in the crowds for their continuous programme of fantastic bands.There were almost  performances between them, giving a stage for many local acts.But there was a wide iety on offer where, from outstanding classical music with The Taylor Family  Friends to colourful belly-dancing at the Union Club, taking in Gaelic singing, ukulele, border pipes and line-dancing on the way.Possibly the biggest audience over the weekend was at the Church of Scotland for Innerleithen born and bred Tommy Ashby who has achieved wide acclaim on the UK circuit.Meanwhile, at the late night Festival Club, in the middle of the many contributions from festival regulars, there was the unexpected pleasure of an impromptu demonstration of Breton folk dancing from a visiting French group.Robin told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoIt feels like the festival has completed a transition from its early years focussed on large scale concerts to a vibrant community based event."It was heart-warming to see so many locals and visitors, young and old, coming together to share their love of music, whether as performers or in the audience."

title: walking-festival-organisers-hail-volunteer-army
story: ORGANISERS of the forthcoming Scottish Borders Walking Festival are hailing the volunteers who have helped pull the packed programme of events together.Since the end of last year a small army of locals from Selkirk and the surrounding valleys have been mapping, plotting and organising.And they have been rewarded with a festival of walks and social events which are selling out fast.Sue Briggs, chair of the  Festival team, told us: ldquoItrsquos been amazing."People say they couldnrsquot run a festival without volunteers and in our case itrsquos  percent true."There are only four of us on the Festival team and the local community has really risen to the occasion and given us a huge amount of support."As well as leading the  planned walks, volunteers will also drive visitors to the drop-off points.Many other volunteers are also organising the social events which will be held throughout the week-long festival.And they will also be manning a pop-up cafe in the Victoria Halls to provide a warm welcome for the walkers.Among the many special offers of help which are being made, are the young people of Rowlands who are serving up ldquoHot and Tasty Comfort Food every weekday evening from pm to pm during the festival.InChorus community choir from Peebles will provide a ldquosinging send-off on the opening day - Saturday, September .Craigdon Mountain Sports are providing a boot clinic in the Victoria Halls on the opening weekend, and local choir Safety in Numbers are hosting a musical stroll around the Haining on the Sunday.Selkirk Community Shed are busily creating wooden walking figures for the entrances to the town.And many businesses have also offered support with raffle prizes.Sue added: "The Scottish Borders Walking Festival is very much a joint effort between the Festival team and the people of Selkirk and the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys."The Scottish Borders Walking Festival takes place in Selkirk and the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys from Saturday, September  to Saturday, September .Late availability tickets can be purchased from www.borderswalking

title: 14-year-old-found-major-search-peebles
