They opted for the Wizard of Oz, which involved Noel, as Dorothy, wearing a gingham dress. Sandi asked, ldquoIs it weird I fancy you now  Paul chipped in: ldquoSo do I. Paul, as you may have read in the papers, is currently going through a messy orce and a split from his younger lover. He is bearing up remarkably well. Must be all that sugar.Michael, in honour of his Scottish Indian heritage, was making a ldquoCup of Chai fruitcake. His mum had texted him at am that day to tell him to ldquoBe calm, be slow, and be confident. Wise words, to which every other mother, having seen Michael chop fruit with giddy abandon, added: ldquoAND BE CAREFUL WITH THAT BLOODY KNIFE! Sure enough, he cut himself. His fingers were already covered in plasters. ldquoThis has to be the last one, he sighed, ldquoI donrsquot have any left. Whether he was talking about fingers or plasters it was not clear. By episode three we can expect a nationwide call for blood donors.On we cantered to the technical challenge, angel cake slices, which had to be made according to Pruersquos -stage recipe. If your instinct on hearing the phrase ldquo-stage recipe is to drive to the nearest petrol station for a Battenberg, applying to take part in Bake Off probably isnrsquot for you.: The Bake Off effectIn keeping with the showrsquos naughty but nice traditions there were several servings of double entendre with whipped filth on top, as when Paul thought one contestant was going to make a furry garden rather than a fairy one for her showstopper birthday cake. ldquoHow big is your furry garden  he giggled. Steady on, fella, yoursquore in enough hot water.There were some calamities, but only minor ones like forgetting to switch a timer on. We hope for bigger, better, worse, in the nine weeks to come. As for who was named star baker and who was given their marching orders I cannot oblige, because TV reviewers are not trusted with the final seconds. Asanyone would be daft enough to give the game away, eh Prue  Whoever triumphed, Irsquoll bet victory was sweet.

title: bbc-take-alexa-launch-voice-assistant
story: The new system, called Beeb, will be built into the BBCrsquos website and iPlayer on smart TVs, but will not be a standalone device such as Amazon Echo or Google Home.It will allow users to find their favourite programmes and use the BBCrsquos online services. The software will also be made available to manufacturers who want to incorporate it in their products.The BBC has pledged to make sure the system understands regional accents by asking office staff around the UK to record their voices to ldquotrain the software.US-developed voice assistants famously do not cope well with regional accents, with videos of people getting into comical arguments with smart assistants not understanding their accents going viral online.A study also found . per cent of Scots said they were frustrated when speaking to systems such as Alexa and Siri.People are also likely to drop their accentsaltogether when speaking to systems such as Alexa or Siri for fear of not being understood, according to a survey conducted in Newcastle.The BBCrsquos voice assistant will be activatedby saying the word ldquoBeeb, but some analysts are sceptical over the reliability of the word.Ben Wood, from CCS Insight, told the BBC:ldquoTypically, voice assistants use a multi-syllable word or phrase such as Alexa or Hey Google to ensure accurate identication. I fear Beeb might end up being unreliable.The BBC replied the word worked well during research, but it was not a final decision.Beeb is developed by the BBCrsquos own team, so it will not present users with the broad range of services offered by Alexa or Siri, which are made by major technology companies. Mr Wood told the BBC it would be dficult for the public broadcaster to compete with the tech giants.Voice assistants have become a common feature in British homes, as one-fth of UK households now own a smart speaker.Beyond offering users from around the UK the ability to use a voice assistant without the need to drop their accent, Beeb is intended to give the BBC more independence, in particular to collect userrsquos data. The BBC will withdraw its radio stations from the popular InTune app, which is used by Alexa, after Amazon refused to share user data with the Corporation.The BBC told : ldquoWith an assistant of its own, the BBC will have the freedom toexperiment with new programmes, features and experiences without someone rsquos permission to build it in a certain way. It will also allow the BBC to be much more ambitious in the content and features that listeners can enjoy.The BBC said it is also aware of usersrsquo concerns with commercial voice assistants and their use of their data.The broadcaster said: ldquoPeople know and trust the BBC, so it will use its role as public service innovator in technology to ensure everyone ndash not just thetech-elite ndash can benefit from accessing content and new experiences in this new way.In the UK, an estimated . million Britons use a smart speaker at least once a month, or theequivalent of .% of internet users, according to data by emarketer. Amazon currently beats competitors as the biggest smart speaker providerin Britain, with a market share of .%. Googlehas .%.Globally, Amazon dominates the smart speaker market with .% market share in the secondquarter of , according to a report by Canalys. Newcomer Chinese-owned Baidu comes second at .%, and Google third at .%.Scots facing issues with voice recognition have been a comedy topic for years. In , a clip in sketch show Burnistoun showing two Scots unsuccessfully trying to talk to an elevator, became an internet favourite. Two years ago, the firstGlaswegian voice assistant, ldquoSenga, appeared in show Gted and Gallus on BBC Scotland.

title: citizen-science-activists-target-salmon-farms
story: Environmental and animal welfare groups are to carry out their own tests on the public waters around salmon farms, as they call for the industry to address fears over disease and animal welfare issues.The peaceful protest follows a,-name petition calling onthe Scottish Government to make emergency inspections of salmon farms.Don Stanord, director of environmental campaign group Scottish Salmon Watch, which is coordinating a nationwide citizen science action plan at farms around the Scottish coast, said: ldquoThe Oban area will be the first one this weekend. We will leave Dunstaffnage Marina, outside Oban, with people swimming and in kayaks and we will be sampling effluent across salmon farm cages.ldquoWe will sample the effluent around salmon farms and conduct some citizen science.He claimed: ldquoOver  per cent of farmed salmon tested by the Scottish Government have got a virus and will have all kinds of toxic waste.ldquoOne-fth to one-quarter of all farmed salmon are dying every year. If this was happening on land there would be outrage. Itrsquos a case of out of sight, outof mind.Mr Stanord says the police and salmon farm companies have been notied that activists will begin their plan by circling salmon feedlots around Norwegian owned Mowi and Scottish Sea Farms at their sites in the Firth of Lorn, Sound of Jura and Loch Linnhe.Protesters will wear fancy dress, with outfits including a lobster in a gas mask, a salmon, a harbour porpoise in ear defenders and a seal in bullet proof vest being used to highlight their cause.Sondhya Gupta, of campaign group SumofUs, said: ldquoTherersquos a rising tide of pubic opposition to Scottish salmon farmsrsquo dirty business.ldquoScottish salmon should be the pride of Scotland ndash not a shameful secret branded sustainable while fish live in filthy conditions, unfit for any animal.ldquoThis year, over , SumofUs members called for the Scottish Government to force emergency inspections of salmon farms.ldquoWhile [there is a] delay, wersquore stepping in ndash but as some point regulators need to do their own job.Animal Concern group spokesman John Robins said it was time for people to reclaim the seas from floating fish farms, which are polluting the nationrsquos coastal waters, destroying wildle and turning the king of fish into the equivalent of battery hens.He claimed: ldquoSalmon farming is unsustainable, incredibly cruel and very damaging for the marine environment.ldquoThe Scottish Government must take the lead from protesters and act now to stop salmon farmers destroying our coastal ecosystem.Aquaculture has become crucial to Scotland in helping to sustain economic growth in rural and coastal communities, particularly in the north and west.It is a erse sector that takes in the farming of both finfish ndash dominated by the production of Atlantic salmon ndash and shellfish species, such as mussels and Pacic oysters.The Scottish Government supporteda working group that launched the strategy to boost the value of Scottish aquaculture from pound. billion in  to pound.bn by .There was also a desire to see the number of jobs double to , over the same period.But those ambitions have taken a hit with growing concerns over fish welfare standards.At the centre of the debate is salmonndashthe largest component of the Scottish aquaculture industry, with about , tonnes produced on farmseach year.It is Scotlandrsquos single biggest food export and worth pound million.The industry says that  per cent of Scottish salmon are certied to the RSPCA Farm Assured scheme ndash a higher percentage than any other UK farming sector.But last year, the salmon farming industry came under fire for ldquoshocking levels of fish deaths as it emerged they hit record levels due to diseases and parasites.Sea lice, which have been a major problem for the farmed salmon industry, feed on the skin and blood of salmon, and can weaken the health of a fish and stunt its growth.There is further concern about non-native rainbow trout escaping from farm cages with the ability to out compete with native species and preying on juvenile populations.While the sector spends around pound million per year in research and more than poundm in new equipment and techniques to understand and manage health and environmental problems, it emerged in April levels of wild salmon in Scotland are at their lowest since records began.At the end of , the last Scottish wild salmon netting station closed because there were so few fish to catch. As a result, Scottish wild salmon is now off the menu.Following the Saturday and Sunday protests around Oban, representativesof Salmon Watch will visit the Scottish Parliament and Marine Scotland on Monday.Hamish Macdonell, director of strategic engagement for the Scottish Salmon Producersrsquo Organisation said: ldquoUnauthorised visits to fish farms place employees and the animals they carefor at risk.ldquoThey also pose serious hazards to those entering the farms without permission.ldquoAs a result, any visit must be undertaken in accordance with the strict safety and biosecurity measures in place on each farm and take place only with the express permission of the farm manager.ldquoSalmon farmers ask that people remain a safe distance away from farms and other facilities, for the safety of all involved and to protect the health and welfare of thelivestock.

title: jim-gallagher-britain-needs-new-type-progressive-federalism
story: Prof Gallagher was Whitehallrsquos most senior civil servant concerned with devolution, working as the Director-General for Devolution in the Cabinet Office, the No  Policy Unit and Ministry of Justice.He retired in June  and is now an academic heavily involved in the Scottish constitutional question and a director in the commercial and charitable sectors.In , he was appointed Visiting Professor of Government at Glasgow University and has also been a Visiting Professor in the Centre for Public and Corporate Ethics at Glasgow Caledonian University.Since , he has been a research fellow at Nuffield College in Oxford. He is co-author of England and the Union, How and Why to Answer the West Lothian Question and of Scotlandrsquos Choices, the Referendum and What Happens Afterwards.Todays world is suddenly all about nationalisms, some of them very disagreeable, as in Hungary or the US, others very disruptive, like Brexit or, potentially, Scottish nationalism. This poses a problem for many on the left who think politics isnt about achieving national sovereignty, but promoting social justice. They struggle to deal with it, and find a coherent vision of how to reconcile peoples need for identity and the demands of economic opportunity and social justice.Brexit has upset the UKrsquos constitutional applecart, and this English nationalist project has encouraged Scottish nationalism. Both projects seek to break up multinational unions in the name of sovereignty. Brexit has already split the UK down the middle, and similar vote in some future Scottish referendum would create a fissure in Scottish society that would last generations. We need something better.Whatever happens with Brexit, there is an alternative for the UK. The risks to economic opportunity and social justice presented by independence stem not from acknowledging Scottish identity, nor from increasing Scottish autonomy, but from breaking the economic and social bonds of the United Kingdom. Its domestic market is vital for Scotlands economy, and sharing resources across the UK supports social justice in Scotland through welfare and public spending programmes, as we saw again last week the latest GERS figures.We do not have to lose these benefits in order to gain more autonomy. Instead, Scotland, and the rest of the UK, should move to a more federal system. The structures of federalism, which means dferent levels of government each with their own responsibilities, can support dferent social models, but I argue for a progressive form of federalism, one designed to create the maximum scope for social justice in each part of the country. Here is what it would mean for Scotland.First of all, it implies a change of mindset in the whole UK, from the worn-out notions of parliamentary sovereignty which drive so much of our overcentralised government, especially in England, to an understanding that the UK really is a multinational state, a voluntary association of nations which come together to preserve their identities and promote their shared interests. That implies a better form of entrenchment for devolution in the UK constitution. Given the circumstances of Brexit, it means entrenching wider powers too.More important, perhaps, it implies a design which embeds the purpose of social justice in the territorial constitution. The federal UK parliament and government should be responsible for providing a guaranteed level of welfare and public service provision across the whole territory, irrespective of whether local taxable resources are big enough to support it, much as today.But government in the devolved nations should have the capacity to increase this from their own resourcesthey think it necessary. Thatrsquos an each-way bet for social justice.Wersquore already close to that for Scotland today. Not only is the Scottish Parliament responsible for most major public services, but it can supplement any welfare benefit it thinks unjustly small. It has the money too: not only is the devolved budget about  per cent per head higher than English levels, Holyrood has wide tax powers too.A UK which followed these principles would make a similar offer to the dferent regions of England. Many of those who voted Leave in the European referendum were expressing a beef with London, not Brussels: thats where they need to take back control from.Those obsessed with sovereignty and identity see nationalism as an end in itself. History tells us this is a dangerous road. But those who want to promote social justice and co-operation between dferent peoples cannot ignore the human need for acknowledgement of their identity. For them the right approach is a model of progressive federalism, empowering the UKrsquos nations and regions in a way which gives each level of government the power to promote a just society.This will be one of the themes explored by the new Think Tank Our Scottish Future being launched with an address by former PM Gordon Brown in Edinburgh this week.

title: andrew-mckie-no-chance-stopping-no-deal-brexit
story: You donrsquot ndash whether you think Parliament is ignoring the original vote, or failing to stop an impending catastrophe ndash get a say. But Mr Corbyn, the keenest subscriber to the view that hersquos best suited to the job, was yesterday sounding out other Westminster opposition leaders. Alas, since theyrsquod settle for anyone, except Mr Corbyn, they united instead on seeking a legislative route to rule out a no-deal Brexit."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Jeremy Corbyn agrees to prioritise cross-party legislation to stop no-deal Brexit","description": "Cross-party talks led by Labours Jeremy Corbyn have resulted in a co-ordinated effort to thwart Boris Johnsons plans for a no-deal Brexit.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs hzIHip-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests hzIHip.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Iain Macwhirter: Gordon Browns caring sharing Union is dead. Brexit has killed itUnsurprisingly, because they paint an exit with no deal as a national disaster along the lines of the Black Death or Scotlandrsquos  World Cup campaign. Yet even those people, who previously promised to implement the referendum result, thenstood on a manesto promising to implement the result, then, by one of the biggest Commons vote ever, voted to implement Article , specying ldquono deal as the default, balked at putting Mr Corbyn in power as the price of stopping any hard exit.Itrsquos dficult to see how legislation guarantees the prevention of no deal, though. Itrsquos an illogical position, when no deal is the default, and when any restrictions wouldnrsquot be binding on the PM, nor even necessarily within his gt .It is, however, no more bonkers than the Brexit Partyrsquos insistence that only a no deal Brexit is real Brexit ndash a stance no doubt inspired by government failure to deliver, but one that no one was advocating three years ago.Mr Corbyn, unlike the other party leaders, mentioned the continued possibility of a vote of no confidence. As Leader of the Opposition, hersquos best-placed to table one, but that is the extent of his advantage. Assumingit were won, the Labour leader would then have to demonstrate he had the necessary support to form a government, which means about  votes: ie, persuading some  non-Labour MPs to vote for him.The prospect of Tories, even those practically demented by the idea of no deal, backing that is nil. The Lib Dems have ruled it out. It would be a huge strategic error for the SNP. And thatrsquos before you take into consideration the fact that there could well be about  of Mr Corbynrsquos own MPs who wouldnrsquot vote for it.Mr Corbyn, despite not banging on about it in his meeting, is still apparently insisting that a vote would mean him becoming prime minister .I think a GNU would be undemocratic, undesirable and unlikely. But in a fantasy world where the proposed interim PM were Ken Clarke, or Harriet Harman, itrsquos just about possible. But you would need a vote of no confidence first. So the person best placed to bring it about is Jeremy Corbyn, and the biggest obstacle to it happening is Jeremy Corbyn.Small wonder the other leaders preferred to make it a last resort, trying instead to rule out no deal by legislation. The problem is that you canrsquot, with absolute certainty, for both practical and political reasons. Practically, because MPs have to vote for something, anything  to avoid what is otherwise the default position, and so far they canrsquot agree on what that would be. Eventhey could, therersquos no guarantee itrsquos anything thatrsquos on offer.:Will SNP efforts to unseat Lib Dems be enough for Shetland by-election victoryAnd while the no deal absolutists are as deluded as the revoke extremists, there are potential deals ndash and the one negotiated by Theresa May is one ndash clearly even worse than no deal. Thatrsquos why MPs voted it down three times.Politically, this approach is tricky because, while Boris Johnson says he would still rather have a deal, he is totally committed to exit by October . Just as his mind wonrsquot be changed by a vote saying MPs wonrsquot accept no deal, nor will such a vote magic away the fact that itrsquos the legal default. His opponents would also have to commit to some positive course of action to replace it: either the blatantly anti-democratic nuclear option of outright revocation, or acceptance of some deal that is actually on offer at the time. Or an election.By contrast, the PM has nothing to lose by calling an election. Therersquos a sporting chance he could win itwersquove left the EU, or would do so during the campaign, or at oncehe won. Therersquos the near-certainty that the Brexit Party would prevent him winninghe were to show the slightest sign of backing down on the date.This is now a game of chicken where everyone ndash Johnson, Corbyn, Remainers, Brexit absolutists, and the EU ndash believes that their only chance of getting what they want is not to blink. The rest of us can only close our eyes and cross our fingers

title: teens-not-ones-misbehave-gigs
story: A couple of months ago, in the first throes of summer, we were quick to bemoan the army of neon-clad adolescents who descended on Glasgowrsquos TRNSMT festival, leaving a trail of glitter behind them. Loud  Yes. Using empty Lucozade bottles to disguise a half a litre of Mad Dog  Almost definitely. But, the way social media sharpened its pitchforks, you would have thought heart-shaped sunglasses were a calling card for the eventual downfall of society.All that fuss is why I find it is pertinent to point out that, after several weeks of attending massive outdoor concerts, itrsquos not young lsquouns who are the problem.It wasnrsquot a teenager who jabbed me in the back repeatedly with a selfie stick, and the woman who obnoxiously heckled Dave Grohl throughout the Foo Fighterrsquos recent Bellahouston Park gig certainly wasnrsquot born in the noughties. See also: the greying gentleman who downed a pint only to bring it back up all over the poor person in frontof him.The younger lot  They smiled, laughed and sang along, offering a cheerful ldquosorry pal whenever an overzealous dance move hit someone next to them.Rather than declaring a case of Teenagers versus the Middle Aged, I think it is important to ask: is this actually annoying, or am I just getting a bit old  For me ndash someone who is young enough to happily elbow my way to the front of a gig but old enough that my lower back will feel the effects of it the next day ndash it is a bit of both.During my recent gig adventures, I found my eyes rolling at a younger couple who spent the majority of The Curersquos two-and-a-half hour set with their tongues in each otherrsquos mouths. Then I sheepishly remembered that, only one decade earlier, I had been guilty of doing exactly the same thing. By my own admission, I am an ageing hypocrite with a short memory.Still, it remains my observation that those who claim to be older and wiser are often drunker and sloppier, as anyone forced to endure public transport the last time Take That played Glasgow will attest. The finger of blame may often be pointed at teenagers because itrsquos easy but the real anti-social behaviour is hardly limited to those under the age of .As far as Irsquom concerned, the kids are alright. Not so convinced about the parents.

title: freshwater-pearls-fund-scottish-river
story: The successfully-breeding population was found in one of the tributaries of the River Spey in an area of native woodland by Kieran Leigh-Moy while he was interning with Scottish Natural Heritage .Freshwater pearl mussels can live up to  years old, but the species is critically endangered as populations across Europe have not been breeding successfully for several decades.But the new colony found on Speyside appears in rude health, with juvenile mussels spotted among the adult mussel beds.Kieran Leigh-Moy has been working on a project to understand why the declining populations of freshwater pearl mussels in the river were not breeding and locate sites where they could be reintroduced to help their recovery.While developing a method for identying the most suitable locations, he came across a previously unknown population which, signicantly, contained juveniles.One of the mussels found by MrLeigh-MoyFreshwater pearl mussels can live up to  years old, but the species is critically endangered as a large proportion of the populations across Europe have not been successfully breeding for several decades.Mr Leigh-Moy, who was working on a project to develop a method for identying suitable locations for pearl mussel beds, said: ldquoIrsquod already identied this river as potentially having good quality habitat, so was visiting the site to conduct more in-depth surveys to seeit would be a suitable site for a reintroduction, but was stunned to find juvenile freshwater pearl mussels already there.:Mussels lsquostressedrsquo by under sea noise, Scottish research suggestsldquoItrsquos really rare to find a new population of these mussels, and especially one that is breeding successfully, so it was a really exciting moment.ldquoWhatrsquos particularly signicant is that the juvenile mussels found were many miles away from the nearest known breeding population and thatrsquos good news because it could help to prevent further range contraction of the species.It is hoped the approach developed by Mr Leigh-Moycan be used to help direct conservation efforts and find good habitat for freshwater pearl mussels at other locations, as well as mitigate the shrinking range of the species in the river.Keiran Leigh-MoyThe pearl mussel is a strong indicator of good environmental conditions and their recovery in this part of the catchment is likely testament to sensitive land management in the area.SNH and Forestry and Land Scotland are working to promote this kind of land management, which includes reducing pollution and establishing riverside woodlands, through their support of the Spey Catchment Initiative.Giles Brockman, from Forestry and Land Scotland, said: ldquoThis is really exciting news.ldquoForest management is not just about trees and this is a strong indication that actions to protect water courses are effective and can help to sustain and nurture wildle and rare species.:New plea for Scotlands at-risk pearl mussel as bid to stop illegal fishing falters#This type of land management will help allow rivers, and iconic species like pearl mussels, to cope with increased temperatures resulting from climate change. This is especially important for freshwater pearl mussels, which are a species that is particularly sensitive to any changes in climate.SNH has also been promoting sensitive land management more widely through our work to protect freshwater pearl mussels in the Pearls in Peril LIFE project that sought to save and restore populations in  rivers across Scotland, England and Wales.Through its pound. million Bioersity Challenge Fund, SNH is supporting a number of projects to enhance key freshwater pearl mussel populations across Scotland.Together with the Scottish Government the organisation is also managing a project starting this month to identy the sources of fine sediments in three key pearl mussel catchments - including the River Spey.:Chefrsquos quest for lsquoclabby dhursquo finally yields a taste from familyrsquos past#APEM and the University of Plymouth have been appointed to conduct state-of-the-art ldquosediment fingerprintingwhere there is evidence that important mussel populations are being adversely impacted by fine sediment inputs."This will be the first step in reducing the impact of fine sediments on freshwater pearl mussels, which is identied as among the primary drivers of the decline of this species across Europe.

story: Service users at Pitscurry Project received a donation from The Inverurie Environmental Improvement Grouprecently.Pitcaple Environmental Projecthas helped IEI to plant up and grow the hanging baskets in Inverurie Town Centre every summer for the past  years.In recognition of this essential work the IEI committee presented a cheque for ¬£, to service user Alan Dawson who received the donation on behalf of all the service users at Pitscurry.The donation has been used to purchase a new John Deere lawnmower for use in the grounds of Pitscurry.John Glover, IEI Chairman, said: ‚ÄúThe service users at the Pitscurry Project play a very important role every year in preparing and planting up the hanging baskets for Inverurie Town Centre.‚ÄúAt the end of the summer they clean out the baskets, compost the plants and store the baskets ready for the following year.‚ÄúThis year‚Äôs floral display is going to be the best ever and the service users deserve great praise for the contribution they made in achieving this.‚ÄúThe hanging basket displays could not have been achieved without the fantastic efforts of the service users at Pitscurry, the local Inverurie businesses that sponsor the hanging baskets and Aberdeenshire Council who provide the plants.‚ÄùLast year IEI won an It‚Äôs Your Neighbourhood award from environmental charity, Keep Scotland Beautul which recognised Inverurie as being an ‚ÄòOutstanding Community‚Äô. The judge praised the efforts to coordinate keeping Inverurie clean, colourful and tidy.This year IEI have entered Inverurie in Scotland in Bloom and the sea of colour from the hanging baskets and planters will enhance the appearance of the Town Centre when judging takes place on the  August.Rona Smith, Day Service Manager Inverurie DAYS, added: ‚ÄúI would like to thank Inverurie Environmental Improvement Group for the kind donation of funds in recognition of the high standard of work achieved by the service users in planting and caring for the hanging baskets every year.‚ÄúThe plants were delivered to Pitscurry from Aden Park Nursery two weeks ago. title: aberdeenshire part of a new national network to save our sound heritage
story: Unique and rare recordings of Scottish traditional music made in Aberdeenshire in the s through to the s are to be preserved as part of a national initiative led by the British Library.Unlocking Our Sound Heritage is a major ¬£. million sound preservation and access project, which has received a ¬£. million National Lottery Heritage Fund grant.It has seen the formation of the first ever network of ten sound preservation centres, including one at the National Library of Scotland.This UK-wide partnership of institutions aims to digitally preserve half a million of the nation‚Äôs most rare and at-risk sounds and share them as widely as possible.Reel-to-reel tape recordings from the John Junner Collection - recently donated to Live Le Aberdeenshire‚Äôs Museum Service - were selected as one of the Scottish beneficiaries.The full collection comprises musical instruments, recording and playing equipment, and music recordings on wax cylinders, tapes and cassettes.Junnerwas a schoolteacher and esteemed musician from Strachan, Aberdeenshire.An acknowledged authority on the music of James Scott Skinner ‚Äì Banchory‚Äôs famous dancing master, violinist, fiddler and composer ‚Äì he was interested in sound, its mechanical production and reproduction on ious machines.Over the years he recorded many local musicians. His musical collecting and recordings pre-dates the Folk Revival of the s and s and consequently are unique.David Cook, sub-committee chair of Live Le Aberdeenshire, said: ‚ÄúWe are delighted to accept this unique collection of local and national signicance into the permanentcollections of Aberdeenshire Council Museums.‚ÄúWhilst the recordings are in good condition, they are threatened by physical degradation and some are stored on formats that can no longer be played. Being part of this national initiative will ensure some of our local recordings of Scots music will be digitally preserved and available to folk at home and abroad for future enjoyment and learning.‚ÄùAlastair Hardie, one of the trustees acting on behalf of the late John Junner, said: ‚ÄúIn his will, John Junner asked for his collection to be kept ‚Äòat a suitable location in northeast Scotland‚Äô.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire Provost Bill Howatson said armed forces personnel make huge sacrices to keep us all safe"  Aberdeenshire Council achieves gold award for work with armed forces, families, veterans and cadetsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"It is claimed the Violet Route for dualling the A could endanger Fyfe House"  Action group ‚Äúappalled‚Äù at threat to Guiding house viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser""Ten years after his death, his wish has finally been fulfilled with this donation. Having the collection in the care of Aberdeenshire Council Museum Service will help to ensure the long-term wellbeing, development and accessibility of the John Junner Collection for posterity.‚ÄùThe major grant from the National Lottery Heritage Fund is allowing the network to develop a range of engagement activities to connect the wider public with their sound heritage. A key element of Unlocking Our Sound Heritage will be an interactive website hosted by the British Library, launching in , allowing listeners to explore a wide selection of recordings.Dr John Scally, Scotland‚Äôs National Librarian, said: ‚ÄúOur sound heritage is under threat as tapes, minidiscs and lacquer, vinyl and shellac discs degrade or equipment to play them becomes obsolete.‚ÄúThis is a vitally important project that will help to save the nation‚Äôs sounds and preserve them to be enjoyed for many generations to come.‚Äù

title: garioch sports centre serves up an ace with new tennis plans
story: With the nation currently hooked on Wimbledon, it#s a fitting time for Garioch Sports Centre to unveil its new tennis-focused proposals.Inverurie Community Council has submitted fresh expansion plans to Aberdeenshire Council on behalf of Garioch Sports Holdings.Full planning permission was secured last year for a major extension of the Inverurie facility, but changes in the community‚Äôs requirements and pressures on funding have prompted a reduced development.Initially the plans would have seen the Burghmuir Drive centre expanding into one of the largest amenities of its kind in Scotland, incorporating tennis courts, a multi-sports arena, fitness suites and an all-weather G pitch for Inverurie Loco Works FC which has now been dropped.But while the scale of the expansion might not be as ambitious, the new plans do reveal tennis courts and improvements for fitness along with an Early Learning Centre for younger children.Thanks to signicant input from Judy Murray ‚Äì mother of tennis stars Andy and Jamie ‚Äì the plans feature three dedicated tennis courts and the centre has committed to a three-year partnership with the JM Foundation, highlighting the commitment of the centre to develop the sport across Garioch.The centre and JM Foundation will work in partnership in upskilling their workforce and identying potential coaches while funding coach education.In a supporting statement the centre writes: ‚ÄúThe matter of securing the appropriate funding for the ious options which have been considered over the last couple of years has impacted upon how the plans have altered with the focus very much now being on the new tennis provision.‚ÄúThe most recent plans reflect the discussions with the Lawn Tennis Association and also Tennis Scotland.‚ÄúThe advice and guidance of Judy Murray has also been pivotal in how the plans particularly for the tennis courts have progressed.‚ÄùThe applicants also believe that despite the downturn in oil and gas and other industries, there is still a demand for its facilities.It reports: ‚ÄúAs many of the activities and programmes now carry waiting lists, there is proof that despite a downturn in many industries the title: money talk team helps thousands of low income families
story: A free financial advice service has helped low income households save more than # million in the last nine months.Low-income families who seek free financial advice from the Money Talk Team are on average now ¬£, better off.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell is encouraging more families to make use of the Money Talk Teams service.The service offers one-stop, personalised advice on dealing with debt and ways to reduce household bills.With around , cases of unclaimed benefits in Scotland, it also helps low income families identy what financial support might be available. The service is supported by Scottish Government funding of ¬£. million over two years.In the last nine months, the Money Talk Team has helped a total of  people be better off by more than ¬£ million ‚Äì meaning households benefit by more than ¬£, on average. A total of nearly  people have accessed the service.Launching a national advertising campaign to raise awareness of the Money Talk Team, Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell said:‚ÄúThe Money Talk Team is making a huge dference to the thousands of families that have already taken advantage of this free service.‚ÄúThe friendly, experienced advisers talk callers through the options available, letting them know exactly what they are entitled to and helping them save money.‚ÄúBut there are still too many families out there not getting what they should be.‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a parent struggling to pay the bills at the end of the month, you‚Äôre not alone. It doesn‚Äôt matteryou‚Äôre in or out of work, one call to the free phoneline is all it takes to get some advice that could be a massive help to your household.‚ÄùMoney Talk Team is the new name for Financial Health Check, which started in  and is delivered by Citizens Advice Scotland. Citizens Advice Scotland Chief Executive Derek Mitchell said: ‚ÄúWith a footprint in every community across Scotland and  years of experience of delivering confidential and impartial advice, the Citizens Advice network in Scotland is uniquely placed to deliver the Money Talk Team service.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.motherwelltimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt""  Free community film showsto Bellshill viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MTHW | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MTHW | Article Teaser"‚ÄúPeople should be claiming what they are due. title: new staff support for recycling sites but permits also on the way
story: On average, % of materials taken to centres in the area are recycled, with rates ying from % to % at the ious locations. The aim is for all recycling centres to reach % by .Up to  new staff are due to be in place by mid-September and will provide advice and assistance to householders about what can be recycled. The additional roles are part of package of improvements agreed by councillors in January.However, a new permit scheme is also being introduced to move business waste away from recycling centres to create more space for new recyclable materials to improve services to householders.While most businesses pay the necessary fees to dispose of their waste and recycling responsibly, the current open access to recycling centres means some business waste is being presented as household waste so that it can be processed free of charge.To tackle this, a new permit scheme is one of the measures being introduced next year to prevent such abuse. Under the new scheme householders using commercial type vehicles - vans, pick-ups, minibuses or trailers - to take materials to recycling centres will require a permit to do so.The permits will be free of charge and can be used at any of the  recycling centres operated by the council.Households will be able to apply for the free permits in advance and a yearrsquos supplywill be issued at one time to minimise inconvenience.Permits can be applied for online or by post at any time of the year and will be valid for  months.Aberdeenshire Council does not expect the new scheme to have an impact on most householders as permits will not be required for cars, estate cars, people carriers, MPVs or xs, unless they tow a trailer or a horse box.Permits can be obtained for trailers up to  x  ft in size.Certain types of vehicle typically used by businesses will not be permitted at HRCs, specically those over . tonnes gross weight, tippers, tractors, large trailersand vehicles with twin wheels or more than four wheels.Aberdeenshire Councilrsquos Waste Manager, Ros Baxter, said: ldquoThe approval of the new permit system is very good news as it will allow us to make space for more recyclable materials at recycling centres and improve services for householders.ldquoMost households will not be affected by the permit system at all as cars, estate cars, people carriers, MPVs and xs will continue to have unlimited access to recycling centres.ldquoWe are keen to minimise inconvenience to those householders who use commercial type vehicles or trailers to take materials to recycling centres."Only one application is required to get a yearrsquos supply of permits and we have also increased the number of permits to  per year to make sure householders have enough permits to cover the grass cutting season.ldquoWe will be communicating the details of the new permit scheme over the coming months, so there will be plenty of time to apply for the permits before the new scheme starts.ldquoBusinesses will be provided an alternative service at waste transfer stations, and with a lower price for recycling, will be encouraged to segregate and recycle as much of their waste as possible.ldquoWe will be monitoring closely how the new schemes settle in and can tweak them in future based on feedback received.More information about the new recycling permit scheme is available on Leave the lights onVehicles parking on a road where the speed limit is more than mph, facing away from the traffic or outside of a designated parking area should technically have their side lights on overnight to help prevent collisions.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. Check all mirrorsDrivers and passengers need to check all of their mirrors before exiting a parked vehicle as it is always the responsibility of occupants to ensure opening doors will not impede passing pedestrians, cyclists or other vehicles.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. title: final flight for flying banker
story: A Royal Bank of Scotland employee who has flown almost , trips in Orkney is celebrating retirement after  years as the UK‚Äôs only full-time ‚Äòflying banker‚Äô.Clocking up more than , journeys on Loganair‚Äôs eight-seat Britten Norman Islander, which provides the Orkney Inter-Isle air service, Anne helped Royal Bank of Scotland customers in the isles branches.Anne served around  to  customers during each visit, from crofters to fishermen to those in the tourist industries.She is only the second person to have held this exclusive role, taking over from Maisie Muir who started the flying service in . Prior to that a banking boat, known as the Otter Bank and skippered by Anne‚Äôs great uncle, docked at each of the islands served by the bank.Officially recognised for her service, Anne was awarded an MBE in  and has worked for the bank for  years, serving customers at the branch in Kirkwall before she took on the flying banker role.Her recent farewell flight was the -minute journey from Westray to Kirkwall, piloted by long-serving Captain Colin McAllister. The aircraft was met with a water cannon salute by the airport‚Äôs fire brigade and Anne was presented with retirement gts and a Loganair membership card entitling her to two freetickets and unlimited ticket upgrades whenever she travels.As Anne left the final flight of her career she was met by Liam McArthur MSP, Bill Spence, Lord-Lieutenant of Orkney, her Kirkwall branch colleagues, Loganair and airport employees ‚Äì who gave Anne a guard of honour as she walked to the terminal.Another resident of Orkney, Lois Canning, who joined Royal Bank of Scotland in  has been appointed to the role. title: highlands and islands msp to retire at next election
story: Highlands and Islands Green MSP John Finnie has announced that he will retire at the next Scottish Parliamentary election.The Scottish Greens have begun selecting candidates for the election in  and Mr Finnie, who was first elected to represent the Highlands and Islands in  and subsequently re-elected in , has indicated that he will not seek a further term.Speaking of his decision, which he announced earlier today, Mr Finnie said: ‚ÄúIt is an honour to serve the Highlands and Islands in the Scottish Parliament and I intend continuing to work hard until my last day in office.‚ÄúI‚Äôve been involved in representative politics since being elected a Highland Councillor in  and enjoyed helping people, but I feel the time is right to step aside and let others bring their energy and ideas to what is a demanding job.‚ÄúThroughout my time in Parliament, I‚Äôve put my home region of the Highlands and Islands and my constituents at the forefront of my work. Driven by my interest in social and environmental justice, I have been pleased to secure a number of concessions and legislative changes to improve the lives of people in the region.‚ÄúAt this time, I‚Äôm focused on working with others to secure the passage of my Member‚Äôs Bill giving children equal protection from assault and hope to see it become law in the near future.‚ÄúThe Climate Emergency our planet is facing means that, more than ever, Green policies are required. I know there are others who can ensure they are promoted, and delivered, for my home, the Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Meanwhile, I look forward to having more time to spend with my family.‚ÄùMr Finnie is one of four list MSPs who currently write monthly columns for The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: next phase of kirkwall thi announced
story: The second phase of works under the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiativeand the Places and Spaces project is due to get underway at the beginning of next month.Orkney Islands Council is reporting that the works include new paving outside the Orkney Museum, a new parking area outside the former Spence‚Äôs newsagent and new paving into Victoria Street.This will take place from September until February, with work suspended through the whole of December to support shopping on the street during the festive period. Free parking of up to one hour will apply as usual in metered car parks over the winter period.Tankerness Lane will be closed to vehicles throughout the works, with one-way systems in place at ious times on Broad Street and Palace Road ‚Äî with Victoria Street closed to vehicles for approximately five weeks from  January . Pedestrian access will be maintained throughout.The council has said the key aspects of the Place and Spaces project are to improve the area at the bottom of the Strynd and top of Castle Street, provide a new path to the war memorial to enhance it as a place to stop and reflect on the signicance of the monument and improve the head of Victoria Street to encourage more people into this part of the¬†town.Depute council leader, councillor Leslie Manson, said: ‚ÄúThe works carried out in Kirkwall‚Äôs town centre through our Townscape Heritage Initiative Scheme have given our streets and buildings a much-needed new lease of le, whether that be improvements to the shop fronts or the attractive new paving at the head of Broad Street.‚ÄúThis latest phase is aimed at improving the entrance to Victoria Street to encourage more shoppers and visitors to take a wander down this street ‚Äî a long-held aspiration of the businesses that are situated there.‚ÄúThere will, of course, be some inevitable disruption, but we‚Äôve worked hard to ensure that this is kept to a minimum, including suspending works for the Christmas period. I look forward to seeing the improvements that are made and the effect these have on our historic streets.‚Äùcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: Orkney Islands Council has announced who will take up the role of executive director of education, leisure and housing, when the current executive director, Wilfred Weir, retires later this year.James Wylie will be taking up the post from Mr Weir, who announced his intention to retire this coming Autumn, after five years in post.Mr Wylie is currently the council#s Head of Education .OIC convener, councillor Harvey Johnston, said: ‚ÄúWe interviewed a strong field of candidates and I would like to offer my congratulations to James, who has accepted this opportunity to take on a role of great importance to the council and to the wider community we serve.‚ÄùCouncillor Gwenda Shearer, chairwoman of the education, leisure and housing committee, said: ‚ÄúThe post provides the chance to make a positive and lasting impact on the lives of children, young people and adult learners, on the tenants of the housing we provide and on the many people who use our leisure facilities ‚Äî from museums and libraries to swimming pools and healthy living centres.‚ÄúI would like to thank all the candidates we interviewed and wish James all the best in this rewarding and challenging new role.‚Äùcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: read how kirkwall hotspurs sealed the brough cup
story: The Orkney Cheese ‚ÄòA‚Äô League reached a thrilling conclusion on Tuesday, August , as Kirkwall rivals Rovers and Hotspurs met at the Bignold, in front of the biggest crowd at a league fixture for a number of years.The  season has been something of a rollercoaster, with the top five teams taking points off each other throughout, leading to an exciting title race.A draw would be enough for Hotspurs to end a -year wait for the Brough Cup, given their head-to-head advantage, while Rovers needed the three points to win their first championship since .Both sides fielded strong line-ups. Craig Clouston and Callan Jessiman were tasked with anchoring the midfield for Hotspurs, while Rovers lined up in a --, spearheaded by Steven Tulloch and Zack Singh.The opening stages were cagey, as the two teams felt each out. The big talking point of the opening half hour was an agricultural challenge by Scott Drever in the Rovers midfield. He went over the top of the ball on Jordan Low in the middle of the park, an offence referee Mike Cursiter saw fit to issue a caution to the midfielder, with Hotspurs looking for a red.Aiden Drever saw a free-kick go narrowly wide of Davy Leonard#s post after  minutes, while Tulloch might have done better with a half chance just before the half-time whistle. A driven ball from Graeme Horne on the left was nodded on by Singh, but the veteran Rovers striker couldn#t direct his header on target, with Hotspurs appealing for an offside flag.The match remained goalless at the break, with neither team having really got going.The match was soon to kick into le in the second half. After  minutes, Rovers ‚Äòkeeper Liam Valentine made a hash of a clearance, booting the ball against Spurs striker Jerry McBeth. With the goal gaping, the Hotspurs striker was just about to pull the trigger when he was tripped by Valentine.Cursiter awarded the free-kick, and after a long consultation with his linesman, deemed the challenge worthy of a yellow card only, despite the protestations of the away side. Joe Wilson#s effort from the set piece was tipped wide by the ‚Äòkeeper.Just before the hour mark, Rovers saw their best chance come and go. A long ball found Connan Rendall on the right, who controlled it wonderfully before shuffling inside to the edge of the box. His drilled effort looked every inch a goal until Leonard flung himself down to his left to tip it round the post.Moments later, the breakthrough was to come at the other end, as the match swung from end-to-end.Aiden Drever was penalised for a foul on Logan Peace wide on Hotspurs left. The free-kick was flighted in but cleared out to Joe Wilson. His cross back in found Hotspurs legend Wayne Monkman at the back post, whose header floated over the stranded Valentine for the opening goal. Could Monkman#s goal be the fairytale ending for the defender on his final Hotspurs appearance Rovers now needed to score twice in the last  minutes to win the title, but in truth they found a well-marshalled away defence dficult to break down. Hotspurs had the bit between their teeth, with a first ‚ÄòA‚Äô League title since  now tantalisingly close.The hosts# task was made even more challenging when Aiden Drever was sent off for two bookings in quick succession with  minutes to go. From there, Hotspurs saw out the game relatively comfortably.In the th minute, Valentine got caught underneath a high ball into the box, dropping it at the feet of substitute Jack Paterson. As the sub tried to get a shot away, he was impeded by the Rovers goalie, who saw his second yellow card of the evening to ensure his side would finish with nine men.Seventeen-year-old midfielder Jessiman stepped up to coolly slot away the resultant penalty, ensuring Hotspurs would win the  ‚ÄòA‚Äô League, and sparking scenes of delight amongst their support on the sidelines.OAFA president Colin MacLeod paid tribute to both sides for a hard-fought league campaign after the match, and invited up Hotspurs skipper Keith Harcus to receive the Brough Cup for his side.Harcus ‚Äî standing in for the injured Owen Rendall ‚Äî paid tribute to his centre-back partner Monkman who is set to bow out of domestic football as an ‚ÄòA‚Äô League champion and urged his teammates not to go another  years before landing the biggest prize in domestic football.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: work set to begin at scapa flow museum
story: Work to restore and improve the Scapa Flow Museum is set to begin next month, Orkney Islands Council has said.This follows a recent decision by the local authority to take forward a revised project at Lyness.The council has said the aim is to concentrate efforts on renovating the historic pump house and on building an extension to the museum, with an Orkney-based company recently appointed to carry out the work. A refurbished and extended museum is expected to re-open during the summer of .Council leader James Stockan said: ‚ÄúThis is a project of tremendous signicance for Hoy and for Orkney as a whole.‚ÄúIt has taken longer than we first hoped to get to this stage and it will be excellent for all involved to see work getting underway soon.‚ÄúI am delighted that, like the council, the project‚Äôs external funders remain fully committed to the scheme.‚ÄúWhen complete, the restored and extended museum will for the first time in many years open all year round, encouraging more people to visit Hoy and boosting tourism throughout the island.‚ÄùThe museum‚Äôs role is to chart Orkney‚Äôs military involvement in the First and Second World Wars and provide a safe home for a major collection of wartime artefacts, many of national and international importance.After a competitive tendering exercise, the contract for the work has been awarded to Orkney BuildersLtd.A temporary exhibition on the wartime history of Scapa Flow is on show at the Hoy Hotel while the museum is closed. This has been part-funded through the Island of Hoy Development Trust.Repairs to the Romney Hut at Lyness and options for the Oil Tank will be considered at a later date.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: key-players-unfolding-political-drama
story: Key players in the next stages of BrexitPrime Minister Boris Johnsonrsquos plan to hold a Queenrsquos Speech on October  has sparked an onslaught of fury as critics branded the move a ldquoconstitutional outrage.The controversial plan ndash described as ldquoa very British coup ndash will see Parliament temporarily shut down from around September  until the state opening on October .But who are the key players in this unfolding political drama  ndash The Prime Minister -- --Mr Johnson insists it is ldquocompletely untrue to say Brexit was the motivation for his plan, explaining that it was time for a new session of Parliament to set out his ldquoexciting agenda.In a letter to MPs, the Prime Minister said he intends to bring forward ldquoa new, bold and ambitious domestic legislative agenda for the renewal of our country after Brexit, adding that while there will be a ldquosignicant Brexit legislative programme to get through there should be ldquono excuse for a lack of ambition.But Mr Johnson will not escape accusations that his decision to hold a Queenrsquos Speech on October  is designed to block MPs from considering ways to thwart his Brexit plans. ndash The QueenMr Johnson spoke to the monarch on Wednesday morning to request an end to the current parliamentary session in the second sitting week in September ndash a process known as prorogation. -- vw,vw,px, px"The Queen and Boris Johnson--MPs have hit out at the position the Prime Minister has put her in, with Labour former cabinet minister Ben Bradshaw saying the move would ldquodrag the title: nicola-sturgeon-accuses-pm-acting-like-dictator-dark-day-democracy
story: Nicola Sturgeon with Boris JohnsonNicola Sturgeon has hit out at the Prime Minister over his bid to suspend Parliament, accusing Boris Johnson of acting like a ldquodictator by pushing through an ldquooutrageous assault on basic democratic principles.The Scottish First Minister joined a chorus of outrage at the PMrsquos plan, which would see the Commons shut down for more than a month in the run-up to Britainrsquos European Union departure date.The Prime Ministerrsquos actions make it ldquoclearer than ever that Scotland cannot be properly served by a shambolic, crumbling Westminster system, and that our future lies as an independent country, she added.Mr Johnson, however, insisted there would still be ldquoample time for MPs to debate Brexit either side of a crunch EU summit on October  ndash despite seeking a parliamentary suspension from around September  until the State Opening on October .# @NicolaSturgeon: ldquoShutting down Parliament in order to force through a no-deal Brexit, which will do untold and lasting damage to the country against the wishes of MPs is not democracy, itrsquos dictatorship." pic lRMVvflmmdash The SNPAugust , But Commons Speaker John Bercow labelled the move a ldquoconstitutional outrage, saying he had not been consulted.And Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThis is a dark day for democracy. Attempting to shut down Parliament to force through a no-deal Brexit is an outrageous assault on basic democratic principles.ldquoIn doing so, Boris Johnson is acting more like a dictator than a prime minister in what is still supposed to be a parliamentary democracy.ldquoInstead of this abuse of process Boris Johnson should have the courage of his convictions and call a general election.The SNP leader pledged the PMrsquos plan would be ldquofiercely resisted byher party and other opposition politicians in the House of Commons, urging Conservatives who are ldquoconcerned about the direction their party and government is taking to speak out against the Government.Ms Sturgeon also called on Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson to join in actions to try to halt Mr Johnson, stating that she ldquokeeps telling us she opposes a no-deal Brexit ndash today she must say what she will do to help stop it.SNP depute leader Keith Brown however claimed that the Scottish Conservative chief had ldquogone into hiding, along with other leading figures in her party. --Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson was accused of having lsquogone into hidingrsquo--Scottish Secretary Alister Jack cancelled media interviews which had been scheduled to take place in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning.Addressing journalists gathered outside the Scotland Office, Mr Jack said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted the Prime Minister is going to have a Queenrsquos Speech on October .ldquoItrsquos a very good step forward in having a Queenrsquos Speech. Wersquove had a long Parliament. We need a Queenrsquos Speech to deliver, as he said on the steps of Downing Street, an exciting legislative programme for this new government.ldquoWhat will then happen is there will be a debate on that and there will be time enough to discuss Brexit and many other things in the Queenrsquos Speech ahead of us, hopefully getting a good deal from the European Union at the Council of Ministers meeting on October .Mr Jack added: ldquoThis is no dferent to what wersquove had, bar a few days, every day since Tony Blairrsquos premiership.ldquoWe have always had a conference recess. This is the conference recess with a few days added on. We donrsquot need to come back and prorogue Parliament for the Queenrsquos Speech, wersquoll do it before we leave, wersquoll have the Queenrsquos Speech and therersquos ample time for debate.Amid the outcry a group of more than  cross party MPs and peers launched a legal bid to try to stop Mr Johnson from proroguing Parliament.Jolyon Maugham QC, director of the Good Law Project, which is supporting the move, confirmed a motion had been filed at the Court of Session in Edinburgh.We have filed a motion asking the Court of Session to suspend the Prime Ministers request that Parliament be suspended. pic vkdRofpNsVmdash Jo Maugham QCAugust , Meanwhile, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie hit out at what he branded ldquoan Eton coup and a democratic outrage.He added: ldquoIhope that Ruth Davidson will join the chorus of condemnation that this decision deserves and confirm that Scottish Conservatives will oppose any measures to prevent Parliament having its say.Scottish Greens co-Leader Patrick Harvie said: ldquoBoris Johnson led a Leave campaign which cheated and broke the law to win.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that now hersquos the Prime Minister he is continuing his assault against democracy.ldquoIf we need to lsquotake back controlrsquo from anyone, we need to take it back from him.copy -. title: lesley laird tories want us to work until we drop don t let them
story: Universal Credit has already shown just how cruel the Tories can be, but even more pain could be heading our way.The Centre of Social Justicethink tank proposed recently to move the pension age to  by the year . The same think tank which, while chaired by Tory MP Iain Duncan Smith, dreamt up Universal Credit and played an instrumental part in its design a design which forces many terminally ill people back to work and deliberately delays crucial payments to some of the most vulnerable people in our society.Centre for Social Justice  Whoever picked that title obviously loves a misnomer.Based on current le expectancy rates in my Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath constituency, increasing the pension age to  would mean men would receive a state pension for around  months on average before they died, while for women it would be five years.After years of work, National Insurance contributions and saving for a pension, the time left to enjoy retirement would be brutally short.Working until you drop would be the norm for a great many of us. The CSJ‚Äôs lack of understanding about dferent types of work is painfully obvious. Imagine working as a carer, nurse, teacher, or in a factory until . I doubt that many of us would even get to our pension.So, while we are all being distracted by flag waving and Brexit, is this the future many Tories have in mind for us People used to say the Tories looked after elderly voters, but it now appears the elderly are an inconvenience.Who can forget the disastrous ‚Äòdementia tax‚Äô that derailed the Tory general election campaign in  For some, the Tories‚Äô broken manesto commitment of free TV licences for over s could be considered a small matter.However, add in WASPI pension injustice and declining le expectancy and we get a very clear picture of a government that really doesn‚Äôt care for the oldest and most vulnerable in our society.No matter how you dress it up the ‚ÄòNasty‚Äô Tory Party is alive and kicking in .But it doesn‚Äôt have to be like this.The work of the last Labour government under Gordon Brown saw the introduction of pension tax credits, free bus travel, cold weather payments and free TV licences to the elderly.Under Labour there was an increase in le expectancy and a signicant reduction in pensioner poverty ‚Äì now being eroded under the Tories.Actions speak so much louder than words.A Labour government will restore dignity and fairness to the lives of our elderly, something they have earned and deserve.A Labour government will retain the triple lock on pensions to ensure that the state pension keeps pace with earnings and the cost of living.A Labour government will work to resolve the unfairness that has hurt so many WASPI women.We don‚Äôt need any more policies from Iain Duncan Smith and the CSJ, we need a Labour government that will be compassionate and deliver for all of our society and we need it now.Lesley Laird is Shadow Secretary of State for Scotland¬©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: group calls for community backing to save maritime heritage
story: was established as a community interest company in  by directors Marc Chivers, Esther Renwick and non-executive director Lauren Doughton.Moder Dy#s Esther Renwick and Aberdeenshire artist Norma D Hunter alongside an unusually large boat noost and boat draw at Bridge End, Burra. Photo: Moder Dy CICThe recent PhD graduates joined forces in their shared passion for saving Shetland‚Äôs #rapidly vanishing# maritime heritage. So far they have footed the bill for the company and its projects.Dr Chivers# expertise on Shetland boats and boat use has been combined with Dr Renwick‚Äôs work on community monitoring of eroding coastal archaeology to create a pilot project recording the boat noosts of Burra, and their stories, with a view to expanding this to a Shetland-wide project.Moder Dy archaeologist Dr Renwick said: ‚ÄúFolk are getting older, those who remember the days where everyone had a small boat are sadly getting fewer. Climate change is speeding up sea level rise and the increasing regularity of violent storm events means the coastal archaeology is also rapidly vanishing.#Please help us record the sites and the stories of everyday maritime Shetland before it is too late.‚ÄùModer Dy is run entirely voluntarily with the non-financial support of Shetland Amenity Trust, Archaeology Shetland and Scotland‚Äôs Coastal Heritage at Risk . It also has the support of Burra History Group for the Burra Noost Project and is partnering with Bressay History Group to support their recording of Bressay noosts this summer.Costs such as the website, room hire, resources for free school visits and insurance have so far been financed by the directors. Money is slowly trickling in via donations, sponsorship, and profits from workshop ticket sales. The next workshop is being held in Unst on Saturday st June.The first step of applying to the National Lottery Heritage Fund has been successful, allowing Moder Dy ‚Äì named after the dialect phrase for the mother wave ‚Äì to apply for a pot of ¬£, to run the Burra Noost Project.However, at least ¬£, needs to be raised to match this grant funding. title: main stands down as shetland manager
story: Outgoing Shetland manager Kevin Main.The Shetland football team are looking for a new manager after Kevin Main decided to step down from the role.This comes just over a week after his side regained the Milne Cup in a dramatic penalty-shootout win over Orkney.Main had been in charge of the Shetland team for the last four years, and said that he had decided the time was right for someone  to step in and lead the squad towards the next Island Games in Guernsey.This decision #certainly was in my mind for a few months,# he said, and he added that last month#s win over Orkney had #confirmed things in my mind# in regards to his decision.He said he had talked over the decision with a few of the team#s senior players before telling the whole squad that he would be standing down.#I thanked them all,# he said.Main refused to be drawn over who would replace him, or who he might like to take on the job next, but he said: #anybody that comes in will inherit a fantastic bunch of players#.He said that although he will take a short break from the sport, he will #not be far from Shetland football#. raquo..
