title: by election hustings updates as candidates clash
story: The first of the two by-election hustings is currently underway in Mareel#s auditorium.Eight of the prospective candidates are in attendance at the hustings, with Ukip#s Stuart Martin still on the mainland and the Conservative#s Brydon Goodlad unable to attend due to medical reasons. He is being represented by Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston.BBC Radio Shetland#s John Johnston is hosting the event, with all eight candidates being given a minute to introduce themselves and their policies before moving on to audience questions.Independent candidate Ian Scott provided an impassioned speech, saying that he has¬†#stood specically steadfastly against the cuts, the Tories, the Liberal Democrats‚Äù before. He also reacted angrily to the news that Mr Goodlad could not be in attendance, shaking his head as Mr Halcro Johnston explained his absence.SNP candidate Tom Wills began by saying that #Shetland is ready for a change# and asked for  months to show what he can achieve in Holyrood, while Lib Dem competitor Beatrice Wishart opened her speech with a defiant message: #If you want an MSP who will speak up for Shetland, I‚Äôm your woman#.The first question of the night revolved around transport, with Ms Wishart and Mr Wills clashing immediately, interrupting each other#s answers as Mr Johnston appealed for both candidates to let the other finish.Mr Halcro Johnston responded to Mr Wills# five-point transport plan by saying that #Tom Wills¬†has a load of great ideas but they won‚Äôt be delivered#, while independent candidate Ryan Thomson added that #nothing gets done‚Äù because ‚ÄúShetland is the pawn‚Äù in mainland politics.Councillor George Smith directed a question at Mr Wills, asking him how he expected the SIC to afford one of his election pledges, free foot passengers on inter-island ferries.Mr Wills responded to say that this could be paid for #, and when# the Scottish government provided additional funding to the council.Mr Thomson criticised the NorthLink ferries in response to a question about increased capacity on the ferries. He focused his attack on the much-maligned sleeping pods, not for the first time, saying that we had been #lumbered# with these pods and said he was reticent to even call them pods, instead saying #it#s a chair#.#Bigger ships# and #daytime sailings# were potential solutions that Mr Thomson suggested as alternatives.On the subject of Brexit, only Conservative representative Mr Halcro Johnston said that he was in favour of Brexit, although he admitted that he voted to remain in the EU.Mr Scott and Mr Wills attacked the coalition of the Tories and the Lib Dems, with Mr Scott saying that the #Tories and Liberals approved austerity and that they had¬†#turned to the racists and the fascists# which garnered wide applause.Mr Halcro Johnston responded to say it was #always very amusing listening to Ian but I‚Äôm afraid he‚Äôs wrong#, which was met negatively by the audience.Mr Wills said that the SNP #could stop Brexit#, and added thatthey were pulled out of the EU by Westminster then a vote for independence could put Scotland back into the European Union.He expanded on Mr Scott#s point by saying the #reason why people voted for Brexit is because of the coalition of Lib Dems and Tories which approved austerity# to a rapturous reception. Ms Wishart responded to the issue of Brexit to say that it was #time for a peoples vote and time for people to work together across parties# to stop Brexit.Scottish independence was the next topic up for debate, and understandably provoked perhaps the most isive reactions of the night.Mr Scott, Mr Wills and the Green Party#s Debra Nicolson all came out in favour of an independent Scotland, while Mr Halcro Johnston, Ms Wishart and independent Peter Tait were against it. Both independent candidates, Michael Stout and Ryan Thomson, said they would wait to see what benefit Shetland could get from Scotland becoming independent before deciding how to vote, should another referendum come up.Mr Scott#s positive attitude towards independence was because, he said, # nothing  we#ll get rid of these damned Tories#.Ms Wishart wanted the audience to #imagine the chaos#Scotland tried to break up the union, citing Brexit as an example. She said the vote was supposed to be #once in a letime# and that there were better priorities for funding, such as healthcare.Mr Wills responded to this point: #which has been cut by the Tory Liberal coalition#, to audience applause.Conservative representative Mr Halcro Johnston said that #I think SNP talk about independence because its easier than talking about their failings#, and added that nobody would be surprised to find that he was against independence.I#m sorry, Tom Wills is havering. Independence will not keep Scots in, or bring us back into, the EU. EvenBritain stays in, Scotland will leave, automatically, with #No Deal#, on Independence Day and will have to reapply to join. The EU has confirmed this, in writing.Also,nothing changes, our starting budget deficit will be ¬£. billion per annumversus the EU#s limit of about ¬£ billion . The UK will stop paying funding that.We shall have to cut spending raise taxes by some ¬£ billion p.a. on an annual budget of about ¬£ billion, to satisfy the EU#s economic conditions for joining.That means we shall face years of withering austerity, just when we need to spend more to stimulate the economy.We also need to set up our own independent central bank which the nationalist think tank #The Common Weal# says will take nine years from an Indy Yes vote. So we shall be out of the EU, with #No Deal#, for at least, seven years from Independence Day.Scots are canny folk. They will not vote for such an independence prospectus.John, your oft repeated notion that an independent Scotland will start with a budget deficit of ¬£. billionis an entire fancy. Whatdebt an independent Scotland may have to take on as a share of the current UK#s debt, in the event of Scotland becoming independent, will be a matter for negotiation and agreement . Similarly, matters such as whether, and for what fees , the rest of the former UK might be permitted to retain its weapons of mass destruction on Scottish soil will be for negotiation agreement in the event of Scotland becoming independent.I would not hold my breath waiting for their answer.Ian Scott and Tom Wills have very selective memories. The austerity cuts introduced by the last Conservative  Lib Dem coalition were in response to the mess Brown and Blair made of the British economy. The outcome of this prudent handling of the deficit was obviously popular with the British people because David Cameron‚Äôs government won an overall majority in the subsequent election. David Cameron also delivered on another election pledge to have an in out referendum on Europe. How can the SNP criticise any party for that they have never delivered on an election pledge in their le. Finally, the only racism and fascism that has come out of this by-election has been promoted by the SNP anti-English racism. The SNP are Tartan Fascists.Had it not been for the global economic crisis, and Blair#s US led wars, Brown#s finances could have seen him becoming PM. This shows the harm in getting too friendly with the US, not that there will be much of a choice for the remnants of the UK after Brexit. I won#t digny John M Scott#s final comment with a response other than to note that it is Trump and Farage that have been too close to white supremacists. Happily neither seem that popular north of the boarder. The SNP promote an inclusive civic nationalism which can#t seriously be compared to that of the far right.##and the peril of getting too friendly with the EU is being dictated to and bled dry by a Union of Socialist Republics ruled by a Germanic Franco dictator, aided an abetted by a random collection of Belgians.Best off going it alone and not being shackled up to some #superpower#, either actual or wannabe.John M Scott#s remark reminds me of something a reviewer wrote in the Shetland News in : #The depths of ignorance are surely plumbed here#.It#s like I wasnt even there.No mention of Labours position on Brexit or Independence. Thanks guysYou#ll have to listen tonight folks, there isnt even any mention of VE which was discussedLabour has a position on Brexit!Where did you find out about this Johan @Brian Hill, It is you who fantasise, not I. I did not mention #national debt#. So let#s set aside the #smoke and mirrors#. I am talking about the ¬£. billion gap between Scottish tax revenue raised last year and money received from Westminster. We have been running similar, sometimes larger deficits for many years. Unless something changes this will become our annual budget deficit on obtaining independence as Westminster will no longer fund the shortfall.Don#t take it from me. A couple of years back, the SNP#s own Sustainable Growth Commission conceded that we would start independence with a budget deficit of .% of our GDP, around ¬£. billion per year, and proposed a multi-year plan to reduce it to less than %, which just happens to be the EU#s maximum permissible limit. @Brian Hill, Ok,we are to be pernickety:The UK funds the dference between our tax revenues and what Holyrood receives from the Exchequer so we are talking about a so-called #notional deficit# that has been ongoing for many years.This is recognised by the SNP#s Sustainable Growth Commission.UK funding will cease on Independence Day and the notional deficit will become , our budget deficit.The current UK funding of ¬£. billion equates to around ¬£ per head of population, per year. With independence that money will have to be found where # borrowing or tax hikes # or cut from public services.#John, as Scotland is not yet independent then it cant have been running a deficit for any#, what utter nonsense. Since when did you have to be independent to go broke  Try telling that one to your bank manager. Dr Craig Dalzell! who  wings over Scotland! still based in England, hard to make it up but you manage it Brian.John, I#m sorryit appeared pernickety, but my fundamental point was that you cant predict the future finances of any putative future independent Scotland based on the notionalaccounts of a devolved Scotland within the current UK state. No amount of repetition of thosefigures alters the arguments.Brian,You#re putting words in my mouth. I#m not attempting to predict future finances. Merely, observing that we would start from a very bad place, losing the ¬£. billion annual UK funding.But please, don#t take it from me.The SNP#s Sustainable Growth Commission propose a multi-year programme of deficit reduction and Oxford University Professor Gallacher has studied the most recent figures. He concludes: #Any more realistic look‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. starting from Scotland‚Äôs actual fiscal position, swtly shows‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.would quickly amass unsustainable levels of debt, and the cost of servicing it would require large cuts in public services. #‚Ä¶.today‚Äôs relatively high spending is supported by large UK fiscal transfers, and to avoid cutting it large borrowing would be needed. #That swtly adds up to very large debt, which cannot be afforded. #All this strategy would achieve is to delay the inevitable big cuts in spending until Scotland is heavily indebted and so has to make even more cuts.#Paraphrasing your own words, Brian, #No amount of SNP preication can alter the facts.#..

title: prevention programme aimed at stopping diabetes surge
story: A programme to tackle the increasing prevalence of type  diabetes by PHA is operational across the Ballymena area.Approximately , people are living with diabetes in Northern Ireland, a startling .% increase since [].Type  diabetes accounts for % of all cases of diabetes and is a serious and progressive condition. The disease can lead to early loss of le, cause preventable sight loss in working age people, and is a major contributor to kidney failure, heart attack, stroke and even amputation, yet the illness is often preventable by adopting healthier lestyle changes.The new Diabetes Prevention Programme is aimed at people who have been identied as pre-diabetic ‚Äì those who have been tested and have a blood sugar level slightly above the normal range ‚Äì by their nurse, pharmacist or doctor.Cullybackey patient Thelma Shanks from Cullybackey was referred onto the programme this year. She said: ‚ÄúThere is a history of hypertension and diabetes in my family. ‚ÄúSeveral of my paternal aunts sadly passed away due to complications that came with the disease, and my mum was found to be diabetic following admission to hospital for routine tests. ‚ÄúI was born in London, but grew up in my parent country, Jamaica. I ed to the UK for good in , and my husband and I moved to Northern Ireland, where all my children were born, in . ‚ÄúAs a nation, we from the Caribbean tend to be a bit more susceptible to diabetes than others, so it wasn‚Äôt a complete surprise to be told I was at risk of developing the disease. ‚ÄúI am also a trained doctor so despite having given up my profession when I had children, I have knowledge of the medical risk.‚ÄúI have a wonderful busy family le. I have four children, all of which I home schooled, and of course, their needs always came before mine. ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre running a busy house and looking after everyone  it‚Äôs easy to forget to look after yourself. However, in  when I heard that a health fair was coming to the area I decided to go along. For a small fee they carried out multiple tests which showed I had hypertension or high blood pressure. ‚ÄúI decided to make an appointment with my GP who put me on a number of drugs, first Irbesartan, then Amlodipine and finally a diuretic to bring my blood pressure under control.‚ÄúI realised I needed to be more careful with my diet and tried to be a bit healthier but I admit it was a bit half-hearted. TESTS‚ÄúMy blood sugar levels were border-line they weren‚Äôt going down but they weren‚Äôt going up either, so I thought everything was all right. I was having routine check-ups with my nurse at this stage so I was on her radar and having blood tests taken intermittently. In April  I had my regular tests done and then hopped on a plane to London. ‚ÄúIt was my daughter‚Äôs birthday and I had decided to treat her by going away for the week. We had just made it to the hotel when I received a phone call from my nurse. ‚ÄúShe said tests showed my sugar levels were up and I was actually diabetic, which was the wake-up call I needed. Let‚Äôs just say it wasn‚Äôt quite the luxury week that I had planned! My daughter certainly ate well, but no sugar passed my lips that trip. ‚ÄúNeedless to say, I had the blood tests repeated soon after our , and was delighted to learn that due to my dietary sacrices, my blood sugar levels had again receded into the ‚Äòpre-diabetic‚Äô band.‚ÄúPrior to our trip away, my doctor had called me. She said there was a new Diabetes Prevention Programme starting soon in my area being run by the Public Health Agency. She askedI would be interested and of course I agreed.‚ÄúThe class has  others in it and we meet on Wednesday afternoons. There are eight women and two men, and together we re-learn what we should be eating, what to avoid, and how to step up our exercise routines. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve found it really helpful because everyone is in the same boat and we can share our experiences and encourage one another. ‚ÄúEach week we build on the goals of the previous weeks, paying attention to diet and exercise and gaining strength from each other.‚ÄúI used to believe that running after a busy family was exercise enough but now I‚Äôm walking every other day, trying to increase my pace and my distance. My daughter and I often walk together and I try to keep up with her. LONG TERM‚ÄúOne day I managed , steps in one walk and  of those miles were uphill. I‚Äôm trying to make long term changes and make sure these become habits I‚Äôll stick to for the rest of my le. So far I‚Äôve lost  kg, and my exercise levels have increased signicantly too. My blood sugar levels have decreased, but more importantly I feel better physically and psychologically. ‚ÄúThe Diabetes Prevention Programme and the team who deliver it have been amazing. I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing a new me at the end of the nine and a half month course.‚ÄùThelma was referred onto the Diabetes Prevention Programme by her GP Dr Jean McCaughern, Maine Medical Practice, CullybackeyThe practice serves around , patients that live within a six mile radius of the surgery. Dr Jean McCaughern joined the surgery around  years ago and was placed in charge of the practice‚Äôs diabetes clinic.At first she managed this alone, today she heads up this specialist clinic with the help of two practice nurses. She does this alongside her normal GP responsibilities.She said: ‚ÄúWhen I first started the clinic around % of our patients were diabetic and that included those who had both type  and type  diabetes. Today that figure has more than doubled. In  we have a prevalence rate of .%. That‚Äôs how quickly the disease is on the rise. ‚ÄúOften patients don‚Äôt realise just how serious the illness is. I have overheard patients saying ‚ÄòI just have a touch of diabetes‚Äô or ‚ÄòI only have diabetes‚Äô, but it‚Äôs a serious illness which can cause deterioration of vision, contribute to heart disease, kidney disease, stroke, and vascular problems which at their worst can lead to amputation.‚ÄúPatients of mine have had all these problems and more. The reality is dferent to the perception and it‚Äôs only when dficulties start that people begin to understand what living with diabetes can mean. The longer you have the disease, the more likely you are to have any one of those complications.‚ÄúHaving diabetes presents practical problems too. In some cases the DVLA can revoke people‚Äôs drivers licensestheythey believe there is poor management of diabetes. This can include raised sugars, but more importantly sugar levels dropping and causing confusion in patients as is would be unsafe to drive.‚ÄúFor some people having diabetes is out of their control. Those with Type  diabetes have no choice but to manage it using medication. ‚ÄúFor others who spot heightened blood sugar levels early, termed pre-diabetic, they have a window of opportunity to reverse or delay a diagnosis of Type  diabetes through healthy eating and exercise. That‚Äôs who the Diabetes Prevention Programme is aimed at and who it can help.‚ÄúOnce higher sugar levels are discovered, the earlier people can make changes and the higher the chance they have of reversing the outcome. Sometimes, it‚Äôs not about changing the diagnosis but delaying it by a decade or so. ‚ÄúThe longer you can hold it off the longer you can hold off the complications that come with it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not all bad news though, having diabetes, whether Type  or Type , is largely manageable either by medication, treatment or diet. ‚ÄúInsulin, used primarily for treating type  diabetes, lowers blood sugar levels when diet and exercise alone aren‚Äôt sufficient, but the effectiveness of these medications depends on how early the disease is diagnosed and the size of the dose.‚ÄúI was happy to get involved in the Programme. Having an interest in diabetes I was approached by the Public Health Agency at the operational stage to look at the programme‚Äôs viability in my area. I‚Äôm a big supporter. ‚ÄúSo far I‚Äôve referred around  people from the practice onto the programme which educates and empowers people of the contents of foods, the need to exercise and develop better eating patterns. ‚ÄúOften I‚Äôve heard people say once they have to go on a special diabetes diet but that‚Äôs not the case, it‚Äôs just healthy eating, it‚Äôs the way we should all be eating.‚ÄúAs far as the success of the programme goes, it‚Äôs a little early to tell. The first cohort of people started on the programme in May and early results are positive. Certainly weight loss as a group has occurred and people have more knowledge of food, portion control and exercise.‚ÄúSo, there are benefits for all and for some the course is working really well. When you join the programme as a group you bond as a group, you encourage each other, you don‚Äôt want to let your group members down. ‚ÄúThat shared experience and cohesiveness is a real motivator and works across all ages and all groups. For many the programme offers them a chance to turn a future diagnosis around and gives them the tools to change their future. ‚ÄúThat can be le changing and what the programme is designed to do‚Äù.KEY FACTSThe Diabetes Prevention Programme is run by the Public Health Agency.It is aimed at people who have been identied as pre-diabetic ‚Äì those who have been tested and have a blood sugar level slightly above the normal range ‚Äì by their nurse, pharmacist or doctor.The Diabetes Prevention Programme is delivered over a nine month period and is free of charge.It is facilitated by health coaches who offer help and assistance to participants, helping them change their lestyle, diet and physical activity with the aim of postponing and even preventing type  diabetes.For more information on the ‚ÄòDiabetes Prevention Programmeemail your local Health Trustdiabetespreventionni@northerntrust.hscni.netst

Bowana, a four-piece blues, soul and rock band then entertained the crowds and played late into the evening.Chairman of Broughshane  District Community Association, Mr Lexie Scott was thrilled with the events success.He told the : ‚ÄúIt really was a terric night.‚ÄúWe were thrilled with the talent that took part in the open mic session and we were equally delighted with the performances of everyone .‚ÄúThere was a great response to the traditional music section and we had an enthusiastic audience for Bowana and the easy listening part of the evening. ‚ÄúThe rain didn‚Äôt even manage to dampen spirits and our BBQ was also a great success.‚ÄùMr Scott is keen that an event like this would be repeated in the future.‚ÄúWe definitely are looking at how this could be repeated.‚ÄúHopefully we can establish a pattern for events that will celebrate the end of Summer each year.‚Äù

title: ballymena rbp for ballymoney parade
story: The Royal Black Preceptory‚Äôs Sovereign Grand Master, Rev William Anderson, will be a special guest at the County Antrim demonstration in Ballymoney on Saturdy .The leader of the Royal Black Institution will join with around , Sir Knights as they walk through what are sure to be packed streets in the busy town.Up to  preceptories and around  bands will gather at the Agricultural Showgrounds. Leaving at .pm, the main parade will travel via North Road, Model School Road, High Street, Main Street, Meetinghouse Street, Rodeing Foot and Garryduff Road, before arriving at the Joey Dunlop Leisure Centre and into the Riada Playing Fields for a religious service.During the parade, there will be a short stoppage for an Act of Remembrance at the War Memorial on High Street where a wreath will be laid.The  proceedings will begin at pm, chaired by Roland Hill, Ballymoney Worshipful District Master. title: poolpod makes access easier at leisure centre
story: A state-of-the-art Poolpod has transformed access to the swimming pool in Seven Towers Leisure Centre.The new equipment, which represents approximately poundk investment from Department for Communities and Sport NI through Disability Sport NI allows users with mobility issues a dignied way of entering the pool.Poolpods are a  lt that were developed for the London  Olympic and Paralympic Games and are transforming access to swimming pools for people with disabilities and restricted mobility.Seven-year-old Avah McGinty was one of the first people to try out the Poolpod at the Seven Towers Leisure Centre.Avahs dad, Darren said it has been a fantastic addition to the leisure centre and he hopes to see more people making use of the equipment.Darren added: ‚ÄúAvah has spina bida and hydrocephalus and spends most of her time in a wheelchair. ‚ÄúShe is a very outgoing little lady and loves to try dferent activities with swimming being one of her favourites.‚ÄúThis new Poolpod makes trips to the pool much easier and a much more enjoyable experience for her.‚ÄúI am sure this will encourage more people with limited mobility to consider swimming as a safe and enjoyable form of exercise.‚ÄùMayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor Maureen Morrow, said: It‚Äôs great to see this Poolpod being installed to help people with limited mobility gain safe access to the swimming pool.I would like to thank Department for Communities, Sport NI and Disability Sport NI for their generous contribution towards this Poolpod.This fantastic piece of technology will contribute to making our leisure centres more accessible for all users.Kevin O‚ÄôNeill, Chief Executive Officer of Disability Sport NI, added: The facilities that have received the Poolpods have shown a great commitment to improving access and providing their staff with disability inclusion training.This project is part of the wider District Council Disability Sports Hub Project which recently saw a signicant investment into disability sports equipment in every council area.Sport NI Chief Executive Antoinette McKeown said many benefits of an active lestyle to our physical, emotional and mental wellbeing should be open to everyone.These new Poolpods are the latest example of how the Active Living: No Limits Action Plan is enhancing the lives of local people with a disability through sport, she added.The many benefits of an active lestyle to our physical, emotional and mental wellbeing should be open to everyone here, and Sport Northern Ireland is proud to be working with our partners to create more inclusive opportunities for local communities to enjoy, engage and excel in sport.

title: car goes up in flames after teenagers come to driver s aid
story: Two teenagers from Co Down have been praised for their brave actions in helping a man escape from his car before it went up in flames.Sean Kelly, , and Joshua Allen, , spotted smoke coming from the grille of the man‚Äôs car in the village of Dromore shortly after pm yesterday and raised the alarm.Sean Kelly and Joshua Allen, the Dromore teenagers who rescued a man from a car which caught fireJoshua said: ‚ÄúWe were on our way back from the shop. You could see smoke and a small bit of flames coming out of the car, I knew the engine was on fire.‚ÄúSean and I were straight over to him and told him he needed to get out of the car. He had no idea what was going on. ‚ÄúWe got him out of the car and pushed it off the road. We got his stuff out of the car and popped the hood. ‚ÄúI phoned the fire brigade and Sean and I redirected traffic to keep them away from the car until they came.‚ÄúThe fire started to escalate, within I‚Äôd say about  seconds of popping the hood the engine was fully on fire.‚ÄúThankfully the fire brigade got there before the petrol tank went up.‚ÄùJoshua guessed the man, whom they helped back to his house in the village with the items they helped rescue from the car, was in his fties or sixties. A video has been circulated on social media of part of the incident and praise has been heaped on Sean and Joshua for their brave actions.Joshua commented: ‚ÄúIt happened so quickly, natural instincts took over. You couldn‚Äôt stand by and watch that. He needed help. He didn‚Äôt have a clue that his engine was on fire. If we hadn‚Äôt done anything he could have died.‚ÄùBoth Joshua and Sean play rugby at Banbridge RFC and are former students at Newbridge Integrated College. The boys will start Banbridge Tech next month.Sean‚Äôs mother Lisa commented: ‚ÄúThey were very brave and I‚Äôm very proud of them, but it could‚Äôve went terribly wrong just as quickly.New date set for  years cycle Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BANB | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BANB | Article Teaser"‚ÄúI‚Äôm a grateful mother that everyone is okay and safe.‚Äù

title: lidl s new concept store officially opens
story: Regional Director of Lidl Northern Ireland Glen Cinnamon has described the opening of the #new concept# Lidl multi-million pound store in Banbridge as an #exciting step.#Lord Mayor Councillor Darryn Causby joined Lidl Northern Ireland on Thursday, to celebrate the launch of its very first ‚Äònew concept‚Äô store following five months of construction. Mr Cinnamon, said: ‚ÄúIt is an exciting step for us to launch our inaugural ‚Äònew concept‚Äô store here in Banbridge. This state-of-the-art design will allow us to streamline our processes and enhance our customer shopping experience even further while still offering top quality products at market-leading prices. ‚ÄúAnd this is just the beginning for us we will continue to invest in new stores and modernisations over the coming months and years, bringing the best of Northern Irish produce to customers in towns and cities right across the country.‚ÄùRepresenting a multi-million pound investment into the locality by the retailer, the state-of-the-art building measures nearly , square feet and stands at eight metres high. Boasting a brand new architectural design and spacious layout incorporating a bigger warehouse, wider aisles, as well as improved staff and customer facilities, the state-of-the-art building represents the future of Lidl stores in Northern Ireland. title: michael keeps on trucking with second book about ni lorry drivers
story: A Co Down man is determined to keep on trucking as he publishes his second book about le on the road for the Province#s lorry drivers.Michael Wallace, a -year-old design graduate from Annaclone, is a driver with his family‚Äôs business Wallace Bros Haulage.Some of the Finneys Bros trucks that feature in the bookHaving grown up around trucks, in the past two years he has put together two photo-focused books about the heavyweights of the highways. The second volume of ‚ÄòTrucks of Northern Ireland: Through The Lens‚Äô was launched at the recent Causeway Coast Truckfest.He said: ‚ÄúThe response to the first book was phenomenal and this was why I decided to bring out a second volume. With the rise in truck runs and shows in recent years interest in trucks throughout Northern Ireland has really grown.‚ÄúA lot of people got in touch after the first volume and I‚Äôve been able to use photographs from a lot more dferent photographers this time round which has helped so much to tell the story.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúTrucking is like no other job and people often spend more time in the lorry than they do at home. Drivers make huge sacrices including being away from their families and missing many important events just to earn a living. A classic Woodside Brothers truck from the late s‚ÄúHowever, when you ask any lorry driver how they find the job most will say that they are living the dream. It gets into your blood and once you‚Äôre a trucker you‚Äôll always be one, nothing could ever replace it.‚ÄùOf the changes to trucks over the years he said: ‚ÄúMany of the older folk would recall having to be able to fix the trucks as well as driving them, you were a mechanic as well as a driver, but nowadays they have to be plugged in so the computer can tell you what‚Äôs wrong with them.‚ÄùProceeds of the book will be going towards the Cancer Fund for Children and the Kevin Bell Repatriation Trust, a charity to help bring people home who have died abroad.The book, priced ¬£, can be ordered via the Facebook page ‚ÄòNI Truck Book‚Äô.These could be the  messiest car interiors in the whole of the UK Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BANB | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BANB | Article Teaser"

title: front door side door always a welcome
story: BORN and bred in North Belfast, Brendan Rafferty is a well-known figure to many in the food and catering industry. With over thirty years experience in the field, he has been the head chef, first manager and then owner of the popular The Side Door restaurant, located at Febro Buildings on the Antrim Road in Glengormley for  years.Brendan grew up on the Cltonville Road until he was  years old when his parents moved to the Antrim Road. His first part-time job came in the old Lansdowne Court as it was known back in the day.Ever since a young age, Brendan was interested in the food and catering industry and decided to pursue a career in the field when he left school at . After three years at the College of Business in Brunswick Street in Belfast, he went on to complete a B-Tech qualication and an advanced catering course.Subsequent employment followed in the shape of a full-time role in the Lansdowne before spells in Belfast Castle, the Crawfordsburn Inn and Chimney Corner.But it is with his current venture The Side Door that he has made his name, establishing the -seater restaurant ever since taking over six years ago as the new owner.Brendan explained: ‚ÄúThe Side Door is basically a family-style restaurant with something on the menu for everyone. The menu is very mainstream.‚ÄúThe previous owner‚Äôs menu was something close to fine dining but people were still ordering pizzas. I thought it wasn‚Äôt right so I changed the menu about a bit.‚ÄúI had my own ideas and kept it mainstream to attract anybody and everybody.‚ÄúThe pressure was there to get bums on seats and it has worked ever since so I have no intention of changing it.‚ÄùBrendan also acts as Head Chef at The Side Door and thanks to his wealth of experience, he has put his own style and spin on food.‚ÄúI would cook things like lasagne, carbonara, scampi and burgers,‚Äù he added.‚ÄúEverything is home-made. I am experienced enough to know what way things are cooked best and what sells well.‚ÄúI used to be a sauce chef and I suppose sauces and soups are still my forte.It is still probably my favourite aspect of being in the kitchen.‚ÄúI was brought up in the catering industry on a French theme which is something I still like doing, especially with some of the specials in the restaurant in some shape or form.‚ÄùAs for how things have changed in the industry, Brendan points to a number of ious things he has noticed over the years.‚ÄúThe food industry has changed massively over the years,‚Äù he explained.‚ÄúThemes and customers needs and wants are like night and day now since when I started off over  years ago.‚ÄúFood takes waves now, much like politics. whether Italian or Mexican themed.‚ÄúThere are more vegans and vegetarians than ever before but allergies is such a big thing these days. Celiac is definitely the main one and you just have to be so careful.‚ÄúI probably wouldn‚Äôt have taken as much of an interest in allergies but when I found out my daughter had a nut allergy, it changed everything. It scared me.‚ÄùLooking ahead to the future, Brendan reflected on what he has achieved so far at The Side Door.‚ÄúGlengormley is a perfect setting. People thought I was mad taking The Side Door on with the amount of competition but my idea wasyou want to buy a washing machine and there is more than one shop available in the same area to buy it, you will still compare it, just like restaurants.‚ÄúI think we stand out because we are not pretentious. Many restaurants are, in my opinion. We are not ‚Äì what you see is what you get: fresh food bought from a number of dferent suppliers who I have built up a relationship with over the years. I buy the best produce that I can get but at affordable prices for customers.‚ÄúI believe also in good service and to my knowledge, we are still the only bring-your-own restaurant in Glengormley.‚ÄúAs for the future, I am not getting any younger. I thought around two years ago about looking for a bigger premises. What I have to turn away from a Thursday to a Sunday now is scary some weeks, but I thought here was working. I decided to stay because things are good and long may it continue.‚ÄúCustomers keep coming back so I must be doing something right.‚ÄùBrendan Rafferty is Owner, Manager and Head Chef at The Side Door restaurant in Glengormley.The Side Door,Febro Buildings,Ballyclare Road,Glengormley,BT DZ.Tel:

title: speckled hen have got it well sussed
story: IN a food market dominated by commercial farming, big drinks brands and unormity, the authenticity and quality yielded by do-it yourself approach is becoming all the more appealing, and there are few businesses doing it better locally than the Speckled Hen Bar and Dining Rooms.Having long brewed an exciting range of its own craft beers and ciders, the Lisburn-based establishment has taken the next crucial step towards self-suffiency by bottling its own still and sparkled water. Although a seemingly simple step, tapping into the natural springs below the bar has revealed interesting information about the geography of the area and, as owner Martin Caldwell explains, has created further links to the Speckled Hen‚Äôs -year history.‚ÄúRight under our feet is the Triassic Aquer, which stretches from the Castlereagh to Black Mountain,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThere has always been a well under the bar, so given that we‚Äôre filtering our own water anyway, it made sense to put in a chiller, a cooler and a carbonator to make fizzy water too.‚ÄúThere was originally a well there and the previous owner had tapped into it. During the winter time you can actually see little springs coming up out in the carpark. There used to be a well where our beer garden is now where they used to dip the buckets for water. The pub goes back to , so it goes back a fair while. They used to brew their own beers and everything here, so access to spring water was vital.‚ÄùHe continued: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fantastic that a place of this age is still ing and providing hospitality and services. This used to be the old post road and was also one of the main roads to Dublin at the time, so coaches used to stop along here. It was actually alleged that Daniel O‚ÄôConnell stopped here before. It would have had to have been self-sufficient. We‚Äôre essentially going back to the notion of our own self-sufficiency in terms of the supply of water as well.‚ÄùThe Speckled Hen started bottling its water last month, installing a new filtration system that provides fresh four-times-filtered water for its customers. The water is, of course, filtered through the rocks on its journey across the mountains that, according to Queen‚Äôs University researchers, began , to , years ago. As for the punters, Martin says they see it as a ‚Äúgreat novelty‚Äù.‚ÄúThey‚Äôre getting their draft beer and now they are getting draft water, he said.‚ÄúThe kids come in and want cordials or juices, so now well ask themthey want still or fizzy water ‚Äì they think it‚Äôs a great novelty getting the fizzy water in the cordial.‚ÄùWhile making connections with the pub‚Äôs past, Martin and his team are also looking to the future with the installation of farming allotments that will provide fruit, veg and more for it‚Äôs kitchens in the years to come.

"We all really felt it," he said.Read MoreClaire McNeilly: Why do we still not know how Belfast Primark fire started In October alone footfall was down % on the year before. Fast food restaurant City Picnic closed on the day of the fire and hasnt been opened since, though hopes to be open again by the autumn. Others such as Pizza Boutique struggled on for a time after the cordon was reduced, only to also shutter their premises completely.Primark opened two stores, one at the back of its Bank Buildings shop and another on Donegall Place - though it is also planning a restoration of Bank Buildings. It was followed by St Kevins College in Enniskillen in st place with .%, and, both in joint nd place, St Catherines College in Armagh and St Michaels College in Enniskillen with .%.Dalriada School headmaster Tom Skelton said he was "absolutely delighted" with the results."Its a fantastic achievement for the staff and pupils involved," he said. "To take every child over the line with % five A*-C represents a lot of hard work and the support of parents as well."Two years ago we were % as well, so were delighted to get up there again. I think it reflects well on the school, the pupils and the standards set by staff."Mr Skelton said the league table "shows the success of the grammar school system" and he added: "Pastoral care is a massive part of it. We have a very simple saying, Happy pupils, high expectation, high achievement and thats it in a nutshell."The school is well led by a supportive board of governors."Principal of Loreto Grammar, Omagh, Grainne OHanlon, said she was "delighted" at its joint top ranking, the first time it has topped the league table."It is the result of the professional relationship and trust which the teachers establish with the pupils," she said. Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# UKIs Queen‚Äôs Speech plan legit or has Boris gone prorogue The Prime Minister insists he just wants to set out his ‚Äòexciting agenda‚Äô. data-dfpadtargeting."." title"Queen Elizabeth II reading the Queen‚Äôs Speech in  ." width"" ""  ." title"Queen Elizabeth II reading the Queen‚Äôs Speech in  ." width"" ""  Queen Elizabeth II reading the Queen‚Äôs Speech in  .By Patrick Daly, PA Political CorrespondentAugust   CommentsIs Queen‚Äôs Speech plan legit or has Boris gone prorogue BelfastBoris Johnson has asked the Queen to prorogue Parliament, which will effectively suspend it for a month.https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk is-queens-speech-plan-legit-or-has-boris-gone-prorogue-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news uk article.ece cce AUTOCROP h bpanews_edc-e-c-bfd-adb_EmailBoris Johnson has asked the Queen to prorogue Parliament, which will effectively suspend it for a month..pushThe Prime Minister insists he is doing so simply to set out his ‚Äúexciting agenda‚Äù in a Queen‚Äôs Speech on October .But critics, including Commons Speaker John Bercow, have lambasted the move, calling it a ‚Äúconstitutional outrage‚Äù designed to stop MPs from intervening as the UK heads towards a no-deal Brexit on October .Here are some of the key questions and answers triggered by Wednesday‚Äôs move:‚Äì What does prorogation mean Prorogation marks the end of a parliamentary session. The current session, which started on June ,  with the last State Opening and Queen‚Äôs Speech, has been the longest in history.‚Äì Who does it The Queen formally prorogues Parliament following guidance from the Privy Council,¬† which¬†is her body of advisers made up mainly of senior politicians." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  ‚Äì Why does Boris Johnson want to prorogue Parliament now A new Government brings with it new plans and legislation which are set out in a Queen‚Äôs Speech. Mr Johnson insists he has asked the Queen to bring about the end of the current session of Parliament so he can start anew.‚Äì What happens during prorogation While Parliament is prorogued, MPs and peers cannot formally debate policy and legislation or make any laws of their own.Parliamentary scrutiny is suspended and the powers of the Houses of Commons and Lords are effectively taken away until the next Queen‚Äôs Speech.‚Äì How long will Parliament be prorogued for Prorogation normally tends to be for a short amount of time ‚Äì no longer than two weeks, with it leading to either a general election or the start of a new Parliamentary session.Under the new plan, Parliament is set to be dissolved in the second week of its September sitting, possibly as early as Tuesday September , with MPs due tofor the Queen‚Äôs Speech on October .Parliament had been due to break for its conference recess for at least two weeks in the lead up to October, even before the news of the prorogation broke, with Number  arguing that MPs are only losing an extra four sitting days in total.‚Äì So why has the move sparked such anger There have been fears for a number of months that, should the Government not be able to strike an exit deal with the European Union, the Prime Minister could look to prorogue Parliament to prevent MPs from attempting to stop the UK leaving without a deal.Critics believe this is what he is doing now. Senior opposition figures and Tory opponents of a no-deal Brexit met on Tuesday to draw up plans to stop the UK crashing out of the EU without an agreement. A day later the PM has effectively moved to curtail their time to draw-up legislation that would prevent Britain from exiting without a Withdrawal Agreement signed-off.‚Äì So could a snap general election still be on the cards Commentators saw the surprise announcement that¬†Chancellor Sajid Javid will set out Whitehall spending budgets next week as a sign that the new administration was ramping up plans for an early election.But inviting the monarch to Parliament for the pomp and ceremony of the Queen‚Äôs Speech on October  would be an odd thing to dothe PM is actually planning a snap election.However,opposition and rebel Tory MPs unite behind a no-confidence motion against the Government in retaliation against the plans to prorogue, that could force Parliament into a stalemate where a general election is the only resolution.

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# UKWhat is Privy Council‚Äôs role amid plan to suspend Parliament Bors Johnson has said the Queen‚Äôs Speech will be held on October . data-dfpadtargeting"" title"The Queen at the State Opening of Parliament " width"" ""  " title"The Queen at the State Opening of Parliament " width"" ""  The Queen at the State Opening of Parliament By Tony Jones, PA Court CorrespondentAugust   CommentsWhat is Privy Council‚Äôs role amid plan to suspend Parliament BelfastPrime Minister Boris Johnson‚Äôs plan to suspend Parliament ‚Äì known as prorogation ‚Äì ahead of the State Opening of a new session, will reportedly be considered at a Privy Council meeting at the Queen‚Äôs Balmoral estate in Scotland. https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk what-is-privy-councils-role-amid-plan-to-suspend-parliament-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news uk article.ece da AUTOCROP h bpanews_ad--aa--dfebbca_EmailPrime Minister Boris Johnson‚Äôs plan to suspend Parliament ‚Äì known as prorogation ‚Äì ahead of the State Opening of a new session, will reportedly be considered at a Privy Council meeting at the Queen‚Äôs Balmoral estate in Scotland..pushMr Johnson has said the Queen‚Äôs Speech will be held on October .Here, some of the key questions about the institutions and conventions involved are answered.‚Äì What is the Privy Council The Queen is head of the Privy Council whose role is to advise the monarch as she carries out her duties as head of state. It dates from the time of the Norman kings when the monarch met in private ‚Äì hence the description Privy ‚Äì with his or her group of trusted counsellors who fulfilled the role that the Cabinet performs today.‚Äì What does it do As well as advising the Queen it provides administrative support for the leaders of the Commons and Lords. It also has responsibility for the affairs of  institutions, charities and companies incorporated by Royal Charter. The body also has a judicial role as it is the court of final appeal for the UK overseas territories and Crown Dependencies, and for a number of Commonwealth countries. It also has a number of important executive s ‚Äì Parliament is dissolved by proclamation approved by the Queen in Council and the monarch formally prorogues Parliament on the Council‚Äôs advice." width"" "" rel"nofollow"  Jacob Rees-Mogg is a member of the Privy Council ‚Äì What is the ceremony for becoming a Privy Counsellor Tradition stipulates on being appointed to the post new members affirm an oath of allegiance, kiss the Queen‚Äôs hand ‚Äì and here it is believed they kneel as they do so ‚Äì then affirm a Privy Counsellor oath. New members sworn in after Mr Johnson became Prime Minister included Jacob Rees-Mogg who became Lord President of the Council as he is now Leader of the Commons.‚Äì Who are its members There are around  Privy Counsellors who take an oath of confidentiality and members are styled Rt Hon. All the Cabinet are members along with some middle-ranking ministers, senior judges, figures from the Commonwealth and the leader of the opposition. An inidual becomes a counsellor for le, although their role may diminish over time.‚Äì When are Privy Council meetings held The Privy Council meets around once a month with the gatherings held at Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle or, occasionally, Balmoral. The meetings are held by the Queen with a Clerk of the Council and usually around four ministers, with the discussions unusually held standing up to ensure they do not last too long.‚Äì What is the Queen‚Äôs Speech The Queen‚Äôs Speech sets out the Government‚Äôs agenda for the coming session of parliament, outlining proposed policies and legislation. It is delivered by the monarch during the State Opening of Parliament which marks the formal start of the parliamentary year.‚Äì Does the Queen write the speech The Queen remains politically neutral and above party politics so the speech is written by the Government.

title: nerve visual gallery close doors ebrington
story: The Nerve Visual Gallery at Ebrington is set to close at the beginning of next month, the Derry News has learned.The announcement will come as a great disappointment to art lovers in the city who have frequented the gallery over the past number of years and will be a loss to the Ebrington site.When it first opened in  it was lauded as a ‚Äúmajor new venue for visual arts in the Northern Ireland‚Äù.However, at the weekend a spokesperson for The Executive Officeconfirmed: ‚ÄúThe Nerve Centre has operated a gallery in a section of the Creative Hub Building   on the Ebrington Site for three years and gave notice that they intend to close the gallery on  September .‚ÄúThe Executive Office is currently considering options for the section occupied by Nerve Gallery.‚ÄùLocated in the former army barracks at Ebrington, the Nerve Centre developed a series of major visual arts commissions with partners including - Now, National Museums NI, The Fondation Gilles Caron, Gallery of Photography Dublin, Ultra Lab Madrid and Matts Gallery London.Exhibitions have shone a light on pivotal moments in Northern Ireland‚Äôs history such as the Civil Rights movement and the Troubles.The Lost Moment exhibition looked anew at the Civil Rights movement fty years on from the marches and peaceful protests that immediately preceded the Troubles. It featured dramatic images of the famous Selma to Montgomery civil rights march in , alongside work on the Northern Irish civil rights struggle, from the first march in August  to the Battle of the Bogside in .Picturing Derry brought together some of the most iconic images from the Troubles and the most recent exhibition explored anxieties around Brexit which were part of a series of cross-border projects.Local artists were also regularly showcased at the gallery.Earlier this year plans to build a whiskey distillery in Ebrington fell through.But last week positive news emerged of plans to build two Grade A office blocks and a -apartment retirement village at the Waterside site.The Nerve Centre was contacted for comment regarding the gallery‚Äôs closure but did not respond at the time of going to press.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: new cain documents highlight unresolved political issues
story: A new batch of documents added to Ulster University‚Äôs CAIN archive demonstrate how important issues affecting Northern Irish politics twenty years ago remain pertinent today.The newly released material provides a valuable insight into the period between -, mostly notably in relation to the Brooke Mayhew talks.In addition, it also charts developments in Anglo-Irish relations for these years, ongoing discussions around ious political and security matters, as well as important issues such as fair employment, the Irish language and community relations.The Brooke Mayhew negotiations took place to secure ‚Äúa new, more broadly based agreement‚Äù which would replace the Anglo Irish Agreement.On the  March, , the first roundtable negotiations, excluding Sinn Fein, took place in an attempt to end the political stalemate in N.I., and continued through to November .Although they appeared to achieve little the Brooke Mayhew talks were the first to have "three strands", the relationships within Northern Ireland, between Northern Ireland and the Republic, and between London and Dublin. A basis had been laid for future discussions.The CAIN website, whose workers are based at the Magee campus in Derry, provides an extensive range of information and source material on the conflict and politics from  to the present day.The site is used by a worldwide audience and has received more than  million visits since it was launched in March .Earlier this year, the Derry News revealed that it was under threat of closure but thanks to a staunch defence of the site mounted by academics and researchers, Ulster University announced a nine-month reprieve while funding options are explored.Around  documents relating to the years  and  have been added to the CAIN website as part of ongoing work involving the Ulster University and the Public Record Office of Northern Ireland .The latest additions will bring to more than , the number of PRONI records available on CAIN.Dr Brendan Lynn, CAIN Deputy Director, said the archive is delighted to have been able to continue its cooperation with PRONI and to update the existing section with material dealing with the years  and .Mr Lynn commented: ‚ÄúCAIN has always sought to work with and iniduals, groups and organisations with relevant information relating to the Northern Ireland ‚Äòtroubles‚Äô in order to make it available on-line.‚ÄúAn obvious example of this has been the partnership that CAIN has developed with The Public Record Office of Northern Ireland . As the official archive for Northern Ireland, one of PRONI‚Äôs many responsibilities is to receive government records from the early s onwards and to make them available for researchers.‚ÄúThe development of ‚ÄòPRONI Records on CAIN‚Äô therefore provides people with an opportunity to gain access to a selection of material from the official files, that to date, chart the period from  to .‚ÄúLooking ahead both CAIN and PRONI hope to continue this work to enable researchers to examine the events and personalities involved in the evolving ‚Äòpeace process‚Äô of the s which culminated with the signing of the Good Friday Agreement in April .‚Äù‚ÄòPolitical stalemate‚ÄôIn terms of the latest documents, one of the most striking features of this material is that some of the issues which are so prominent today are the same ones which confronted politicians and policy makers back then.‚ÄúFor instance the search for an end to the political stalemate in Northern Ireland was dominated by a series of long, drawn out discussions ‚Äì often referred to as the Brooke Mayhew talks of -. Whilst these were ultimately to end in failure they did leave behind an important template that was to be used at a later date,‚Äù Mr Lynn added.Dr Michael Willis, PRONI Director, has welcomed the publication of previously secret records through a continuing partnership between PRONI and Conflict Archive on the INternet .He said: ‚ÄúPRONI‚Äôs mission is to identy, preserve and promote public access to Northern Ireland‚Äôs archival heritage.‚ÄúThis latest addition of official documents to the CAIN website enhances the opportunity to view and read key documents from the time. It is an invaluable resource for anyone studying our recent past.‚ÄùTo access the documents you can visit: https:cain.ulster.ac.uk proni googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh
