title: nicola sturgeon accuses pm acting like dictator dark day democracy
story: The Scottish First Minister joined a chorus of outrage at the PMrsquos plan, which would see the Commons shut down for more than a month in the run-up to Britainrsquos European Union departure date.The Prime Ministerrsquos actions make it ldquoclearer than ever that Scotland cannot be properly served by a shambolic, crumbling Westminster system, and that our future lies as an independent country, she added.Mr Johnson, however, insisted there would still be ldquoample time for MPs to debate Brexit either side of a crunch EU summit on October  ndash despite seeking a parliamentary suspension from around September  until the State Opening on October .# @NicolaSturgeon: ldquoShutting down Parliament in order to force through a no-deal Brexit, which will do untold and lasting damage to the country against the wishes of MPs is not democracy, itrsquos dictatorship." pic lRMVvflmmdash The SNPAugust , But Commons Speaker John Bercow labelled the move a ldquoconstitutional outrage, saying he had not been consulted.And Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThis is a dark day for democracy. Attempting to shut down Parliament to force through a no-deal Brexit is an outrageous assault on basic democratic principles.ldquoIn doing so, Boris Johnson is acting more like a dictator than a prime minister in what is still supposed to be a parliamentary democracy.ldquoInstead of this abuse of process Boris Johnson should have the courage of his convictions and call a general election.The SNP leader pledged the PMrsquos plan would be ldquofiercely resisted byher party and other opposition politicians in the House of Commons, urging Conservatives who are ldquoconcerned about the direction their party and government is taking to speak out against the Government.Ms Sturgeon also called on Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson to join in actions to try to halt Mr Johnson, stating that she ldquokeeps telling us she opposes a no-deal Brexit ndash today she must say what she will do to help stop it.SNP depute leader Keith Brown however claimed that the Scottish Conservative chief had ldquogone into hiding, along with other leading figures in her party. --Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson was accused of having lsquogone into hidingrsquo  --Scottish Secretary Alister Jack cancelled media interviews which had been scheduled to take place in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning.Addressing journalists gathered outside the Scotland Office, Mr Jack said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted the Prime Minister is going to have a Queenrsquos Speech on October .ldquoItrsquos a very good step forward in having a Queenrsquos Speech. Wersquove had a long Parliament. We need a Queenrsquos Speech to deliver, as he said on the steps of Downing Street, an exciting legislative programme for this new government.ldquoWhat will then happen is there will be a debate on that and there will be time enough to discuss Brexit and many other things in the Queenrsquos Speech ahead of us, hopefully getting a good deal from the European Union at the Council of Ministers meeting on October .Mr Jack added: ldquoThis is no dferent to what wersquove had, bar a few days, every day since Tony Blairrsquos premiership.ldquoWe have always had a conference recess. This is the conference recess with a few days added on. We donrsquot need to come back and prorogue Parliament for the Queenrsquos Speech, wersquoll do it before we leave, wersquoll have the Queenrsquos Speech and therersquos ample time for debate.Amid the outcry a group of more than  cross party MPs and peers launched a legal bid to try to stop Mr Johnson from proroguing Parliament.Jolyon Maugham QC, director of the Good Law Project, which is supporting the move, confirmed a motion had been filed at the Court of Session in Edinburgh.We have filed a motion asking the Court of Session to suspend the Prime Ministers request that Parliament be suspended. pic vkdRofpNsVmdash Jo Maugham QCAugust , Meanwhile, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie hit out at what he branded ldquoan Eton coup and a democratic outrage.He added: ldquoIhope that Ruth Davidson will join the chorus of condemnation that this decision deserves and confirm that Scottish Conservatives will oppose any measures to prevent Parliament having its say.Scottish Greens co-Leader Patrick Harvie said: ldquoBoris Johnson led a Leave campaign which cheated and broke the law to win.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that now hersquos the Prime Minister he is continuing his assault against democracy.ldquoIf we need to lsquotake back controlrsquo from anyone, we need to take it back from him..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, story: Though almost six years since little Oran Creaney passed away, he is still inspiring people to raise money for the Children#s Heartbeat Trust.His grandfather, Francie McAlinden and his colleagues in Lurgan Masters Swim Club, have organised a Swim  Oran event which they hope will raise much needed funds for the charity.Oran Creaney.Oran, son of Barry and Aisling Creaney, was just six years old when he died and in his short lehe inspired many by his bravery.Or√°n was born in June  with a single ventricle heart. His heart condition coupled with a feeding peg meant that he had little energy and was tube fed three times a day. This never got him down and he was proud of his ‚ÄúSpecial Heart‚Äù. Sadly, after his third open heart surgery, Or√°n passed away on the th of October .The Creaney family have been keen to help raise funds for the Children‚Äôs Heartbeat Trust which helped them so much throughout Oran‚Äôs le. Now Lord Mayor of Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon Council Mealla Campbell is challenging the public to ‚ÄúSwim  Oran‚Äù.Having visited Lough Neagh Discovery Centre to launch the event, she announced that she too will be doing the ‚ÄúSwim  Oran‚Äù on th September  at the Centre.Cllr Campbell challenged everyone to take part in either the Try-A-Swim or one of the longer swims or indeed to go along and support the action-packed family fun day also taking place on dry land.Swim  Or√°n will be a charity open water swimming event to raise funds for the Children‚Äôs Heartbeat Trust.There will be a m ‚ÄòTry-A-Swim‚Äô and a m fun swim with Ripples Special Olympics Swim Club, while the longer distances will include m, .k and k. title: ulster business top  sees sales rise by
story: Posted on Monday August  by Ulster Business Michael Neill, head of office, AL Goodbody Belfast, sponsor of the Top , Flavio Malnarcic, chief financial officer, Moy Park and Ulster Business editor John Mulgrew Northern Ireland‚Äôs largest businesses have seen sales rise by .% to more ¬£.bn, the Ulster Business Top  Northern Ireland Companies list  has revealed.The list, sponsored by AL Goodbody, showcases the successes of the biggest firms from right across Northern Ireland. And poultry giant Moy Park has also retained the top spot on the list for the eighth year running, posting sales of more than ¬£.bn.However, across the list pre-tax profits fell overall, dropping from ¬£.bn to ¬£.m, when comparing the previous year‚Äôs accounts for the Top .New entrants to the list this year include Thompson Aero Seating ‚Äì which shot up to number  ‚Äì along with McBurney Transport, while others saw their positions increase substantially.Michael Neill, head of office, AL Goodbody Belfast, said: ‚ÄúThe results of this resilience and determination speak for themselves in this year‚Äôs Top  rankings, with collective turnover increasing by .% in the  months to ¬£.bn. ‚ÄúWhile many companies are long-standing players and remain unchallenged at the top end of the rankings, it is positive to see businesses continue to rise up the ranks, year-on-year.‚Äù And Chris Kirke, Moy Park president, said: ‚ÄúWe are honoured to be named Northern Ireland‚Äôs top company once again and to help shine a light on NI‚Äôs proud agri-food heritage and strong manufacturing credentials. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the people in Moy Park that make the company what it is, and I am extraordinarily proud of our great team, and of all our growers and partners who continually go above and beyond to make it the successful business it is today.‚Äù The Top  edition of Ulster Business is out nowView all articlesSearch ulsterbusiness -- --SearchSearch -- --Follow us -- -- copy  Ulster Business Designed  Built by Laposa, Powered by Onxshop

title: top  moy park takes number one spot
story: Posted on Thursday August  by Ulster Business From a purely editorial perspective it would be refreshing to have a dferent company head up the Ulster Business Top  Northern Ireland Companies list.But Moy Park has now made it to the top for eight consecutive years, as the poultry processing giant continues to expand both its workforce, global sales and pre-tax profit ‚Äì firmly setting its place at Northern Ireland‚Äôs biggest business, with a workforce of more than , here alone.In the last year, it has grown turnover to just over ¬£.bn, up from ¬£.bn a year earlier, while pre-tax profits have surged by % ‚Äì rising to ¬£.m in its latest set of accounts, ending December .The business supplies Moy Park branded and own label chicken products to leading retailers and foodservice providers throughout the UK, Ireland and Europe.In numbers, Moy Park processes six million fresh chickens each week, , turkeys a year, along with , tonnes of other ‚Äòadded value products‚Äô.London-born Chris Kirke replaced long-serving boss Janet McCollum in , less than a year after Craigavon-based Moy Park was taken over by new US owners Pilgrim‚Äôs.And around a year ago, Flavio Malnarcicjoined the business ‚Äì then as executive business director ‚Äì before taking over as the firm‚Äôs chief financial officer.He was formerly business director at JBS Global, and has a senior leadership background as executive director of the poultry and export business in Seara, also as chief financial officer and chief executive at Tyson do Brazil and finance roles in Cargill.‚ÄúThere has been a consistence in the performance. We have been growing volumes‚Ä¶ we got to six million birds each week, which is about a third of the UK market. For the UK, it is a signicantly big company.‚ÄúLooking year-over-year, our performance was very consistent in the last few years.‚Äù‚ÄúFor people working there, working for a company which is the largest employer in a country, the top company, it is a source of pride for us.‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt think that drives the behaviour of the team. We are more interested in making sure that our performance is sustainable in terms of margins.‚ÄúIt is nice that we arebut that is not our main goal. We are making sure that we are sustainable, work on quality, safety. There are lots of other things. It‚Äôs making sure that we fit our customer needs.‚ÄúWe have a lot focus on that, and we need to be competitive.‚ÄùAnd as for growth, expanding turnover isn‚Äôt necessarily the main focus, according to Flavio‚ÄúA lot of the efforts in the last year have been to consolidate the management tools they have in Pilgrim‚Äôs. They are very keen on efficiency, so that‚Äôs one of their strategies. ‚Äú a lot of focus in improving our performance, it‚Äôs how we can be more efficient, focusing on a portfolio that feeds our customer base, how we deal with our customers.‚ÄùView all articlesSearch ulsterbusiness -- --SearchSearch -- --Follow us -- -- copy  Ulster Business Designed  Built by Laposa, Powered by Onxshop

title: ulster business top  launch

title: axiald from start up seed to a global business
story: Posted on Wednesday  August  by Ulster Business Medical D printing firm axialD has shone as one of the major success stories to emerge from leading technology hub Catalyst. We speak to founder Daniel Crawford and his team about the journey so far A spark in the mind of Daniel Crawford as he studied for his masters degree in Glasgow just a few years ago has grown into a business at the sharp end of technology. axialD is tasked with turning the complicated and laborious process of converting D medical scans into D models ‚Äì and producing them for use by surgeons and medical professionals. It‚Äôs an ever-growing business, spun out of Ulster University, which is expanding its reach across the UK, Ireland and now into the US where it‚Äôs targeting a burgeoning fresh marketplace. The company has been involved with Catalyst since , been directly involved with a host of its programmes, and is participating in the EU INTERREG funded North West Centre for Advanced Manufacturing , managed by the Special European Union Programmes Body . Catalyst is Northern Ireland‚Äôs leading technology hub, home to  companies and around , staff. Daniel has a strong team around him ‚Äì growing to  staff based in Belfast city centre, including Niall Haslam, chief technology officer, Katie McKinley, head of new business and strategic partnerships and Cathy Coomber as operations manager. While studying medical visualisation and human anatomy in Glasgow, Daniel was exposed to the raft of imaging available ‚Äì including CT, MRI and ultrasound, and began examining how the crucial data could be better used. The biomedical physics undergraduate grew the idea into his thesis ‚Äì looking at converting D data sets and converting them into fully D printable files. ‚ÄúThat allows us to turn images into D models to allow surgeons or registrars, to understand digital pathologies, before going in to theatre,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut we discovered it wasn‚Äôt just good for that and surgeons also wanted to get their hands on the D models.‚Äù That gave Daniel greater scope for developing the concept. In one early case, a surgeon was able to use one of the D prints to identy small fractures in a patient who had suffered a motorcycle crash, that weren‚Äôt initially apparent using more traditional methods. The company was thrust into Catalyst‚Äôs Springboard programme in  ‚Äì a  week scheme which allowed a would-be entrepreneur, fresh out of university, access to business training and development, which included working with PathXL‚Äôs Stuart Harvey. From there, it was into the Halo programme ‚Äì bringing axialD together with angel investors in order to get the start-up off the ground. It landed ¬£, through Techstart and private investors, which allowed the company to get the ball rolling. Through Catalyst, Daniel also got the opportunity to visit MIT and the entrepreneurial development programme, Way to Scale, bringing axialD to Massachusetts and the Boston area ‚Äì the global heart of the health technology sector. Niall Haslam is axialD‚Äôs chief technical officer. He said a Belfast and Boston partnership has helped strengthen the links between the cities, bringing firms from Northern Ireland to the US for both networking and scoping out the potential for setting up shop across the Atlantic. ‚ÄúThe Way to Scale program brings entrepreneurs together. It‚Äôs a great networking opportunity,‚Äù Niall says. axialD is now a partner in the EU INTERREG-funded NW CAM, which brings together a network of research institutes, universities and enterprises to carry out research in advanced manufacturing. It is working with Ulster University on a number of projects, including looking at developing custom designed jigs for hospitals to produce D models. Cathy Coomber has been with axialD for three years. ‚ÄúWhat we have done in that time is looking at standardising the processes,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBiomedical engineers from Ulster University and those across the UK are producing data, manually segmenting thousands of medical images in order to help them develop an algorithm. ‚ÄúThat allows us to massively improve our standardised process and reduce the time involved in producing those files.‚Äù That could mean reducing the time down from up to five hours, to as little as an hour. ‚ÄúWhen the company started, Daniel was able to get those early users excited in Glasgow, and then setting up in Belfast there were key surgeons which helped set the pace,‚Äù Katie McKinley, head of new business and strategic partnerships said. The company has since been involved with NHS frameworks as a means to help remove as many bottlenecks as possible. This involves developing and marketing the products to the NHS and HSC in the Republic ‚Äì helping them to learn about the product, the process and what area of specialism it can be used in. ‚ÄúIn the last  months with the development of the algorithms, we are moving in to the US,‚Äù Katie said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre seeing a lot of growth in the US.‚Äù And the axialD team is also growing fast. ‚ÄúWe have  staff at the moment but are looking to expand in  months,‚Äù Daniel said. ‚ÄúThat includes new staff in the US to help grow and manage that market as we further expand our software team back home.‚Äù The success of axialD mirrors the overall success of Catalyst, since its inception  years ago.
